narrative: On June 7,2023, at 10: AM., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Carol Anderson conducted an announced pre-licensing inspection to the above facility. LPA Anderson met with President Antwone O'Quinn. LPA Anderson toured the administrative office for the Transitional Housing Placement Plus Foster Care (THP+FC). The participants' apartment units will be in within a two hour radius from the Administration office. LPA Anderson inspected the office. The following areas were observed: The Administrative Office located in the Emerald Plaza Building in San Diego. There is reception area/waiting room located in suite 400. There are three conference rooms in suite 400 that will be used to conduct confidential interviews. All participants' and staff files will be locked in file cabinets inside suite 400. Staff desk will be in suite 400. All documents have been received and the physical plant meets the minimum requirements of Title 22 regulations. An exit interview was conducted, a copy of this report was discussed and left with President Antwone O'Quinn.

On May 14, 2024, at 12:30PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Carol Anderson conducted an unannounced annual/required inspection. There was no one at the facility at the time. LPA contacted Execute Director President Antwone O'Quinn via telephone stated that he will be there in 30 minutes. At 1:30PM, LPA Anderson toured the administrative office for the Transitional Housing Placement Plus Foster Care (THP+FC), with Antwone O'Quinn. Currently there are 11 participants' living in apartments throughout San Diego County. The Administrative Office is in the Emerald Plaza Building in San Diego. There is a reception area/waiting room located in the lobby area and staff break room. There are three conference rooms to conduct confidential interviews. The administrative office consists of several staff workstations. Emergency Disaster Plan, Personal Rights, Foster Care Ombudsman are posted in a prominent area for participants to view inside the administrative office. Telephones, computers, fax and copying machines are operable. LPA reviewed six participants' files and three staff files. Fire extinguishers are current, there are fire sprinklers, smoke detectors, and carbon monoxide detectors located in the building. A complete first aid kit readily accessible located inside the administrative office. A review of Guardian on May 14, 2024, indicates that all facility staff associated to the facility had DOJ, FBI, and child abuse index check clearances. There were no deficiencies cited for today's inspection. An exit interview was conducted, a copy of this report was discussed and left with President Antwone O'Quinn.

On August 15, 2024, at 10:30AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Carol Anderson met with Executive Director Antwone O'Quinn for purpose to conduct an announced, licensee initiated case management inspection. The above-named agency is requesting a capacity increase for the Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP). The Transitional Housing Placement Program is currently licensed to serve 30 participants. The agency is requesting an increase from 30 participants of a total of capacity of 100 participants. Agency staff provided verification there will be social workers among this caseload to serve these participants. According to Transitional Housing Placement: Section 86020 -Fire Clearance. The THPP shall secure and maintain for each THPP participant living unit any fire clearance required by and approved by the fire authority having jurisdiction. The THPP shall request a fire clearance for the THPP participant living unit prior to residence of a non-ambulatory individual. The non-ambulatory individual may be the participant, persons approved by the licensee and authorized by the licensing agency to remain in the apartment, the child of a THPP participant, a THPP employee, or the employee's child(ren). The increase of capacity is approved as of August 15,2024.

narrative: On November 18, 2024, at 10:00 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nestor Gomez and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Kevin Sauk conducted an announced visit for the purpose of a pre-licensing inspection for the above-mentioned facility. Licensing staff met with the COO (Chief Operating Officer) Jennifer Heinen-Stiffler who granted access, and who provided a tour of the office for the inspection. The office is located at Eugenia Place, Suite 104, Carpinteria, CA 93101. The program only has one single site location that is 20 minutes away from this administrative office. This single site location is currently still under construction. The office is set up as follows: Suite 104 is located on the first floor of a two story commercial building. This suite contains a large conference room for large and private meetings, as wells as a copy room, server room, storage room and an exercise room. There are a total of eight cubicles in the office space. Four cubicles are located on the left side and 4 on the right side of the office space. There are a total of 10 offices in the suite. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was emailed to the facility.

facility_name: MY HOME AT THE LYONS HOUSE
narrative: On 3/26/25, at 9:45am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nancy O'Connell conducted an unannounced visit for the purpose of a Post-Licensing inspection for the above-listed facility. LPA was granted access to the facility office and was met by Amy Tovias, Facility Administrator, at 10:50am. FA granted access, and who provided a tour of the entire suite for the inspection. The office is set up as follows: The office is located in a two-story commercial building in suite #104. The Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) administrative office is located within the suite that maintains additional offices for the YMCA organization. The THPP office is located near the front entrance of the suite and to the right of the exercise room. The program only has one single site location that is 20 minutes away from this administrative office. This suite contains a large conference room that can be used for confidential meetings, as wells as a copy room, server room, storage room and an exercise room. Four cubicles are located on the left side and 4 on the right side of the office space. There are a total of 10 offices in the suite. LPA observed the following: · Client/personnel records are stored electronically and FA maintains access to all records · Required signage postings were observed in administrative office · There is designated space for clients to conduct confidential meetings with social workers/authorized representatives within the designated THPP office as well as in the conference room. Continued on LIC809C.r · LIC500 was reviewed and all staff were confirmed to have a criminal records clearance · Client roster was reviewed and contained all required information Administrator was informed that the administrative office is the licensed location for the facility and where all required visits will be conducted. LPA O'Connell explained that the remote site, where youth reside, will be visited and inspected as necessary only. The licensee is required to ensure that the remote site is maintained according to county/state requirements. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was emailed to the facility administrator.

decoration. Confidential interviews report that although the sword was requested to be kept as an antique it is still considered a weapon. Confidential interviews reported that NMD asked PM2 for permission to keep a sword that was given to NMD as an antique. Confidential interviews reported that PM2 granted permission. An additional allegation that the agency (New Alternatives Transitional Housing Program (NA THP)) is not following their Program Statement was also received by CCL on February 5, 2021. Specifically, it was reported that NA THP program statement youth found with a weapon would be going against program policy. Confidential interviews reported that NA THP program policy is that weapons are not allowed. Confidential interviews reported that PM2 granting permission for NMD to keep the sword in NMD's housing unit went against NA THP program statement. CCL received an additional allegation that the agency did not ensure a safe environment for the participant resulting in injury. Confidential interviews report although the sword that PM2 granted permission for was not the weapon that caused injury to NMD, the presence and threat of its use escalated the incident. Confidential interviews and record review report that the presence and threat of use of the sword lead to the environment being unsafe for the participant and lead to NMD's injury. Based on confidential interviews and record review of facility documentation the allegations Program Manager (Program Manager 2 (PM2)) allowed participant (Non-Minor Dependent (NMD)) to have a weapon in the housing unit, the agency (New Alternatives Transitional Housing Program (NA THP)) is not following their Program Statement, and the agency (NA THP) did not ensure a safe environment for the participant (NMD) resulting in injury are substantiated. The preponderance of evidence standards have been met. Facility is cited for violation of California Code of Regulations (CCR) Title 22, Division 6, Chapter Article 7 regulation Buildings and Grounds (d) Notwithstanding section 80087(h), firearms and other weapons shall not be stored in the THPP participant living units, CCR Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 3 regulation Plan of Operation (k) the facility shall operate in accordance with the terms specified in the Plan of Operation and may be cited for not doing so, CCR Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 7 regulation Physical Environment (a) The facility shall be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair at all times for the safety and well-being of clients, employees and visitors. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided along with appeal rights New Alternatives Inc., Program Manager Carol Lockwood.

The investigation was conducted by Special Investigator, Lucius Charlemagne with Community Care Licensing's (CCL) Investigations Branch Bureau. The investigation included interviews with El Cajon Police Department, San Diego Institutional Evaluation Unit (IEU), Program Manager 1 (PM1), Program Manager 2 (PM2), County Social Worker (CSW), and Non-Minor Dependent (NMD). In addition, law enforcement records, county records and facility records were reviewed. On February 5, CCL received an allegation of program manager (Program Manager 2 (PM2)) allowed participant (Non-Minor Dependent (NMD)) to have a weapon in the housing unit. narrative: On August 16, 2021 at 10:30 am Licensing Program Analyst's (LPA's) Darlene Almaraz-Oseguera and Adaleyci Caballero met with Program Manager Carol Lockwood. The purpose of this visit is to conduct an annual/required inspection. The facility is licensed to provide Transitional Housing Placement's for Non-minor Dependents and/or Transitional Housing Placement for foster children. The facility provides care for 60 participants ages 18 through 21. The facility utilizes apartment buildings and housing model throughout San Diego County for Participants to reside. Currently, there are 57 participants and forty three scattered apartment sites in the program. Participants residences are inspected by the case managers weekly. The Administrative office is located at Kettner Blvd., Ste.3B1, San Diego, CA 92101 consist of desks and offices furnished with chairs, tables and computers. There is a club house, conference room and store on site for participants to use the computer and obtaining personal items. LPA observed participant files and staff files were stored in secured cabinets and are in program manager's office. Currently the facility is staffed with two Program Managers and six Case managers. LPA's reviewed seven staff files and fifteen client files. All staff met the minimum qualifications and training requirements. A review of the facility file indicated that the facility is current with the Annual Fees. Licensee is aware of submitting unusual incident reports as needed to the Department to include all Law Enforcement contact. A review of records shows that all staff have FBI, DOJ and Child Abuse Index Check clearances. A review of the facility file indicated that the facility is current with the Annual Fees. LPA's left LIC 308, LIC400, LIC 500 and LIC 610C to be completed and return to Community Care Licensing within 30 days Based on LPA's observations, there are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted and copy of the report was left with the Program Director, Carol Lockwood.

On September 22, 2021 at 10: AM, Licensing Program Analyst 's(LPA's) Anastasia Flores and Lorena Valenzuela, arrived at the agency for the purpose of conducting an unannounced Required/ Annual Licensing Inspection for the agency's Transitional Housing Program (THP) At 11: AM, LPA's met and toured the facility with Program Director, Danielle Saporita. Facility utilizes apartment complex housing model. The agency currently has Apartments designated for THP+ NMD. There are Non minor dependents (NMD) youth who are currently in placement with the agency. LPA's conducted a tour of the agency. Files are located in locked file cabinets within locked offices. There are no physical plant deficiencies. Staffing: The agency employee's the following assigned staff under the THP program. Program Director , Program Supervisor; Case Manager Supervisor, Four Case managers and one Housing Specialist. All employees have the required experience, and training for their current job employment. At 11: AM, LPA's reviewed 4 staff files and Non minor dependent files. All staff files reviewed were very well organized, Criminal Background and Child Abuse Clearances are complete and current for all employees.The non-minor dependent files were Transitional Independent Living Plan (TILP) and case progress notes are well written, thorough and current. During the inspection, LPA's observed four of 10 client files (C4, C5. C8, C9) did not contain a signed Needs and Service Plan by the authorized representative, non-minor dependent and/or case manager. Based on the record review, the THPP did not ensure the participant needs and service plans were signed by the authorized representative. Therefore, the Facility is cited under the Non-Minor Dependent regulations, section 86168.3 (f) Needs and Service Plan. LPA's received updated participant and certified apartment information. Current Personnel Report (LIC 500) and Designation of Facility Responsibility (LIC 308) all staff current CPR certificates are on file. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report , deficiency with appeal rights was provided to Program Director, Danielle Saporita.

On September 20, 2023, at 10: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Charmaine Linley arrived at the agency for the purpose of conducting an unannounced Required/Annual Licensing Inspection for the agency's Transitional Housing Program (THPP). LPA met and toured the facility with Program Director, Danielle Saporita. The facility is licensed to provide 100 placements for Transitional Housing Placement Program Non-Minor Dependent (THPP-NMD) from ages 18 (18) through twenty-one (21). There are currently (34) participants in the THPP-NMD program which includes nine remote sites throughout Orange County. The Administrative Office consists of a two-story office building, which is convenient to the public. The office is located on the second floor of their corporate establishment. The office consists of a lobby/reception area, and offices for the Program Director, Social Work Supervisor, Case Managers, and Housing Specialists. There is a kitchen area for the staff and an additional conference room. There are working telephones and office equipment, furniture, and supplies located throughout the office space. LPA observed Participant files were stored in a locked cabinet within the Case Manager's office. Staff files were located in the locked Program Director's office. Currently, the facility is staffed with a Program Director, Social Work Supervisor, ten full-time Case Managers, and two full-time Housing specialists. The Program Director was informed that each Social Worker should maintain a 1 to 25 ratio, which should never be exceeded. Licensee is aware of submitting unusual incident reports as needed to the Department to include all Law Enforcement contacts. LPA reviewed five staff records. All staff met the minimum qualifications and training requirements. A review *** of records shows that all staff have FBI, DOJ, and Child Abuse Index Check clearances. LPA also reviewed five THPP-NMD Participant files. All files reviewed were complete and had the required documents. LPA received updated participant and certified apartment information and Current Personnel Report (LIC 500). Based on LPA observations, there are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted with Danielle Saporita and due to printer malfunction, a copy of this report, deficiency was emailed to Program Director, Danielle Saporita.

narrative: On April 14, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) C. White arrived at New Vision Group Homes Inc for the purpose of conducting an Annual Required visit inspection of the Transitional Housing Placement Administrative office. LPA met with Administrator, Administrator - Princess Wesley and CFO, Julia Leonov. LPA was granted access and toured the entire facility. The program is licensed to provide THP+FC services to Non-Minor Dependents up to 6 beds. The current census is 2. This facility is located in a business district, in a small two story office building on the second floor. The office contains the following: Reception area, Waiting area, Office, and Kitchen area. Reception area: upon entering the office to the left of the entry way is a receptionist area equipped with a desk and chair. Waiting area: contains a sofa and coffee table available for clients/visitors. Office: this room doubles as a staffing office and meeting room. The room is equipped with a large conference room table with chairs. There is also a separate desk and chair and the area is intended for private meetings with clients or service providers. The room contains a locked four (4) drawer file cabinet, copier/fax/scanner multi-functional machine, and a storage closet. Kitchen area: is equipped with a small refrigerator, a sink, and cabinet storage. This room also stores supplies for the office. LPA observed one (1) fire extinguisher, one (1) smoke detector, and three (3) fire sprinklers in the ceiling. The smoke detector was tested and found to be in working order. The office building has a shared restroom located to the right of the main office and it requires a key to enter. Report continued on LIC 809C (Page 1 of 2). LPA was unable to review client and staff files as files were not located on the premises. Facility cited on the attached LIC D for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 7 regulation 86087.1(b)(1) ADMINISTRATIVE OFFICES; 86087.1(b)(1) ADMINISTRATIVE OFFICES; and 86023(a)(2) DISASTER AND MASS CASUALTY PLAN. (Page 2 of 2).

narrative: On June 21, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) C. White arrived at New Vision THPP for the purpose of conducting a Plan of Correction (POC) inspection, to verify corrections of the deficiencies that were cited during the Annual/Required inspection dated April 14, 2023. LPA met with Administrator, Princess Wesley regarding Type B deficiency 86087.1(b)(1); Type B deficiency 86087.1(b)(2); and Type B deficiency 86023(a)(2). Upon inspection, LPA observed complete staff and client files stored in the administrative office. Additionally, the Licensee has developed a facility Disaster and Mass Casualty Plan which is maintained in the administrative office. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and POC letter was provided to the Administrator.

On August 10, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) C. White arrived at the above location for the purpose of conducting a Case Management visit. LPA met with Facility Administrator, Princess Wesley. LPA informed the Administrator, the facility's remote THPP site would be inspected on this day, for compliance with Title Regulations. The Administrator provided the following address.. Remote Site: Declan Street Riverside, CA. Administrator, agreed to meet LPA at the site to grant access to the home for inspection. LPA inspected all three units and found each unit to be clean and in good repair. No deficiencies were observed or cited. A copy of this report was left with the Administrator.

On April 14, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) C. White arrived at New Vision Group Homes Inc for the purpose of conducting an Annual Required visit inspection of the Transitional Housing Placement Administrative office. LPA met with Administrator, Administrator - Princess Wesley and CFO, Julia Leonov. LPA was granted access and toured the entire facility. The program is licensed to provide THP+FC services to Non-Minor Dependents up to 6 beds. The current census is 2. This facility is located in a business district, in a small two story office building on the second floor. The office contains the following: Reception area, Waiting area, Office, and Kitchen area. Reception area: containing a desk and chair. Waiting area: containing a sofa and coffee table. Office: containing a large table with chairs; a separate desk and chair and the area is used for private meetings with clients or service providers. The also contains locked file cabinet, copier/fax/scanner machine, and a storage closet. Kitchen area: containing a small refrigerator, sink, and cabinet storage. LPA observed the office to have one (1) fire extinguisher, a smoke detector, and fire sprinklers in the ceiling. The smoke detector was tested and found to be in working order. There are no bodies of water on the premises. There are no firearms or other weapons on the premises. The organization uses single family dwelling model and Licensee ensures the following services: that no more than two participants share a bedroom, and on-site supervisor is available 24/7 days a week to assist, oversee, and support the needs of the participants. Report continued on LIC 809C (Page 1 of 2). The facility ensures that THPP living unit has one functioning carbon monoxide detector that meets the statutory requirements. The facility ensures that THPP living unit has disinfectants and cleaning solutions. That facility ensures that THPP living unit is sanitary and in good repair for the safety and well-being of participants, employees, and visitors. During this visit LPA reviewed a total of three (3) client files, each client file contained copies of important documents including, but not limited to, the following: TILP, and medical records. LPA reviewed a total of three (3) staff files. The following was discussed with staff: Licensee shall not operate a facility beyond the conditions and limitations specified on the license, including the capacity limitation. There were no deficiencies noted on this date. Exit interview was completed and a copy of this report was left at the facility. (Page 2 of 2).

investigation_findings: 13On April 14, 2025 at 1:00pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Justine Armstrong and License Program Manager (LPM) Enrique Hernandez conducted an unannounced visit to NEW VISION THPP Administrator Office to conclude the investigation of the above allegations and deliver the findings. LPA met with Princess Wesley the Administrator and together, they discussed the investigation details. During the investigation process, all relevant parties have been accounted for. It was reported that Due to lack of supervision, non-minor dependents have access to drugs, Staff did not provide a safe living environment, and Non-minor dependents are not being properly supervised by the staff. No deficiencies are being cited at this time. An exit Interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left at the facility. UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

narrative: On May 13, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) J. Armstrong and License Program Analyst (LPA) C. White arrived at New Vision Group Homes Inc for the purpose of conducting an Annual Required visit inspection of the Transitional Housing Placement Administrative office. The program is licensed to provide THP+FC services to Non-Minor Dependents with up to 18 beds. The current census is 7. This facility is situated in a business district on the second floor of an office building. The office includes the following areas: a reception area, waiting area, private office, small storage closet, and kitchen area. In the reception area, there is a desk and chair next to a large window. The waiting area, which is connected to the reception area, features a small sofa and a coffee table. The kitchen area contains a small refrigerator, a sink, cabinet storage, a First Aid Kit, and a fire extinguisher. The private office has a large table with chairs, a separate desk and chair, a fax/scanner machine, and a TV monitor that can be used for conferences and presentations. It displays important documents including the license, emergency disaster plan, client roster, and LIC 500. Additionally, there are locked file cabinets that contains staff and client files. The office also includes a small storage closet, with a landline phone. Safety features within the office consist of one fire extinguisher, one smoke detector, and three fire sprinklers located in the ceiling. The smoke detector has been tested and is in working order.The office building has a shared restroom, located outside to the right of the main office, which requires a key for entry. narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Katherine Deaton conducted an annual inspection at the facility address located above in accordance with COVID-19 precautions. The LPA toured the facility; the facility is clean, safe, and sanitary. The LPA interviewed two staff members. Transitional Housing Placement Provider (THPP) Participants with children residing in their living units ensure disinfectants / poisons are inaccessible. All participant living units have at least one toilet, sink and tub or shower in working order. Participants and their minor children are provided with household essentials. There are no firearms stored in THPP participant living units. The LPA reviewed participant records and found signed copies of personal rights and all school records, immunization records, and medical records that were provided. narrative: Continued from LPA made four attempts to interview another Transitional Housing client. Client would not participate in an interview, but texted one sentence saying they had no concerns about their placement. Law enforcement contact records indicate police were called to a Transitional housing, minor dependent, mentor home twice on 7/5/21 and 10/10/21 due to unknown persons breaking into the backyard and banging on the windows. Suspects had fled before police arrived. Interviews and record review were inconsistent regarding whether the mentor was home at the time of the break-ins in the backyard. Interviews indicate the mentor home is located in a high crime area, near a park where individuals are often seen using drugs. A youth and mentor corroborated an additional break-in of a transient individual entering the home and demanding water, but police were not called, as the individual left the home without conflict. Based on interviews and record reviews, although the allegation may have happened, or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the violations did, or did not, occur. Therefore, the allegation the Facility does not provide a safe environment for foster youth is UNSUBSTANTIATED. Facility mentors are not required to be present in the home at all times, but to maintain adequate supervision to protect the clients. Mentors and youth acted appropriately by reporting the break-ins to law enforcement and the agency. Exit interview was conducted. A signed copy of this LIC-9099 and LIC-9099C were provided to the facility.

narrative: On 06/17/ Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Hillary Hall met with Christina Sierra, Human Resources Manager, for the purpose of completing the Required Annual Inspection of the facility. LPA initiated the Annual Inspection on 6/16/22. LPA utilized the CARES Tool to complete the inspection. The facility has 52 clients, both minors and Non-Minor Dependents. The facility employs Social Workers and Case Managers, plus a Program Manager. LPA reviewed two staff files. Staff were current on CPR and First Aid had required education and training. LPA interviewed two staff on site. LPA reviewed 10 client files on 6/16/22. See LIC-809 from 6/16/22 for details. One citation is being issue per Title Section 86175(b): Health Related Services: The THPP participant's physician has stated, in writing, that the THPP participant is able to determine and administer his/her own prescription or nonprescription PRN medication. Of 3 minor client files reviewed, there was no documentation that the physician had authorized for the minor client to administer their own medication. Program Manager reported a conversation was had with the placing agency to get approval for the minor client to administer their medication before admittance into the program. Program Manager agreed to have the physician be aware of the client's placement in the program and determine the minor clients ability to administer their medications going forward. A signed copy of this LIC-809 and LIC-809D report were emailed to the Office Manager. An exit interview was conducted and appeal rights were offered.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lyta Vue arrived unannounced at the facility on this date for the purpose of a case management. LPA met with Kari Barron, Program Manager. LPA Vue conducted the case management. On May 12, 2023, the facility administrator, Eve Nash, notified the Department via phone that on April 30, 2023, a minor client left the home without permission. The facility failed to notify the Department or submit a Serious Incident Report (SIR) indicating the client was missing, until May 12, 2023, which is a violation of Interim Licensing Standards Reporting Requirements. The administrator admitted the error was an oversight. The Facility is issued a citation per Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Section 86161 (b)(1)(D) Reporting Requirements: (b) Upon the occurrence, during the operation of the facility, of any of the events specified in (1) below, a report shall be made to the licensing agency within the agency's next working day during its normal business hours. In addition, a written report containing the information specified in (2) below shall be submitted to the licensing agency within seven days following the occurrence of such event. (1) Events reported shall include the following: (D) Any unusual incident or participant absence which threatens the physical or emotional health or safety of any participant. Exit Interview conducted and Appeal rights provided to Kari Barron, Program Manager. A signed copy of this LIC-809 and LIC 809D were provided to the facility.

narrative: On 07/05/2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Wendy Brown arrived unannounced at the facility and met with Kari Barron, Program Manager. The purpose of the visit was to conduct a Required Annual Inspection of the facility. The last Annual inspection for the facility was on 06/16/2022. LPA utilized the CARE Tool to complete the Annual inspection. LPA conducted an inspection of the physical plant, and checked for all necessary requirements. The facility was clean and organized, and maintained at acceptable room temperature. The facility has thirteen offices for staff (four are unoccupied, five visit rooms, one conference room, a kitchen, one small meeting room, and five confidential interview/visitation rooms. LPA observed the proper postings including: facility license, complaint hotline, and emergency disaster plan. The restrooms for clients and staff were clean. Smoke alarms were in working order, fire extinguishers were current, and a first aid kit was fully stocked. Evacuation drills for the facility were completed monthly. LPA observed client files were stored electronically with password protection. The facility has no outstanding fees. The facility has THPP and Non-Minor Dependent clients. Clients live in either mentor homes or remote site apartments. No client resides more than two hours from the facility. The facility employees three social worker(s) with a fourth starting next week, two case manager, and a program manager. LPA reviewed five personnel files. Social work personnel had completed criminal record clearances and met minimum education and experience qualifications. All First Aid and CPR certifications were up to date for social work personnel. LPA interviewed all three social worker personnel on staff. Social work personnel indicated they did not have more than 12 clients on their caseload. LPA reviewed five client files. All clients had signed Admission Agreements. Client files had current Needs and Service Plans, signed. Needs and Services Plans detailed adequate supportive services the facility offers to the clients. CHDP physical and dental were current in the minor file reviewed and there was no need for a JV220. No citations were given on this date. A signed copy of this LIC-809 and LIC-809C and was provided to Kari Barron Program Manager. An exit interview was conducted.

facility_name: NO CA YOUTH & FAMILY PROGRAMS THPP/THP+FC
narrative: Support Visit logs. Records and interviews were consistent that placement homes are known to be without mentors present for days. Clients were absent from care for extended periods of time while unsupervised by mentors or case workers. Facility policy indicates case workers will stop by the homes when the mentors are absent but there was no record of regular visits to the homes while the mentors were away. Records and interviews indicated the facility did not provide supportive services to ensure transportation to school for one client. The client was in care for over two months and only attended school for one-half day. Truancy was reported to be a result of the client not securing transportation. Records reviewed and interviews conducted demonstrate the facility did not ensure a client's medical needs were met. One client had been prescribed treatment to occur once or twice a week. Interviews and records review demonstrate that this medical care was not facilitated by staff despite being a facility policy. Based on LPA's observations, interviews, and records review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be SUBSTANTIATED. One citation is issued per Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 6 section 80078(a): Responsibility for Care and Supervision due to the clients being unsupervised and the transportation to school not being secured. One citation is issued per Interim Licensing Standards Section 86175(a): Health Related Services as the client's medical needs were not met. A signed copy of this LIC-9099 report, the LIC-9099C, and LIC-9099D were provided to the facility. An exit interview was conducted, and appeal rights were provided.

The Case Management is in regard to an Unusual Incident/Injury Report (LIC624) for an incident on 03/08/2024 wherein a THPP NMD cut themselves with a razor. Volunteer staff helped the Participant clean the wound, but did not report the incident until three days later. The Facility instructs volunteers on reporting requirements before volunteering, annually, and revisited it with this volunteer after the incident. The facility recently completed a Plan of Correction wherein staff were trained on the Facility Absence Agreement and it included reporting requirements. Volunteers are undergoing training, with one more week before completion. LPA reviewed and collected records at the facility and interviewed one individual. Records indicated the Agency Social Worker (ASW) was making regular contact with the participant with recent contacts made on October 19, 23 and 24. A current Needs and Services Plan was on file dated 10/08/2024. Law Enforcement is still investigating the shooting that happened at a Halloween party that started on 10/26/2024. facility_name: NO CA YOUTH & FAMILY PROGRAMS THPP/THP+FC
narrative: On June 3, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Wendy Brown arrived unannounced at the facility and met with Kari Barron, Program Manager. The purpose of the visit was to conduct a Required Biennial Inspection of the facility. The last inspection for the facility was on 07/05/2023. The file was reviewed prior to conducting the inspection and the LIC 9237 completed. LPA utilized the CARE Tool to complete the inspection. LPA conducted an inspection of the physical plant and checked for all necessary requirements. The facility was clean and organized and maintained an acceptable room temperature. The facility has thirteen offices for staff, five visit rooms, one conference room, a kitchen, one small meeting room, and five confidential interview/visitation rooms. LPA observed the proper postings including: facility license, complaint hotline, CARF accreditation, personal rights, and emergency disaster plan. The restrooms for clients and staff were clean. Smoke alarms were in working order, fire extinguishers were current, and a first aid kit was fully stocked. Evacuation drills for the facility are completed monthly. LPA observed client files were stored electronically with password protection. The facility has no outstanding fees. The facility has Non-Minor Dependent clients. Clients live in remote site apartments or one designated THP house. No client resides more than two hours from the facility. The facility employs five Social Worker(s) and two Case Managers, and two Program Managers. LPA reviewed five Social Worker personnel files. Social work personnel had completed criminal record clearances and met minimum education and experience qualifications. All First Aid and CPR certifications were up to date for Social Worker personnel. LPA interviewed two social worker personnel and one Program Manager. Social work personnel indicated they did not have more than 12 clients on their caseload. LPA reviewed five client files. Client files had current Needs and Service Plans, signed by the client and placing agency. Needs and Services Plans detailed adequate supportive services the facility offers to the clients. No citations were given on this date. A signed copy of this LIC-809 and LIC-809C report was provided to facility staff. An exit interview was conducted.

Fire extinguishers are current, there are fire sprinklers, smoke detectors, and carbon monoxide detectors located in each office. facility_name: NORTH COUNTY LIFELINE,INC:DBA LIFELINE COMM SERV
narrative: On January 24, 2025, at 9: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jacob Salem arrived at the facility for a post-licensing inspection. LPA met with Melissa Haupt, Director of Programs and toured the facility. The office consists of a multiple buildings on the property and across the street, including a public reception area which contains the posted license and LIC 610C. The LIC 610C contains all of the required information. Other program buildings consist of a staff office building, which contains the confidential clients files, a human resources building containing the staff files, and a walk-in residential home office for current and prospective clients, which includes telephone service for client use. All office and residential units contain rooms for confidential interviews, and all units accessible to clients that were inspected are well maintained and no health or safety hazards were identified. Client living units are located across the street in two public apartment buildings. LPA reviewed two client files (C1 and C2), which contained required demographic information and signed program policies. LPA observed that a separate file was absent for two of four clients served by the program (C3 and C4). LPA observed the following records absent from the client files reviewed: Needs and Services Plans/Transitional Independent Living Plans and pre-admission health assessments. LPA reviews five staff files, which contained the required demographic, educational, and professional information. LPA observed that staff training records for five staff (S1-S5) were absent from staff files. LPA conducted two staff interviews. Based on records reviewed, the facility is being issued a citations for violations observed during the inspection (see LIC 809D). An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and appeal rights, and LIC Confidential name list were given to Melissa Haupt, Director of Programs.

On April 1, 2021, at 09: AM Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Anastasia Flores was greeted and granted access to facility by Chief Executive Officer, Tammy Wilson. LPA was greeted by Program Director, Tammy Nelson, Director of Community Based Programs, Misty Kerrigan and Sanctuary of Palm Springs Executive Director, Rob Woronoff. The purpose of the visit is to conduct a pre-licensing inspection of the facility Oak Grove Sanctuary Palm Springs which was previously licensed as Sanctuary of Palm Springs. At 09: AM, LPA began tour of the facility with Tammy Wilson and Tammy Nelson for a pre-license of a Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) for Non-Minor Dependents. The office resides on premises with a locked door. The office consists of a small couch two workspaces utilized by staff. In the office are two locked filing cabinets for staff files and resident files. There is a master bedroom that is left empty for case managers to utilize if necessary but is kept open in case a COVID positive were to occur for isolation. LPAs observed computers and phones in the offices. The facility has six bedrooms with locking doors and the residents each have their own key, there is a master key if necessary held in the main office. The common areas for residents are the kitchen, two sitting areas with computers, living room with ample sitting space, television and games. There is ample parking for residents and staff. The laundry area had a washer and dryer. The facility has ample storage space in the garage. The windows had curtains for privacy. There is a small gym with age appropriate equipment with air conditioning available that is utilized by the residents. There is a pool located in the backyard with access by three different doors. There is a large area that was previously utilized as a garden. The exits in the backyard are free of debris and accessible to all residents. The bedrooms are all furnished with full size beds, dressers, closets and clean linens. Individual beds in good repair, equipped with good springs, clean mattresses and pillows observed. () The residents are given daily chore assignments and offered incentives to assist with the independent living activities. Residents are allowed to create a list for specified groceries and go shopping on Friday's with Program Director. The following were discussed: LPA advised that this pre-licensing report and application will be reviewed by the Department. The facility will be notified once they are provisionally licensed as a THPP/NMD facility. License will expire one year from effective date. Facility will be licensed for a capacity of 6 clients. Facility accepts only ambulatory clients. It was discussed the possibility of expansion for the facility license in the future as stated in the program statement. . An exit interview was conducted with facility representatives.

The facility Executive Director and the Case Manager (CM) denied the allegations as presented. The CM disclosed that C1 made a threat to client #2 (C2) and as a result terminated the agreement for C1 to continue with the program at Olive Crest. C1 was given a date and time to vacate the premises. Furthermore, it was reported that the a.c -heating unit and WIFI was turned off intentionally however those allegations are being denied by Olive Crest. CM disclosed that C1 reported the ac-heat was not working. CM disclosed that a work order was submitted to the apartment complex maintenance for repair. Service was restored that same day. CM disclosed that WIFI service was never disconnected intentionally, however it was discovered that billing statements were being sent directly to the apartment unit's address instead of Olive Crest's address for payment. The Case Manager and Executive Director at Olive Crest denied that the client was treated unfairly. In confidential interviews, LPA Vargas was provided with inconsistent statements by C1. The client denied threatening her roommate (C2) and never agreed to vacate the unit where she resided. C1 disclosed that her roommate (C2) will corroborate her statement and deny the allegation of being threatened. Furthermore it was reported that the WIFI service was turned off intentionally but has acknowledge that billing statements for the WIFI service were being delivered to her apartment without forwarding the statements to Olive Crest for their review. The client disclosed that after reporting no WIFI service, the facility had service restored within the same day. C1 reported that the ac-heat in the apartment was intentionally turn off, however admits to not knowing how to operate the ac-heat unit and was instructed by the building maintenance worker how to turn on the unit. The other client who was allegedly threatened could not be contacted and therefore no statement was obtained. Individual other who was identified as having information to the alleged allegations could not be contacted and as a result, no statement was obtained. The assigned county social worker (CSW) to C1 stated that the client did attend a meeting where it was disclosed that she would be vacating her residence by a certain date and time. It should be mentioned that Olive Crest continued to allow the client to reside at the apartment and was not removed from their program. The interviews revealed inconsistencies in the explanations obtained during this investigation. Therefore, the above allegations are determined inconclusive at this time. A finding that the complaint is inconclusive means that although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged abuse occurred. An exit interview was conducted and copy of this report was email electronically to the above facility or review and signature. No deficiencies were cited at this time.

narrative: On 7/19/2021 at 12:00 pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jenny Mundo conducted an unannounced Case Management inspection at the Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) Olive Crest and met with Joey Collinsworth, the facility's Program Director and Annamarie Dachtler, the facility's Executive Director. The purpose of the inspection was to follow up on an "Inappropriate Sexual Behavior and Staff Related" Special Incident Report (SIR) that was submitted by the THPP on 5/12/2021. S1 (see confidential names form LIC 811 dated 7/19/2021) was made aware by a program participant hearing from another program participant that S1 was dating and engaging in sexual intercourse with NMD1. LPA Mundo interviewed S2 and S3 at 12:30 pm. The following was revealed: S2 and S3 stated that an internal investigation was conducted. NMD1 and S1 denied dating each other and being involved in a sexual relationship. S2 and S3 stated that S1 was following up on a noise complaint (sexual noises) coming from NMD1's apartment. S1 walked in on NMD1 and NMD2 having sexual intercourse. NMD2 told NMD3 that S1's look on her face was that of a girlfriend who walked-in on her boyfriend having sex with another female. NMD2 refused to be interviewed by S2. S2 stated that NMD1 was already transitioning out of the THPP (for an unrelated issue) and was discharged on 5/26/2021, and S1 resigned on 7/2/2021 due to medical reasons. Based on the interviews conducted by LPA Mundo, there is no evidence of violations of the California Code of Regulations. No deficiencies were cited during today's inspection. A copy of the LIC 809 and LIC 811 were provided to the facility representative and an exit interview was conducted.

The SSW indicated the THPP conducts monthly inspections of the apartments and there were some maintenance issues with the apartment that are being address. The CM indicated CM observed maintenance issues with the apartment and submitted work request to the property maintenance team to correct the issues. The confidential interviews conducted indicated the NMDs stated the apartment was missing blinds, had holes in walls, pieces of wood on doors and was not clean. LPA during the tour of the apartment observed the apartment had several maintenance issues, however SSW indicated work orders have been placed to correct the issues. LPA took pictures of what LPA observed. The CSW indicated when CSW was going to move NMD into the apartment, however it was not move in ready and NMD had to go to a hotel until the maintenance issues were taken care of. Although LPA observed some maintenance issues with the apartment, the SSW indicated work orders were placed for those issues to be corrected. SSW provided LPA pictures of the maintenance corrections once they were completed. Based on the interviews, observations and records reviewed the allegations is/are found unsubstantiated. narrative: On June 5, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Claudia Portillo conducted an unannounced follow up case management inspection at the agency above and spoke with the representative above regarding a special incident report (SIR) that was submitted to Community Care Licensing (CCL) on April 15, 2023. The SIR disclosed that the Non-Minor Dependent (NMD) indicated she fell slightly when moving a changing table, but Manager and Program director reported severe damage was caused to the bathroom door, door frame and surrounding wall. Damaged done does not appear to be from slight fall. LPA Portillo interviewed the Director who indicated that a Child Family Team meeting (CFT) was conducted to discuss the concerns and a safety plan that was for the NMD. The NMD denied domestic violence towards her and denied therapy. NMD has a child who lives with her part-time (shared custody). The Director indicated that a visual wellness check was conducted for both NMD and child and there were no observations of injuries. Based on information received from Director, a work order was initiated to repair the damages in the apartment (pending). The Director stated support and guidance has been provided for NMD. The SIR will be updated to reflect the follow-up that was provided by the agency. There are no violations of Title 22, of the California Code of Regulations. No deficiencies were cited during today's inspection. A copy of LIC 809 and LIC 811 was provided to the facility representative above and an exit interview was conducted.

This is a 2-story building and will share the 2nd floor with Olive Crest -Foster Family Agency (FFA). On the 2nd floor there is sufficient staff and social worker space that consist of hotel station cubical set up, a conference room, (which can also be used for confidential meetings), staff kitchen/break room, and a file storage room with a lock on the door for confidential files. An exit interview was conducted and a signed copy of this report, LIC 9102 and LIC 811 was provided to the Program Administrator and Program Director.

An unannounced case management inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Angelina Garibaldo. During the inspection LPA Garibaldo met with Director, Jessica Appel. The purpose of the case management was to follow up on Special Incident Report (SIR) 1361172 the Department received on 7/21/25. SIR stated that Client 2 (C2) found Client 1 (C1) in the bathtub with deep self-inflicted cuts and immediately called 911. SIR also stated that that the night prior (7/18), C1 had three unknown male guests in the unit past visiting hours, making her C2 feel uncomfortable, and as a result, C2 invited own guests to stay the night. (see confidential names form LIC 811 dated 07/24/25). LPA discussed with the Director the facility visitation rules and procedures, corrective action procedures, safety plan, mental health services and use of ring door cameras. An exit interview was conducted. No deficiencies were cited. A copy of this report and LIC 811 were provided to the facility representative.

On March 8, 2023 at 11:06am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Adrian Mendez arrived unannounced at the facility to conduct an Annual inspection of the facility. The facility was inspected with Director of Transitional Housing Programs Tisha Roberts. The Transitional Housing Program office is located in a business establishment. The office consists of a lobby/reception area, cubicles, and staff offices. The restroom is located on the same floor of the office of the building establishment. All children's files are maintained and stored in locked cabinets in the staff cubicles. Staff files are also maintained in a locked cabinet in the Human Resources office. There are working telephones and office equipment, furniture, and supplies located throughout the office space. LPA reviewed five staff files and all staff have met training and qualification requirements per regulation requirements. All staff associated to facility have met Department of Justice, FBI and Child Abuse Index Check requirements. A sample of five client files were reviewed during the inspection. All client files had the required documents per regulations. Currently the facility has 48 placements and four remote site apartments. The remote apartments are all within two hours of the administrative office. LPA discussed and reviewed the following inspection components; Operational Requirements, and Emergency Disaster Preparedness. Based on the facility inspection, and files reviewed, there are no deficiencies found at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was explained to Director of Transitional Housing Programs Tisha Roberts. Due to printer malfunction this report will be emailed to Director of Transitional Housing Programs Tisha Roberts.

On 05/07/25, at 9: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Gilbert Marquez met with Tisha Roberts, Administrator for the purpose of conducting an annual inspection. The facility is licensed to provide 100 placements for Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) for foster youths ages 16 through 18, and a Transitional Housing Placement plus Foster Care (THP+FC) for Non-Minor Dependents (NMD) ages 18 through 21. There are currently 53 participants residing in the THPP/NMD programs, which included four remote sites throughout Orange County. The Fire Drill log was up to date and in compliance. All client files are stored and maintained in binders and on a secure internet portal called "Oliver." Binders are locked in the Program Director's Office. LPA reviewed five client files (C1 - C5, see Confidential Names List, LIC811) to ensure clients had all required documents per Title 22 regulations. Client files had education records, physical examinations, Needs and Services plans, and case manager notes. All staff records are maintained in file folders and locked in the Human Resources Office. LPA reviewed five staff files (S1 - S5) to ensure staff had all required documents per Title 22 regulations. Per a review of Guardian, all staff have a criminal record clearance. All staff files also had applications, job descriptions, resumes, physical health screenings, drivers licenses, and training certificates. LPA conducted three staff interviews (S2, S3, S5). **Continued on LIC809C** **continued from LIC809** Per Interim Licensing Standards, AB Non Minor Dependents, THPP, Article Needs and Services Plan Section (d) The Needs and Services Plan shall be signed by the nonminor dependent, the THPP administrator or social work personnel, and the person or agency responsible for placing the nonminor dependent...and maintained in the records for the nonminor dependent... This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on observation, interview, and client file review, two of two NMD client files(C4 and C5) did not have any space for the NMD to sign their NSP, which poses a personal rights risk to persons in care. Therefore, a Type B violation is being given. An exit interview was conducted, a plan of correction was made, appeal rights were explained, and a copy of this report, deficiency statement LIC809D, appeal rights, and LIC811 was provided to Tisha Roberts. A copy of this report will be placed in the facility file.

Regarding the allegation that staff did not prevent minors from consuming alcohol while in care, confidential interviews confirmed that on 12/02/ C1-C4 were hanging out at the jacuzzi and were observed to be under the influence. Interviews revealed that S1 was called by the apartment management regarding the minors be at the jacuzzi after hours, when S1 arrived at the jacuzzi, the clients were observed to be "tipsy." S1 told the clients to go to their apartments without checking for alcohol. In addition, interviews further revealed that minors then went to C2 and C3's apartment and continued to consume alcohol. Interviews also confirmed that minors were observed to be more intoxicated at the apartment, and the apartment was not checked for alcohol. Regarding the allegation that staff did not properly report an incident involving a minor, confidential interviews and documents reviewed confirmed that incidents involving minors were not being reported to CCL. Based on confidential interviews and records reviewed, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met and the allegations that staff did not prevent the minors from consuming alcohol while in care and that staff did not properly report an incident involving a minor are substantiated. The facility is being cited for violation of Title 22, Division Chapter Subchapter 1. Transitional Housing Placement Program for Minor Foster Children Section 86178(b) and Title General Licensing Requirements, Division 6, Chapter Subchapter 1,Transitional Housing Placement Program for Minor Foster Children Section Reporting Requirements. An exit interview was conducted with Tina Chang and appeal rights were explained. A copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to the Administrator and a copy will be placed in the facility file. hanging out in C2 and C3's apartment. While hanging out minors were consuming alcohol and at some point, began engaging in sexualized behavior. Confidential interviews further revealed that a video was taken of C2 and C3 engaged in sexualized behavior. The program staff declined to see the video. Clients interviewed confirmed that the video was taken. Confidential interviews did not provide LPA the opportunity to view the video, interviews revealed that it had been deleted and original source was not revealed. Confidential interviews also revealed conflicting statements regarding whether the sexual interactions were consensual due to minor being intoxicated. Based on confidential interviews and records reviewed, that staff did not prevent inappropriate sexual interactions between the minors may have occurred, however, is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained. A copy of this report and appeal rights was provided to the Administrator.

On 02/07/25, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received allegations that staff did not prevent the minors from consuming alcohol while in care and that staff did not properly report an incident involving a minor. ****CONTINUED ON 9099C**** SubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

On May 19, 2022 at 08: AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA's), Darlene Almaraz-Oseguera and Toni Castillo met with Program Manager Darlene Logan who granted access to the facility. The purpose of this inspection was to conduct an required two year annual inspection for the Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) for Non-Minor Dependents. The Administrative Office is located at Technology Ct., Ste 300, Riverside CA 92507. The office is located in the main offices of the Olive Crest business establishment. Presently, the THPP is licensed to provide care for ages eighteen (18) through twenty-one (21). There are currently 37 participants utilizing the program. The participants reside in several remote sites throughout Riverside County (Riverside, Coachella, Indio, Palm Desert and Moreno Valley). The THPP Administrative office is located in Riverside, CA. The office is located on the first floor of a retail business establishment. The office consists of a lobby/reception area, a quiet room for the participants, furnished with chairs, tables, and a computer. Cubicles/offices for the Program Directors, Independent Living Coaches and Case Managers. There is a kitchen area for the staff, and an additional conference room. There are working telephones and office equipment, furniture, and supplies located throughout the office space. LPA observed Participant files were stored in secured cabinets and are in a locked storage area. Staff files are kept in a locked file cabinet in the HR office in the adjacent building . Currently the facility is staffed with two Independent Living Coaches/ Peer Specialist and two Case Managers. A review of the facility file indicated that the facility is current with the Annual Fees. The Program Director was informed that each ILS coach should maintain a 1 to 12 ratio, which should never be exceeded. Licensee is aware of submitting unusual incident reports as needed to the Department to include all Law Enforcement contact. () LPA's reviewed four staff records. All staff met the minimum qualifications and training requirements. A review of records shows that all staff have FBI, DOJ and Child Abuse Index Check clearances. LPA's reviewed eight non minor dependent files. During client file review, LPA's observed C7 missing client and authorized representative signatures on the Needs and Service Plan, C3 file was missing the needs and service plan. Facility did not provide or have a copy of the drill log of the emergency disaster and mass casualty plan. , the facility is cited under the Non-Minor Dependent regulations, section 86268.3 (a) Needs and Service and section 1565(c) Plan and Disaster Preparedness. Exit interview was conducted with Darlene Logan, a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to the facility representative.

deficiencies.title:
Participant Medical Assessments

(a) Prior to or within 30 calendar days following the acceptance of a participant, the licensee shall obtain a written medical assessment of the participant, as specified in Section 80069(b), which enables the licensee to determine their ability to provide necessary health related services to the participant. The assessment shall be used in developing the Needs and Services Plan.

This requirement is not met as evidenced by

narrative: However, per the shared living agreement R1 signed, while visits are unannounced, staff are to knock before entering. The agreement states on page 2, "Privacy: Staff will always knock and wait a few seconds prior to opening a closed door... Pop-Ups: For everyone's safety, we will pop-up at the apartment for unannounced visits. We will knock and then use our key before entry." R1 had not previously met S1 and had no way of knowing S1 was program staff until S1 began pushing open the door. R1 reported feeling afraid for R1's safety. Further, the program did not protect the youth's personal rights and did not accord the youth dignity and respect by not abiding by the agreement they signed with the youth. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and therefore the above allegations are found to be Substantiated. The facility is being cited per California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section Personal Rights. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report left with Program Supervisor Faith Jackson, who agreed to sign the report emailed by LPA Hawkins and return a signed copy to LPA.
investigation_findings: 13On Thursday 11/05/20 at 3PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a visit to deliver findings of a complaint investigation of the above allegation. LPA met with Program Supervisor Faith Jackson. Due to COVID-19 social distancing orders, this visit was scheduled as a tele-visit. During the investigation, LPA Hawkins conducted confidential interviews with program staff and the victim, resident R1 (See LIC Confidential Names). Based on interviews and record review, staff S1 (See LIC 811) entered R1's apartment unit unannounced without knocking and announcing self. A second incident was reported as well. On 9/3/20, per Program Supervisor, S1 was officially reassigned to another youth, so S1 would have no reason to go back to that unit. S2 (See LIC 811) confirmed that S1 knew there was a possibility of a resident being in the unit, as S1 texted S2 about this prior to making the visit. S2 also confirmed that staff make unannounced visits. SubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

LPA collected relevant participant records, including program social worker information, incident details shared with the program thus far, needs and services plans, and service notes. On 10/19/ Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alarcon conducted an announced tele-inspection via FaceTime. The purpose of the inspection was to conduct a Pre-licensing for the relocation of the Foster Family Agency (FFA). The FFA's Executive Director Tony Yadon provided a virtual tour of the facility. The FFA is in a multi-story commercial building. There is street parking located around the property. The facility has its own suite located on the third floor of the building. Upon entry to the suite there are personal rights posters, facility sketch with emergency exits displayed, and a fire extinguisher. The facility has a separate Administrative suite for HR records on personnel, financials, and other necessary records which are kept within a locked room. There are smoke detectors and a sprinkler system located throughout the facility. The second floor of the building has an operational coffee shop ran and operated by the facility to provide youth of age professional work experience. The coffee shop is open to the public Monday through Friday. The restrooms are controlled access by electronic keypads. There is a janitorial service who maintains the building, so cleaning supplies are securely locked within the janitorial closet in the basement. There are first aid kits located in the building management office, janitorial room, and each suite. The THPP has a waiting area, fire exit plan, fire extinguisher, smoke detector, and personal rights upon entry. There are two private office for the THP staff. Within the suite there is a training room which could be used as a meeting room for THP staff and youth to have private meetings. Prior to today's visit, the application for the relocation was received and reviewed by the Regional Office. LPA Alarcon did not observe any deficiencies in regard to Physical Plant during today's inspection. An exit interview was conducted, copy of report emailed to the Executive Director for signature.

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Marla Horne spoke with Tony Yadon, Executive Director on 4-1-21 at 1:06 p.m. to deliver the finding of the above allegation. During this investigation a virtual inspection of the facility was conducted on 12-17-20. Some copies of documents obtained include a transitional independent living plan for the youth, participant contract and case notes. Interviews were conducted on the following dates: the reporting party on 12-16-20; the youth on 12-28-20; the youth's guardian on 12-29-20; the county social worker on 3-4-21. Staff 1,2,3 and 4 were interviewed on 3-24-21. It was alleged that staff do not treat participants with respect. FY1 (see LIC Confidential Names List, dated 12-17-20) was a participant in the transitional housing program and had received three violations. A meeting was held via ZOOM to discuss the violations an inform FY1 that termination from the program would happen if violations of the policies continued. FY1's guardian, cousin and county social worker also attended the meeting. According to statements made during interviews, there were accusations from the transitional housing staff and FY1's family. S2 stated she felt attacked by FY1's guardian and cousin. According to a statement made one of the transitional housing staff was unprofessional during the meeting and asked to be excused from the meeting. Staff 1-4 stated they were never unprofessional or disrespectful to FY1. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, appeal rights and the LIC811 were sent via email to Tony Yadon on 4-1-21. UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:
allegations: UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion: Unsubstantiated Estimated Days of Completion: Unsubstantiated Estimated Days of Completion:

narrative: On October 19, 2021 at 12: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stephannie Verna arrived at the above facility for the purpose of completing an unannounced required Annual Inspection. LPA Verna met with Debbie Magistrado, Program Administrator. Parents by Choice is a Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) that supports Non-Minor Dependents (NMD) in creating and achieving independent living goals, and fostering independence. LPA Verna completed an inspection of the physical plant, the Administrative office and THPP office. LPA observed the facility sketch and facility license was posted in a prominent place in the the Administration office. LPA completed the staff file review and reviewed five staff files. The staff files contained the required documentation, with the exception of: one out of five staff files did not contain record of a health screening, two out of five staff files did not contain current Mandated Reporter training, two out of five staff did not have a completed criminal record transfer request and are not associated to the facility license, and four out of five staff files did not contain criminal record clearance documents. The facility was unable to confirm if the one staff completed a health screening at the time of hire. The facility reported they are working to get all staff up-to-date on the training requirements. The facility was unsure as to why two out of five staff were not associated to the correct facility license. Continued on 809-c LPA Verna began the review of a total of 10 client files. From files and documents reviewed on today's date, it was observed that the client files contained the required documents with the exception of some client files missing the Transitional Independent Living Plan (TILP) from the placing counties. This was the case for five out of 10 client files. Additionally, some client files contained the TILPs, but from the year 2020. This was the case in one out of 10 client files. The facility staff stated that they have requested the TILPs from the placing counties, but they do not always receive them at placement or when requested. The facility stated that the placing counties do not complete TILPs for NMD over the age of 21, as they are not required. Of the 5 client files missing the TILP, two out of NMD are over the age of 21. The facility stated they will continue to request the TILPs from placement counties if not provided by the placing counties. Staff Interviews were not complete and will be completed on another date. LPA Verna is to completed the annual inspection on another date. The facility is being cited for deficiencies of the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, section 80019(e)(2), which poses an immediate health, safety or personal rights risk to persons in care. See 809-D for citation and Plan of Correction (POC) information. The facility is being assessed for a civil penalty assessment of $100 per day for a maximum of five days, and total of $1,000, see LIC421BG. An exit interview was completed with Tony Yadon, Agency Administrator. A copy of this report and appeal rights were discussed and was provided to Tony Yadon, Agency Administrator.

On October 21, 2021 at 1: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stephannie Verna arrived at the above facility for the purpose of finishing an unannounced required Annual Inspection. LPA Verna met with Tony Yadon, Agency Administrator. LPA Verna completed a review of facility's plan of operations and emergency and disaster preparedness plan, and found the agency to be in compliance with the required regulations pertaining to these areas. LPA Verna completed the review of a total of 10 client files. From files and documents reviewed, it was observed that the client files contained the required documents with the exception of 10 out of 10 client files were missing the Needs and Services Plans for Non Minor Dependents (NMDs), and 10 out of 10 client files were missing a Health Assessment and TB test results documentation. The facility stated they do not have a plan in place to have NMDs complete a Health Assessment or obtain a TB test, and results, at the time of enrollment into the program, or within 30 days of enrollment into the program. The facility stated that at this time, the staff complete Monthly Goal with the NMDs but do not complete Needs and Services Plans, specifically. The facility stated they would easily be able to implement the process for completing Needs and Services Plans with the NMDs. Continued on 809-c A total of four staff interviews were completed. LPA Verna completed the annual inspection on today's date. The facility is being cited for deficiencies of the Interim Licensing Standards AB Nonminor Dependents, THPP, article 6, section 86168.3(c) which poses a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to persons in care; and the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, section 80069(a), which poses a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to persons in care. See 809-D for citation and Plan of Correction (POC) information. An exit interview was completed with Tony Yadon, Agency Administrator. A copy of this report and appeal rights were discussed and was provided to Tony Yadon, Agency Administrator.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Stidman, conducted an unannounced inspection to the agency on 02/10/23 for the purpose of a case management inspection. LPA met with Elisa Corral Office Manager and discussed during a complaint investigation it was discovered staff conducted an unreasonable search of the apartment of a Non-Minor dependent client on 6/24/22. Based upon staff interviewed, staff stated they observed a car parked in the clients parking spot that did not belong to the clients. Then the staff immediately conducted a 'pop-up'/unannounced search of the apartment. This search did not constitute an "imminent concern about someone's safety" as stated in the facility's Plan of Operation dated May 2016. The facility is cited for violation of a client's personal rights to be free from unreasonable searches of personal belongings as per Interim Licensing Standards AB Nonminor Dependents, THPP Article 06. Continuing Requirements Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report and a copy of the appeal rights were left at the facility with Elisa Corral Office Manager.

dated May 2016 included a letter titled "THP+FC Revisions/Responses:" dated 3/24/17 which states "There isn't a guest Agreement per se, as this is covered by the 'Admission Agreement'" and "Monthly stipends will not be affected by disciplinary measures, so there won't be fines, per se." Based upon records reviewed the Placement Agency Admission Agreement does not contain any information on guests. The facility failed to abide by their Plan of Operation. Facility is cited Interim Licensing Standards AB Nonminor Dependents, THPP, Article 03. Application Procedures, Regulation 86222(a)(2) PLAN OF OPERATION Section 86222, Plan of Operation shall apply to nonminor dependents, including the following: A description of programs or services to be provided by the THPP consistent with assisting a nonminor dependent in preparing for emancipation from foster care. Based on LPA's interviews which were conducted the facility staff engage in inappropriate interactions with clients in care. Staff S3 has at least on two occasions brought a non-staff person to the apartment complex of a Non-Minor dependent. Therefore, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be substantiated. California Code of Regulations, Interim Licensing Standards AB Nonminor Dependents, THPP Article 06. Continuing Requirements 86272(a)(11) Personal Rights. The licensee shall ensure that each nonminor dependent is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code section 16001.9 and the following personal right to have dignity in their personal relationships with others in the THPP. The facility is cited on the attached LIC 9099D. A copy of this report was left with Elisa Corral Office Manager and appeal rights were given.

narrative: On October 27,2023 at 10:00AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Donna Edwards arrived at the above facility for the purpose of completing an unannounced required Annual Inspection. LPA Edwards me with Shawn Nunn, Supervisor. Parents by Choice is a Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) that supports Non-Minor Dependents (NMD) with achieving independent living goals and fostering independence. The THPP office consists of two couches, two chairs, three tables and a locked cabinet for training manuals and keys. LPA Edwards completed a tour of the THPP office and observed the business license, facility sketch and fire extinguisher were posed in a prominent area in the Administration Office. LPA Edwards completed an inspection of the physical plant, the Administration Office, and the Transitional Independent Living Plan (THPP) office.
