Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Paul Simien made an unannounced visit to the above listed facility's main office to conduct an office visit to discuss a incident report (IR) received by CCL. LPA discussed this with Shaniz Beza, Executive Director (ED) at 11: AM on 12/9/22. On 12/6/ CCL received an IR from the facility detailing an incident that occurred on 12/1/22. The incident report stated that a client's dependent (aged 1) was exposed to ant poison while playing in the living room. The client informed a staff member about what had occurred and stated that they weren't sure if the child had ingested the ant poison. The staff member called 911 for emergency assistance. LPA Simien expressed his concern that a child was exposed to ant poison and asked what happened and how the child was able to access ant poison. ED stated that the facility was having an ant issue. ED said the client claimed she was watching the child in the living room while on the phone and then noticed the poison on the child's arm. The client informed a staff member who called 911. The local fire department arrived and checked the child and stated that it did not seem like the child ingested the poison due to no substance being around her mouth. ED explained that the facility took consideration of the child and bought ant traps instead of using ant spray so the child wouldn't be able to touch the poison. ED showed LPA Simien a picture of the trap the facility was using. The trap was a small plastic container with small holes and gel inside. ED speculated that the child probably put the trap against her arm and squeezed it getting gel on it. ED stated that the traps were removed from the facility. LPA Simien informed ED that the facility either needs to find child safe ant traps or find a different solution to the ant problem. Exit interview was conducted and and a copy of this report was provided to Shaniz Beza, ED whose signature confirms the receipt of this document.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Paul Simien made an unannounced visit to the above listed facility. The purpose of this visit was to conduct a Case Management inspection. During LPA Simien's investigation of complaint 26-CR-20220930163206 (9/30/22) he was informed of a instance where a client was moved abruptly without much notice. LPA was not given the context of this instance and being concerned with potential personal rights violations opened up this case management. ED informed LPA that clients aren't moved unless it's an emergency or a client is struggling with compliance. If a client is struggling with compliance they will be placed on a 30 day behavioral contract. The client would then sign the agreement statement within the contract. The contract gives a 30 day notice to any potential changes, including moving rooms or a new location if compliance is not met. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to Shaniz Beza, ED whose signature on this form confirm receipt of these documents.

The interview with C1 confirmed that the client was restricted from outings as discipline and had their phone confiscated for similar reasons. An interview was conducted with C2 (see confidential names LIC811) on August 12, 2021. The interview confirmed that the client was also aware of cell phones being confiscated as discipline and understood that if they got in trouble restrictions on outings would extend on outings with CASA, county social workers or family visits. An interview conducted with facility Manager Shaniz Beza on April 13th, 2021 revealed that C1 had their phone confiscated due to discipline as a result of behavioral issues. Shaniz was unable to recall of any discipline that took place where C1 was restricted from outings due to discipline and indicated that the only recent restrictions that took place were due to COVID19 restrictions and shelter in place orders in 2020. A review of the facility Program Statement revealed that included during admission was a cell phone policy indicating a cell phone would be confiscated as discipline. Based on interviews and document evidence, it was determined that the THPP did confiscate personal belongings of C1 (cell phone) and limited visits of C1. Although regulations allow for confiscation of personal items as part of a discipline policy (86068.2), this must be documented in a Needs and Services Plan and justified as a risk to the Child's Health and Safety. At the time of the file review of C1 on 03/16/2021 there was no Assessment Needs and Services Plan (ANSP) for C1. The ANSP would have documented the Health and Safety Need for the client to have their phone confiscated as part of a discipline program. The regulations also allow limits on outings; however the limits must also be documented on the ANSP. C1 had no ANSP on file to review limits on visitation outside of the THPP. Based on the information obtained, there is a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the THPP violated the documentation regulations. Therefore, the above allegations are substantiated. Appeal Rights were provided and discussed with the facility manager and deficiencies were cited.

An interview was conducted with S1 on 09/08/21 at approximately 1:45pm. Staff reported that they had found C1 had left the home without permission on multiple occasions; however, they indicated that C1 responded via text of their whereabouts. In an effort to build rapport with C1, S1 did not report that C1 had left the home without permission to their authorized representative or C1's case manager, S2. S1 admitted that they knew it was required for them to report C1 being absent without permission. S1 provided the facility screen shorts of their efforts to have client come back and keep track of their whereabouts. C1 was responsive to S1's texts and on some occasions sent selfies to show their whereabouts. A review of the screen shots submitted indicated that S1 was encouraging C1 to return the facility. A confidential interview was conducted with the reporting party (RP) on 07/15/2021 at 9am. The RP revealed that the facility failed to report the client leaving the facility without permission and failed to provide adequate supervision of C1. LPA Segura conducted a file review at the facility on 07/21/2021. LPA found that C1 did not have an Assessment Needs and Services Plan developed. Regulations for THPP programs require for a THPP to identify the level of care and supervision a client requires in their Assessment Needs and Services Plan. The facility had not complied with this requirement; therefore, LPA was unable to evaluate the level of supervision the client required. Based on the information obtained, there is a preponderance of the evidence to prove that facility staff failed to develop an Assessment Needs and Services Plan to assess the need for care and supervision the client required. Further facility staff failed to report the client had left the facility without permission. Therefore the allegations are substantiated. Appeal rights were provided and discussed with Shaniz Beza and deficiencies were cited. Exit interview conducted and a copy of the report was left with Shaniz Beza.

narrative: On June 24, 2021 @ 1:45PM an unannounced site inspection was made for the purpose of conducting a Required Annual Evaluation. LPA Kathy Landry met with Program Manager and Director of Housing Services and toured facility. Tour began near 1:45PM. This program is a Transitional Housing Program operating with remote sites. There were 26 clients ranging in age from 18 to 21 residing in the facility's program. Facility has remote sites in Los Angeles County in close proximity of its headquarters. At 2:45PM a secondary tour by LPA Landry was conducted on one remote apartment site located at Gresham St. Unit #5, N. Hills, Ca 91343. There are no fire arms on any premises. There are no bodies of water on site premises. Children are supervised. Facility is clean, safe and in good repair. No passage ways, inclines, stairways, ramps or open porches are obstructed. Disinfectants/poisons are inaccessible. There is an adequate amount of emergency food supply. Clients are responsible for their medications and regular food supply. Personal Rights is posted. Childrens rights are upheld. Facility operates within its licensed conditions & limitations, including capacity. There are no excluded persons on premises. LPA Landry has requested an updated LIC 500 to review all staff Criminal Record Clearances. Facility has a current Plan of Operation. Staff have been instructed to report Personal Rights Violation. Licensee/Admin have been instructed to report changes in the plan of operation which affects clients. Facility Rep has been reminded to report client injuries requiring medical treatment and other special incidents. Four Clients records were reviewed. Staff records are secured at Human Resource Headquarters. Facility was within Title Regulations and no citations issued. Exit interview conducted.Copy of Report given.

On 6/25/2021, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Kendal Zirbes met with Licensee Sherry Brown who granted access to the facility. The purpose of this inspection was to conduct an announced pre-licensing inspection for a Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) for Non-Minor Dependents (NMD). The administrative office was toured both inside and out with the Administrator at 3:50pm. Presently, the THPP NMD has requested a capacity of NMD's who will be placed in remote site apartments or houses. Licensee was advised the remote sites must be located within two hours of the administrative office. The THPP Administrative office is located in San Bernardino County. The office is located in a retail business establishment. The office consists of a reception area and two offices for administration. The Licensee plans to set up a computer station with education and job resources in the reception area. The administration office was equipped with working office equipment, furniture, and supplies. According to Licensee, all participant files and staff files will be stored in locked cabinets within the Administrators office. During this inspection Component III for THPP NMD was conducted by LPA Zirbes. During this component, LPA discussed Post Licensing inspection that Community Care Licensing (CCL) may provide, solutions to problematic areas, overview of Title 22, THPP regulations; NMD regulations, personal fingerprint requirements, associations, abuse reporting requirements and licensing fees. LPA informed the Licensee about the reporting requirements specifically, AB388 and LIC LE. Furthermore, Provider Information Notices (PIN), Resource Guides and the process for designating a new facility Administrator was reviewed. Licensee was advised that this pre-licensing report and application will be reviewed by the Department. The facility will be notified once they are licensed as a THPP NMD. An exit interview was conducted with Licensee Sherry Brown and a copy of this report was emailed to the Licensee.

On November 20, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Vanessa Galvan traveled to Phoenix THPP located in Exeter, CA, to conduct an unannounced Case Management inspection and met with the Brian Gambini, Administrator. The purpose of the inspection is to follow up on a Special Incident Report (SIR) submitted to the department on 11/07/2023. On the evening of 11/4/23 at Client's 1 residence, it was reported to case manager (CM) that there had been a drive by shooting at C1's apartment. It was reported to CM that C1 had some friends over to hang out with and words were exchange between C1's guests and by passers. Evidentially a short time later shots were exchanged between the two parties. No one was reported injured. Visalia Police department (VPD) arrived onsite within minutes and C1 and guest were detained. C1 was released the next morning 11/5/23. CM notified C1 on 11/5/23 that C1 was terminated from the program and was not to return to the apartment. CM meet with C1's family member on 11/6/23 at the apartment to collect C1's belongings. C1 did not have a roommate. No Phoenix staff were present during the event. All information stated in the incident report was gathered from conversations with C1's family members. VPD would not give any information out when CM arrived at the apartment. After receiving the phone call informing CM of the situation, CM immediately went to the apartment. When he arrived, VPD was on-sight conducting their investigation. They did not allow access to the apartment or divulge information concerning the investigation. CM was later informed that a friend of C1 admitted to law enforcement having the gun and firing the shots. C1's probation in agreement with Phoenix of C1's termination of the program. Based on the information obtained through the interview and records review, there are no violations. No deficiencies are being cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and at the conclusion of the inspection a copy of this report and the LIC 811 were provided to Brian Gambini.

narrative: On November 7, 2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Vanessa Galvan traveled to the Phoenix Transitional Housing Plus office located in Visalia CA. LPA was met by Administrator (ADM) Brian Gambini for the purpose of a scheduled pre-licensing inspection for a THP + NMD. A general overview of their program and a tour of the facility was provided. This facility has a reception area, waiting area, office space for staff and space for confidential meetings. LPA observed fixtures and furniture, equipment and supplies necessary for this operation. Also observed locked cabinets for client and staff files to ensure confidentiality. The office was equipped with a first aid kit and a fire extinguisher. All required LIC forms and personal rights are posted in a common area. The ADM is in the process of setting up a Guardian account to transfer and associate staff. Agency to provide to LPA Galvan association requests and copies of current identification for any staff to be associated prior to Guardian account approval. A copy of this report was provided to Brian Gambini at the conclusion of the inspection.

On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst Lisa Slusher arrived at Phoenix Transitional Housing Plus for the purpose of conducting an unannounced Post Licensing inspection. LPA met with Administrator Brian Gambini and inspected the facility, inside and out. The facility has a written emergency disaster plan. A fire extinguisher is properly charged. Certificates of compliance were observed for all remote/scattered sites where participants are placed. The facility employs Administrator, 1 full time Social Worker Supervisor/Social Worker , 2 part time Social Workers, Case Managers, Clerical employees. Six records of personnel/staff members were reviewed to ensure staff meet regulatory requirements. Personnel Files are maintained on-site. All staff are appropriately fingerprint cleared and associated. Six Records of clients were reviewed. Staff interviews were conducted. No deficiencies noted in areas observed. One Technical violation is noted in the area of documenting Education and Experience. A copy of this report and appeal rights were provided at the conclusion of the inspection.

On 5/1/25, at 10:45am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nancy O'Connell conducted an announced Pre-Licensing inspection at Phoenix Transitional Housing Plus THPP, located at N. Halcyon Rd. #A, Arroyo Grande CA 93420. LPA met with applicant, Brian Gambini, Denise Rabena (proposed program director), Sandra Hyatt (proposed administrative assistant). At the time of the visit, there are no children in placement. The facility is seeking a license to provide care for thirty (30) ambulatory, Non-Minor Dependents, ages 18-21. The only interview conducted was with the applicant. Facility Overview: The facility is located within an office building. The office is comprised of two office rooms, a bathroom, a kitchen, and a lobby/reception area. The main office has a desk area for staff, locked filing cabinets, a computer, a functional telephone for youth to make telephone calls, and a printer. LPA confirmed that the applicant is seeking approval to operate a remote site model and confirms that the remote sites will be located within a two-hour driving distance. Applicant identified area in office that may be used for confidential meetings and phone calls for youth. An exit interview was conducted with applicant, Brian Gambini, and an electronic copy of this report was sent via email.

Due to the COVID- Pandemic, LPA met with the THPP Administrator via FaceTime who provided a virtual inspection of the Administrative Office and conference room where the youths records are maintained. LPA-Gray concluded the Tele-Inspection the business for the Capacity Change. A copy of the report will be emailed to S Administrator of the THP+FC for signature.

Licensing Program Manager Angela King and Licensing Program Analyst Sethany Yem conducted a case management inspection on 9/20/23 at 10:43am based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 3 out of Direct Care Staff and 6 out of 11 youth files were reviewed. 3 out of Direct Care Staff and 3 out of 11 youths were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, 9/20/23). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the Board Meeting Minutes related to the facility's incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the Safety Plan, Crisis Prevention Plan and Needs and Services Plan, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPM Angela King observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Administrator Miki McRee.

On May 25, 2023, Investigator Miles arrived unannounced at the Transitional Housing Placement Program Participant Living Unit (Reseda location). Investigator Miles was not able to meet with facility staff or Administrator during this visit as there were no staff available during the hours of operation. Confidential statements obtained revealed the live-in staff often left residents unsupervised, unattended and was unreliable. Confidential statements further revealed that drugs and alcohol were often being used by the residents and other individuals while in the facility. According to the programs House Rules, "no drugs or alcohol" are allowed in the home. Based on statements and record reviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the allegations are deemed substantiated. A deficiency is cited, California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 7, Plan of Operation. Exit interview was conducted with the Administrator. A copy of this report and appeal rights are discussed and provided. Information obtained revealed a lack of evidence to support or corroborate reported claims. Confidential interviews found not enough evidence to prove the alleged as statements indicate denial and or no knowledge of said allegations. Administrator informed LPA that the THPP once located in Reseda has since been closed and is no longer in operation. Based on gathered information, the allegations are determined Unsubstantiated. A finding that the complaint is unsubstantiated means that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. Exit interview completed. A copy of this report and LIC811 was provided to Facility Representative. Exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report was left with the Administrator.

LPA met with Miki Mcree, who granted access to the facility, and together, they discussed the investigation details. During the investigation process, all relevant parties have been accounted for. It was reported that Staff allows the minors to engage in sexual intercourse on the facility grounds and Staff allows inappropriate activities on the facility grounds. After conducting confidential interviews and reviewing documents, there was insufficient evidence or testimony to substantiate the allegations.Although the allegation may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. The Department has decided that the allegation of Neglect/Lack of Supervision is Unsubstantiated but if any additional information is received this complaint can be amended and the finding can be changed. narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christopher Rollins made an unannounced required Annual inspection to Real Alternatives (Side by Side) Administrative office. LPA met with Rebecca Hathorn Administrator and Ahnjolique Haskins Program Director (PD). The Transitional Housing Placement Plus Foster Care program (THP-FC) services non-minors dependents. At 11: AM, LPA did a walk through inspection with Administrator and PD of the office. The office has sufficient space for confidential meetings, all participant files and staff files are located in a locked cabinet in a secure location. The agency has their license posted in their office. The office is in compliance with Community Care Licensing (CCL) regulations. LPA spoke with Administrator and PD about the residential units. Administrator stated that all residential units have at least one toilet, sink and tub in working order. Administrator stated that all disinfectants and cleaning supplies are locked up and inaccessible. Administrator notified LPA that the program provides all participants with household essentials and that there are no weapons or firearms stored in the housing units. At 11: AM, LPA reviewed 6 participants files with Administrator and PD. LPA observed Participants files to be complete and found no deficiencies. All documents are complete and up to date. At 12: PM LPA observed 6 staff files with Administrator and PD. LPA observed all 6 staff files to be complete, all documentation is up to date and all staff training were up to date/current. At 1: PM LPA conducted staff interviews with 2 staff. During inspection, LPA received a updated copy of the LIC Personnel Report to maintain their file current. LPA receive an updated list of the Participant Residential Units and LPA reviewed the program Certificate of Compliance for all apartments. A review of Licensing Information System on December 15, 2021 indicates that all facility staff associated to the facility had DOJ, FBI and child abuse index check clearances. Per Title Regulations, no deficiencies were cited during this inspection. Exit interview conducted and a copy of the report was left at the facility. .

On 3/8/22 at 1: PM Licensing Program Analyst's (LPA) Alyssa Ng and Isabel Mendoza made an unannounced case management inspection at the above facility. The purpose for this inspection is to conduct a case management and follow-up on three incident reports that occurred on 2/2/22, 2/18/22, and 2/21/22. All three incident reports were submitted to Community Care Licensing (CCL) on Friday 3/4/22. LPA also recommended Ahnjolique Program Director to submit only the LIC 624LE or to use only one form when sending in an IR. Due to the lack of information LPA's needed to gather additional information. 1.Incident report involves (P1) (please refer to LIC 811, dated 3/8/22 for confidential names). On 2/2/22 (P1's) apartment was raided, and (P1) was arrested. During inspection, LPA's interviewed (P1's) case manager regarding the incident and obtained copies of case notes, staff phone numbers. It was learned that (P1's) apartment was raided by Oakland Police Department, and the raid occurred because of (P1)'s roommate (P2). (P2) had a warrant for his arrest, and the facility does not have any additional information regarding the warrant. LPA will follow-up with Oakland Police Department. During inspection, Director submitted a copy of incident report pertaining to (P2). Program Director informed LPA that the incident report was submitted to CCL on 2/7/22. However, LPA was unable to confirm and will follow-up with the facility if needed. At this time, (P1's) bed closed on 2/10/22 per probation officers request, and (P2) bed closed on 2/8/22. The facility was last in contact with the (P2) on 2/3/22. 2. Incident report involves (P3). On 2/21/22 neighbors reported to property manager of loud noises/yelling and a knock on the door from P3's girlfriend crying and scared. P3 was ----CONT. ON 809C-------- arrested and released the following day. Program Director told LPA that facility could not find an open bed and therefore, exited the program on 2/22/22. The facility submitted on (2.25.22). Community Care Licensing did not receive IR until 3/4/2022. 3. Incident report involves P4 getting arrested and taken to Santa Rita jail. Program Director told LPA that P4 was released due to it being the wrong person. Program Director was on leave until the 2/22/22 and approved the IR's. Facility will send follow up incident reports, needs and service plans and Case Manager notes for each client no later than Monday (3/14/22) and updated IR's with more information regarding the incident(s). An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was sent to the Program Director.

On 07/06/2022 at 11: AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA's) Alyssa Ng and George Karkazis conducted a visit to the main office of the above facility. On 07/05/2022, LPA Ng was informed that an 20 year old client of the facility had died from being shot multiple times in the back on 07/01/2022. LPA met with Bonnie Meyer, Housing Service Manager (HSM). LPA Ng collected copies of the Transitional Independent Living Plan, the client's progress notes, case plan goals for client and roommate, and any other information regarding the client. LPA also discussed with HSM what steps the facility is taking to help staff and youth process the incident. Clinical Case Manager and Youth Specialist were also in attendance. HSM discussed the plan following the incident. The facility is providing and will continue to provide grief counseling to clients and staff. Facility has also provided extra support to clients by utilizing therapeutic services, etc. There is a session scheduled to debrief and discuss the next steps for the staff, and more resources being provided to the clients. The facility is also working with the county worker to coordinate a meeting with the client's family to collect their belongings. LPA conducted an exit interview with Bonnie Meyer, Housing Service Manager at 12: PM. Facility will provide updates on what was discussed during the debriefing meeting and when the family collects the client's belongings.

investigation_findings: 13On 4/15/22 at 1: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng made a visit to the facility to open and close a complaint investigation of the above allegation. LPA met with Ahnjolique Haskins, Director of Transitional Housing and Intake Coordinator Tully Tampakes. Although, the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that minor is being discriminated against. Therefore, the above allegation are unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was sent to Ahnjolique Haskins, Director of Transitional Housing. narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jonathan Medina conducted an unannounced required annual inspection of the Real Alternatives (Side by Side) administrative office. LPA met with Program Manager De'Misha Barker. The Transitional Housing Placement Plus Foster Care (THP-FC) program serves non-minor dependents. During the inspection, LPA received an updated copy of the LIC Personnel Report to ensure the facility's records remain current. LPA also obtained an updated list of the Participant Residential Units. A review of the Guardian background check system on March 19, 2025, confirmed that all facility staff associated with the program had cleared DOJ, FBI, and Child Abuse Index checks. At 10: AM, LPA conducted a walkthrough inspection of the office with the Program Manager. The office has sufficient space for confidential meetings, and the agency's license is prominently posted. LPA observed a designated room where clients can relax, a clothing room where clients can select items, and another room where clients can pick up personal hygiene products and contraceptives. No deficiencies were observed. At 11: AM, LPA reviewed five staff files. The program is paperless and utilizes Paylocity to upload staff documents and Relias to track staff training. During this review, LPA identified two deficiencies in the CARE tool assessment. Specifically, some personnel folders were missing documentation of past work experience and job duties. Additionally, certain required staff training sessions had not been completed to meet regulatory requirements. Please refer to the LIC 809-D for details. Continues on LIC 809-C. At 1: PM, LPA reviewed five client files with the Program Manager. Client files have also been converted to a paperless system using a program called TIER. During the review, LPA identified four deficiencies, including missing Health and Education Passports or equivalent documentation, the absence of immunization records, missing required signatures in Needs and Services Plans, and outdated Transitional Independent Living Plans (TILPs). Please refer to the LIC 809-D for further details. At 2: PM, LPA began but did not complete the operational requirements section of the CARE tool. One technical violation was observed regarding the specification of clients' ambulatory status. LPA will return on another date to complete the inspection. As a result of today's inspection, seven deficiencies are being cited in accordance with the California Code of Regulations (CCR) and Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), 86066(a), 86065(f)(3), 86270(a)(2)(B), 86270(a)(2)(B)(1), 86268.3(d), 86068.3(a), and 86069(b)(1) . See LIC 809-D pages for details. An exit interview was conducted, during which the report and appeal rights were discussed and provided to Facility Manager De'Misha Barker.

narrative: On 03/26/2025 at 10: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jonathan Medina conducted an unannounced visit to complete the required two-year inspection of the Real Alternatives (Side by Side) administrative office. LPA met with De'Misha Barker, Program Manager. At 10: AM, LPA reviewed the Operations section of the CARE tool. The program currently has 15 units with a capacity of 30, currently serving 21 clients. No deficiencies were observed, and all records were well maintained digitally. At 11: AM, LPA reviewed the facility's Disaster Preparedness section of the CARE tool. The program maintains client files digitally, making them easily accessible to all staff members in the event of an emergency. Staff also utilize a mobile application called M Copilot, which stores all client-specific documents, including emergency contacts, date of birth, social worker contact information, and bedroom location. Additionally, personal documents such as Needs and Services Plans and TILPs are stored in a computer application called TIER. The facility did not have records of quarterly drills available for review upon request. Please refer to the LIC809-D page for further details. Two technical violations were also noted in this section of the CARE tool regarding the location of the water shutoff valve and the description of how the emergency generator should be used. As a result of today's visit, one deficiency is being cited in accordance with Health and Safety Code (HSC) §1565(c). An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were discussed, and a copy of this report was provided to Facility Manager De'Misha Barker.

Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Katherine Deaton and Kellie McKinley conducted an annual inspection at the facility address located above. The LPAs reviewed all participant records and found signed copies of personal rights and all school records, immunization records, and medical records that were provided. Current, signed Certificates of Compliance were also found in the participant files. The LPAs then conducted a facility inspection of the Administrative office located at G St, Eureka, CA. The facility is clean, safe, and sanitary. The LPAs reviewed all staff records. Personnel meet education and experience requirements. Annual evaluations are maintained. Staff have appropriate background and Child Abuse Central Index checks on file. LPA Deaton found that two staff records that had vehicle insurance information that recently expired. LPA Deaton received current vehicle insurance information following the in-person inspection. LPA Deaton contacted Pat Sweeney, Administrator (AD). AD stated that there is one Transitional Housing Placement Provider (THPP) Participant with a child residing in their living unit; the THPP and participant are aware that disinfectants / poisons are to be kept inaccessible to the child. All participant living units have at least one toilet, sink and tub or shower in working order. Participants and their minor children are provided with household essentials. There are no firearms stored in THPP participant living units. There are no participants who are non-ambulatory; licensee is aware of the fire clearance requirement. The THPP administrative office and participant living units have telephone service. No citations were issued throughout the course of this investigation.

On 7/19/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lyta Vue arrived unannounced at the facility and met with Patrick Sweeney, Program Manager. The purpose of the visit was to conduct a Required Annual Inspection of the facility. The last Annual inspection for the facility was on 6/28/21. LPA utilized the CARE Tool to complete the Annual inspection. LPA conducted an inspection of the physical plant and checked for all necessary requirements. The facility was clean and organized and maintained an acceptable room temperature. The facility has five offices for social workers and two confidential interview/visitation rooms. LPA observed the proper postings including: facility license, complaint hotline, personal rights, and emergency disaster plan. The restrooms for clients and staff were clean. Smoke alarms were in working order, fire extinguishers were current, and a first aid kit was fully stocked. Evacuation drills for the facility were completed quarterly. LPA observed client files were stored in locked filing cabinets and in locked offices. The facility has no outstanding fees. The facility has no minor clients and Non-Minor Dependent clients. Clients live in either mentor homes or remote site apartments. No client resides more than two hours from the facility. The facility employs two Case Managers, one program Coordinator, and one of Supervisors/Program Manager. LPA reviewed 4 staff personnel files. All 4 staff completed criminal record clearances and met minimum education and experience qualifications which 2 are Case Managers. All First Aid and CPR certifications were up to date for all 4 staff personnel which 2 are Case Managers. LPA interviewed 3 staff personnel which 2 are Case Managers. 1 staff personnel was not present. One Case Worker personnel indicated they did not have more than 12 clients on their caseload. LPA reviewed 2 client files. All clients had signed Admission Agreements. Client files had current Needs and Service Plans, signed by the client and placing agency. Needs and Services Plan detailed adequate supportive services the facility offers to the clients. (*For facilities with minors, indicate whether CHDP Physical, dental, and JV 220 are current.) Continued on 809c No citations were given on this date. A signed copy of this LIC-809 (and LIC-809C) report was provided to the Program Manager (PM). An exit interview was conducted. Appeal rights were provided (if applicable)

On 4/10/ Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kellie McKinley met with Administrator to conduct a death investigation. LPA inspected the facility. The facility walkways and hall ways were free and clear of obstructions. The fire extinguisher were current on inspections. The bathrooms were found clean and sanitary. The water temperature was found to be within the require limits. There are several office spaces within the facility all organized and some with storage of facility equipment. The facility has a working phone line. The smoke and carbon monoxide detectors are in function order. The first Aid kit contained the required supplies. The kitchen area was found clean with no dishes in the sink and the counter only with kitchen equipment. The garbage's are covered with lids. Food supplies are sufficient for 3-5 days and dry goods for 5-7 days. LPA interviewed the administrator and the case manager for C1. LPA collected documentation found pertinent to the investigation of C1's death. The autopsy was conducted on 4/07/2023. The coroner found nothing from the autopsy to determine cause of death. Information was shared by Administrator via his contact with the coroner. The coroner collected many documents and medications while at C1's apartments for the investigation. A toxicology report was requested by the coroner. The toxicology report should be completed with 6 to 8 weeks time. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report electronically sent to the administrator. Further investigation is needed to determine the cause of death. (NOTE:Original completed 4/10/2023 and not saved in system- this is a copy of the original)

On 9/28/22, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brian Bertoli conducted a pre-licensing inspection at the Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) for purposes of a change of location. Note that LPA was not able to enter visit on the day it occurred due to not being able to access the Pre-licensing Visit Type. LPA Bertoli met with Program Managers Lorraine Montano and Samantha Stafford and inspected the facility. The office is conveniently located for the public. This location previously housed the RCS Foster Family Agency and Adoptions Agency. The office has a reception area, multiple private offices, and conference room/training room (all of which can be also be used for confidential meetings). There is adequate parking available. Emergency Disaster Plan will be revised to show THPP. License will be posted as soon as issued. Masks and hand sanitizer are available. All files will be kept confidential and locked in the office and separated from visiting areas. Personnel files are stored securely at the administrative office on S Orchard St in Ukiah. Telephones, computers, fax and copying machines are operable. There are two all-gender bathrooms. Fire extinguishers are current. There are fire sprinklers, smoke detectors, and carbon monoxide detectors. A complete first aid kit is readily accessible. A Redwood Community Services sign is posted outside of the office. Prior to today's visit, the application for the relocation was received and reviewed by LPA Bertoli. An updated LIC 500 has been submitted. No deficiencies in the Physical Plant during today's inspection. Due to recent completion of the THPP Annual Inspection, no files were reviewed and no interviews completed. LPA Bertoli determined that the facility meets Title 22 regulations for the operations of a THPP. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was given to the facility. LPA Bertoli will submit the application for license and forward to the facility when issued.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Katherine Deaton conducted a pre-licensing inspection on 4/8/2021 at the new Remi Vista THPP/THP+FC-CHICO (THPP) location at Floral Avenue Suite 30, Chico, CA 95973. The LPA arrived at the facility donning a facemask and applied hand sanitizer. The LPA met with Rose Mary Marquez, (RM), Admin. who confirmed there have been no recent COVID-19 positives, exposures, or symptoms at the facility. RM prefers and in-person visit. Serenity Coleburn, Social Worker / Case Worker (CW) for THPP program was not present at the time of the inspection. The LPA toured the facility inside and out. The THPP is still in the process of moving in; boxes were visible however the facility is safe and sanitary. The office telephone is in proper working order. Staff residential and participant living unit phones have service at all times. There are no non-ambulatory THPP participants however RM is aware of the fire clearance request requirement. CW is the only staff who works with the four THPP participants. The LPA reviewed CW's personnel file and found a copy of CW's child abuse index check and criminal record clearance. The LPA found evidence that annual performance evaluations are being provided. Participant records were not available at the time of the inspection. The THPP does not allow participants to store firearms or other weapons in THPP participant living units. Participant are provided household essentials and have at least one toilet, sink and tub or shower in working order. There are three participants with children who reside in their living unit; participants are aware of the requirement that disinfectants and other items that could pose a danger must be made inaccessible. The LPA reviewed participant records on 4/15/2021 and found copy of personal rights forms. The LPA made multiple attempts to tour a THPP participant living unit without success. The facility does not maintain Certificates of Compliance for the participant living units. The LPA made contact with Troy Foster, Quality Assurance Officer who will develop the Certificates of Compliance and ensure all regulatory requirements are met. A copy of this report will be emailed to the facility with a read receipt requested.

On March 2, 2021 at 10: AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Charmetha White initiated a Case Management Incident inspection (via telephone) with Renaissance Pride in response to Special Incident Report (SIR) #744215. The incident involves a Client's death. LPA spoke with Administrator, Chris Onyegbaduo. The incident report was submitted to Community Care Licensing (CCL) on February 27, 2021. The incident, occurred on 02/27/2021, Client #1 was found unresponsive on her bed by her siblings who had come to the apartment to check on the client after the client was not answering their calls. Client #1's siblings called 911, the Ambulance and Hawthorne Police Department responded, and Client #1 was pronounced dead on arrival. During the visit LPA interviewed Staff #1. LPA was informed Staff #1 last spoke to Client #1 on 02/25/2021. Staff was notified of the incident from Client #1's roommate, Client #2, who was present in the apartment when Client #1 siblings arrived. Additionally, LPA was informed that Client #2 has been temporarily relocated to a different location. Staff has notify all pertinent parties regarding both Client #1 and Client #2 and Hawthorne Police Department is currently conducting an investigation. LPA requested the following information from Client #1's files: Placement Agreement, Intake Paperwork, Transitional Independent Living Plan (TILP), Case Management Notes, a copy of the police report, and a copy of Client #1's death certificate once the document is made available. This incident requires further investigation. A copy of this report was emailed to Chris Onyegbaduo for signature.

On 05/26/2022 at 10am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Bernice Karnsrithong arrived at the facility office for the purpose of conducting a Case Management-Incident that occurred on 05/02/2022. Health and safety risk assessment were conducted upon arriving at the facility. LPA Karnsrithong met with Olivia Ofomata, Youth Advocate and Office Manager. The current census is twenty-eight (28). A Special Incident Report (SIR) #810620 dated 05/02/2022 stated that a client had seizures on April 27, 2022 and was taken to the hospital for medical treatment. SIR indicated that this was caused due to client stopping to take her psychotropic medication. During the visit, LPA Karnsrithong conducted one (1) staff interview and reviewed documentary evidences. At this time, not all parties are available and additional time is needed for this case management. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted with Olivia Ofomata and a copy of this report will be provided.

On 06/07/2022 at 9am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Bernice Karnsrithong arrived at Renaissance Pride Main Office for the purpose of delivering Case Management-Incident findings. LPA Karnsrithong met with Olivia Ofomata, Office Manager and Youth Advocate for the agency. Health and safety risk assessment were conducted upon arriving the main office. A special incident report (SIR) #810620 dated 05/02/2022 stated that a client was taken to the hospital/urgent care to seek medical treatment. During the case management, LPA Karnsrithong has conducted confidential interviews and reviewed documentary evidences. Statements were consistent that client seek medical treatment from symptoms resulting from stopping her psychotropic medications. There was no evidence to corroborate that staff are not complying with emergency intervention procedures. This agency has conducted a case management-incident and has found that the case management was unfounded, meaning that the allegation is false, could not have happened and/or is without a reasonable basis. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted with Olivia Ofomata, Office Manager/ Youth Advocate and a copy of this report will be provided to the facility.

On 11/16/2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) C. White arrived at the above location for the purpose of conducting a 2-Year Required Inspection of the Transitional Housing Placement Administrative Office. LPA met with Executive Director, Chris Onyegbaduo. LPA was granted access and toured the entire facility. The program is licensed to provide THPP services to children 16-17 years old and THP+FC Services to Non Minor Dependents up to 49 beds. The current census is 33. This facility is located in a multilevel office building. The facility has 4 separate office rooms, a receptionist area, a waiting room, and a bathroom. The office rooms are set up as follows: Upon entering the office there is a waiting room area available for clients/visitors which is equipped with 2 couches, a coffee table and a small side table. There is a receptionist area, utilized by the facility manager. The office has a bathroom, and 4 separate rooms. Office room #1: is equipped with locked storage cabinets used to store client files. The room remains locked at all times. Office room #2: is used as the staff break room. Office room #: is equipped with a desk, chair, and a computer. The room is used by case managers and clients should they need computer access. Office room #4: is equipped with a large table and seating for at least 10 people. The room is used as a conference room for both staff and client meetings. Report continued on LIC 809C. This program utilizes the remote site housing model and ensures the following services will be applicable: 1.) Participants have their own bedroom; 2.) No more than two participants share a bathroom: 3.) No more than two participants share a refrigerator; 4.) On-site supervisor available 24/7 to support, assist and oversee the needs of the participants: 5.) Assigned Social Workers assist and meet with participants a minimum of once a week (face-to-face); and 6.) Supervision, if needed, for the distribution of prescription medication. The organization also utilizes the iTrack system to report Special Incidents to CCL. A total of four (4) client files were reviewed. All Client Records are current and contained the required documentation including: Admission Agreements, Allowance Logs, Savings Deposit records, Receipts, Needs and Services Plans, Personal Rights forms. A total of five (5) staff files were reviewed. All staff files contained caregiver background checks, criminal record and child abuse index check clearances, and current First Aid/CPR cards. Personnel Files are maintained on-site. LPA obtained a copy of the facility personnel report, LIC 500. The facility operates within license conditions and limitations including capacity limitations. LPA will return at a later date to conduct staff and client interviews. No deficiencies were observed or cited at the time of this inspection. A copy of this report was left at the with the Executive Director.

narrative: On March 27, 2023, at 9: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Gloria Meza-Gonzalez conducted an unannounced inspection at the above facility. LPA Meza-Gonzalez met with Case Manager (CM) Ashley Parra and Program Manager (PM) Berenice Perez. The purpose of the inspection is to conduct a random annual. The facility is licensed to provide transitional housing placement plus foster care for non-minor dependents for 30 participants ages eighteen (18) through twenty-one (21) years old. There are currently 13 participants in the program. The Administrative Office is located at Spring Drive, Spring Valley, CA 91977. The administrative office is in a portable on San Diego Youth Services (SDYS) property in room #29. LPA Meza - Gonzalez inspected the administrative office. The facility has three offices within the portable bungalow. Office #1 is the Program Coordinator's office. Office #2 is the file room and Program Assistant's Office. Office #3 is the Program Administrator's office The Youth Advocates' desks are located in the main area of the bungalow. The administrative offices have working telephones. The facility also is able to reserve conference rooms on the property for meetings, interviews, and orientation with receptions services. The participants' files (See Confidential Name List, LIC 811, date: March 27, 2023) are stored and locked in a cabinet located in office #2. Five participants' files were reviewed. The participants' files were complete. Staff files are located off-site in the main administration building. The staff files were brought to the facility. Five staff files were reviewed. The staff files were complete. LPA Meza-Gonzalez conducted one staff interview due to one staff was present. There were no deficiencies observed on this date in accordance with Title 22, Division 6 of the California Code of Regulations. An Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to PM Perez.

Confidential interviews indicated C1 would not sleep at the apartment complex for consecutive days. Confidential interviews indicated C1 would be gone for 10 days and wouldn't take out their trash to the apartment complex dumpster. Confidential interviews also indicated C1 refused for their unit to be fumigated. Regarding the allegation non- minor is not provided unit keys, it was reported that C1 never received a key to their door. During the investigation, confidential interviews indicated C1 requested for keys two times and the facility offered a keypad lock for C1 and C1 refused. Documents reviewed indicated a request was submitted for keys. LPA received conflicting information. Regarding the allegation that a non- minor is being evicted. Confidential interviews and record review indicated C1 was placed on a 14-day supportive plan to avoid eviction and a 30-day notice to terminate tenancy. Confidential interviews disclosed that C1 was being evicted for failing to follow the program housing guidelines such as meeting with case worker on a weekly basis, maintaining full time productivity of a minimum of 32 hours a week of school or work, making rental payments, no pets at apartment complex, safe behavior guidelines and visitor restrictions. The confidential interviews continued stating that C1 would miss meetings with case manager and C1 was not enrolled in school nor employed. Additional confidential interviews reported that C1 was interested in joining the military and was speaking with a recruiter. Confidential interviews indicated C1 was behind on their rent and C1 had a dog on site which was not allowed unless proper documentation was submitted to the program. Confidential interviews revealed conflicting statements. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the allegations that C1's unit has pests, C1 is not provided unit keys, and C1 is being evicted, may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support or deny the allegations. Therefore, the above allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this signed report was provided to Jose Ayala, Program Manager.

On 09/28/2021 at 09:30 a.m., Licensing Program Manager (LPM Ann Valenzuela and Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Marisol Lopez conducted an unannounced inspection for the purpose of conducting a required annual. LPM and LPA met with Facility Administrator Xavier Martinez and conducted an inspection of the facility. The facility is licensed to provide Transitional housing placement plus foster care (THP+FC) services for 27 participants to non-minor dependents. LPA and LPM inspected both indoor and outdoor areas of the facility. The facility has 15 participants in care. The facility administrative office is located on site. Facility utilizes apartment complex housing model and has 17 apartment homes. There are ten apartment homes that have two bedrooms and seven apartment homes that have 1 bedroom on two different sites. Files are located in locked file cabinets within locked offices. There are no physical plant deficiencies. Staffing: The agency employee's the following assigned staff under the THP program. Program Director/Administrator, Program Coordinator/Social Worker Supervisor, Housing Coordinator; Case manager/Social Worker and Resident Manager. All employees have the required experience, and training for their current job employment. LPM and LPA reviewed 5 staff files and Non-minor dependent files. During the review, 1 out of 5 staff (S1) did not maintain a criminal record clearance in the staff file as required, all personnel records are not maintained at facility site, 5 out of 5 staff (S1-S5) files are missing a completed Child Abuse Central Index check (LIC 198A) and a Criminal Record Statement (LIC508). All staff files met the minimum qualifications for training requirements. The facility provided a list of clients and certified apartment information, current Personnel Report (LIC 500), Designation of Facility Responsibility (LIC 308) and all staff have current CPR certificates on file. (see continuation form LIC 9099-C dated 09/28/21) The non-minor dependent files were complete and included a signed Needs and Service plan, Transitional Independent Living Plan (TILP) and case progress notes were current. All client files reviewed were complete and had the requirement documents. Based on LPM and LPA's records review, the facility is cited under Title 22, Division 6, Chapter Criminal Record Clearance section 80019(d), 80019(j),Child Abuse Central Index section 80019.2(b) and Personnel Records section 80066(e). An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was given the Program Administrator Xavier Martinez.

On April 6, 2023, at 11: AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Gloria Meza-Gonzalez and Lucero Jauregui conducted an unannounced inspection. LPAs Meza-Gonzalez and Jauregui met with Program Administrator (PA) Xavier Martinez. The purpose of the inspection is to conduct a random annual inspection. The facility is licensed to provide Transitional housing placement plus foster care (THP+FC) services for 27 participants to non-minor dependents. There are currently 10 participants in care. LPAs Meza-Gonzalez and Jauregui inspected both indoor and outdoor areas of the facility with PA Martinez. The facility administrative office is located on-site. The facility utilizes an apartment complex housing model and has apartment homes. There are ten apartment homes that have two bedrooms and seven apartment homes that have 1 bedroom on two different sites. The facility has two offices, Administrative office and housing office. The Program Administrator is located in the administrative office. The staff files are in a locked cabinets. The participate files are located housing office locked in filing cabinets within a locked office. There are no physical plant deficiencies. The agency employs the following assigned staff under the THP program. Program Administrator, Housing Coordinator; Case Manager. LPA Jauregui reviewed three staff files. LPA Jauregui observed the staff files met the minimum qualifications for training requirements. LPA Jauregui observed that all employees have the required experience and training for their current job employment. LPA Meza-Gonzalez conducted two staff interviews. See page 2 - LIC809C LPAs Meza-Gonzalez and Jauregui reviewed five participants files (see confidential name list, LIC811, dated: April 6, 2023). The non-minor dependent files were complete and included a signed Needs and Service plan, Transitional Independent Living Plan (TILP) and case progress notes were current. LPAs Meza-Gonzalez and Jauregui observed the participants files reviewed were complete and had the requirement documents. There were no deficiencies observed on this date in accordance with Title 22, Division 6 of the California Code of Regulations. An Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to PA Martinez.

On October 15, 2024, at 11: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lucero Jauregui conducted an unannounced inspection at the facility and met with Hillary Sloan, Program Administrator. The purpose of the inspection is to conduct a case management. On October 10, 2024 the Department received a report regarding alleged abuse and neglect to a client in care. LPA Jauregui conducted one staff interview, one client interview, obtained Special Incident Reports and reviewed maintenance requests. Based on information gathered, further information is needed and the case management will be extended. An exit interview was conducted and copy of this report was provided to Hillary Sloan, Program Administrator.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nicole Moua conducted a pre-licensing inspection for Sierra Nevada Connections-THPP/THP+FC. LPA met with Executive Director Shauna Rossington (SR) telephonically via Facetime. The facility is currently looking into signing a lease at the new location and has not yet moved their facility. The anticipated move date is 11/01/2020. LPA conducted a walk-through via Facetime with SR. SR provided a virtual tour of the facility. · Complaint hot line will need to be posted in a prominent area · Internet and phone services will be added · Disaster and mass casualty plan will be posted in a central location · There are multiple confidential office spaces for interviews and visits · Smoke alarms and carbon monoxide detectors are present and working · Disinfectants, cleaning solutions, poisons, firearms and any other items posing a danger if readily available will be locked when the move is complete · There is a file room, which includes a lock on the outside door · Toilet, hand washing, bathing facilities are maintained in a safe and sanitary operating condition · First aid kit will be added · Fire extinguisher will be added · Disaster drills will be conducted every six months and every time there is a new employee · There are multiple private offices for staff · Fire clearance needs to be completed No deficiencies cited. Facility will be ready to operate from the new location when all of the above has been completed. LPA to follow up.

On January 7, 2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Hillary Hall arrived unannounced at the facility for the purpose of completing an Annual inspection for the Sierra Nevada Connections Transitional Housing Placement THPP/THP facility. On 12/16/2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Hillary Hall and Danielle Walker-Flores arrived unannounced at the above facility for an Annual Inspection of the Foster Family Agency, housed at the same address as the Transitional Housing facility. LPA's conducted a facility inspection using the CARE tool on 12/16/21. Facility was clean and organized. First Aid kit was complete. Private rooms were available for interviews. Kitchen and bathroom facilities were in good repair. Facility was not re-inspected on this date. The THPP/THP +FC facility has been licensed since 12/07/2020. As of 1/7/2022, the facility has two non-minor dependent clients. Both clients reside in a host home model placement. LPA Hall interviewed three staff between 12/16-12/17/21 who work with THP clients. LPA's Hall and Walker-Flores reviewed two staff files who work with THP clients on 12/16/21. On 1/7/2021, LPA Hall reviewed two THP client files. During the file review, LPA observed Needs and Services Treatment Plans and Updates were missing for two out of two clients. One client was placed in March 2021 and the other client was placed in August 2021. Facility is being cited for California Code of Regulations Section 86168.2(a): Needs and Services and Transitional Independent Living Plan: At the time of placement, the THPP social work personnel in consultation with the authorized representative shall commence a needs and services plan for each participant. One THP client was residing over 3 hours drive from the facility (188 miles). Continued on 809C Continued from Facility is being cited for California Code of Regulations Section 86178(c): Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision: No social work staff shall have participants who are located more than two hours' travel by automobile from the THPP office in their caseload. Medical and dental records were missing for one THP client. Facility is being cited for California Code of Regulations Section 86069: Participant Medical Assessments: (a) Prior to or within 30 calendar days following the acceptance of a participant, the licensee shall obtain a written medical assessment of the participant, as specified in Section 80069(b), which enables the licensee to determine his/her ability to provide necessary health related services to the participant. The assessment shall be used in developing the Needs and Services Plan. A signed copy of the LIC-809, LIC-809C, and LIC-809D were provided to the facility. Exit interview was conducted and appeal rights were provided.

On May 6, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Briana Placencia traveled to Sofiya's Village THPP located in Modesto CA. LPA was met by Licensee Nattaly Valenzuela-Meza and Facility Manager Joy Burgner, for the purpose of a scheduled pre-licensing inspection for the THPP. A general overview of their program and a tour of the facility was provided. The facility is a two story residence with three bedrooms, the bedrooms have all required furnishings, the facility has three restrooms and one office. Facility is to ensure water temperature is maintained between 105 and 120 degrees. LPA observed fixtures and furniture, equipment and supplies necessary for this operation. LPA observed locked cabinets for client and staff files in order to ensure confidentiality. There is ample confidential space for meeting with clients on an as needed basis. The facility does have a pool on site and meets regulatory standards. The agency employs one administrator, and one facility manager. The facility is equipped with a first aid kit and a fire extinguisher. All required LIC forms and personal rights are posted in a common area. The THPP has set up a guardian account and will need to associate the facility manager and submit the required documents to LPA Placencia. Items discussed were the access to cameras on property. The hot water temperature. Possibility of off-site office space to free up the fourth room. LPA discussed daily ongoing functions including incident reporting. LPA also discussed that Licensee should obtain a telephone for the clients use. The above licensee meets the requirements to be licensed as a THPP in Stanislaus County, with the ability to place participants within a two hour radius. On a quarterly basis, facility is to submit a roster of THPP clients that includes client names, dates of birth, county worker and current address of placement. A copy of this report was provided to the Licensee.

The purpose of the inspection is to conduct a post-licensing inspection. LPAs conducted a physical plant inspection and included the following observation and checks: client and staff files are kept in locked filing cabinets. The agency has adequate confidential meeting space, space for Social Worker and Case Manager to complete job duties. The facility has a current copy of the license, Facility Sketch, Client Personal Rights, posted in a common area. The agency has a client register roster LIC 9120, with all required information. The agency's office is located on facility grounds at this time. The agency employs (1) Executive Director/Administrator, (1) Program Manager (2) Facility Managers/Case Managers, and (1) Administrative Assistant. LPAs reviewed five staff files and one client file. The facility is being issued five Technical Assistance (TA) at todays inspection. A copy of this report and TAs were provided Joy Burgner at the conclusion of the inspection.

narrative: issues were taken care of. It was advised that Client #1 disclosed that there were no issues with safety and Client #1 just desired to be in the apartment without a roommate. CSW stated the only time she was advised of a delay was allowance was distributed on November 18, but was received on November 19. The CSW stated there were no issues or concerns regarding the allowance. Based on interviews and information obtained, clients needs are not being met and facility staff withheld client's funds may or may not have occurred; therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview conducted and a copy of the report will be provided to the facility.

On December 12, 2023 at 9: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jacob Salem arrived at the above facility's administrative office for the purpose of conducting an annual inspection. LPA met with Verenna Huerta, Administrator and explained the purpose of the visit. The inspection CARE tool was inoperable during LPA's visit, such that the spreadsheet cells that indicate compliance could not be selected. LPA used the CARE tool as a guide only during his inspection and contacted IT support to rectify the technical issue. LPA began by conducting an inspection of the office's physical plant. The office consists of a large main room with four desks, and two private offices that can be used for confidential interviews. Client files are kept in a locked file cabinet in the main room. LPA observed the facility license to be prominently posted near the entrance. LPA reviewed five staff files (S1-S5) which were provided upon request.The staff files have the required background information and health screenings, criminal record clearances, staff qualifications, and mandated reporting acknowledgements. LPA also reviewed the facility's emergency disaster plan. LPA conducted a review of five client files (C1-C5), which were also provided upon request. All client files reviewed contained the signed admission agreement and discharge policies, as well as signed and up-to-date Needs and Services Plans. LPA observed that C2 did not have a written medical assessment within thirty days of entering the program, but record of the case worker's attempts to facilitate the assessment are documented in the client's file. Based on observations made during the inspection, there were no deficiencies cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted with Verenna Huerta, Administrator and a signed copy of this report was provided.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christopher Rollins conducted an unannounced follow up case management inspection at Stability Through Enhanced Peer Support (S.T.E.P.S.) administration office and met with Larry Hickman Administrator. The purpose of inspection is to deliver the case management investigation findings of the reported death of non minor dependent participant on 02/26/21. During the course of the investigation, LPA conducted confidential interviews with staff, social workers, clients and reviewed documentation that was submitted to LPA. Confidential Interviews conducted and documentation reveal a lack of supervision/neglect by program staff to protect the health & safety of the participants in the program care. Confidential Interviews and documentation reveal that program staff were aware of ongoing issues that were happening at the apartment complex which resulted in the death of a non-minor dependent participant in care. Based on confidential interviews and documentation there was enough evidence to prove that there was a Lack of Supervision/Neglect when it came to staff protecting participants in care safety needs which also violates the participants personal rights. Based on the information obtained during this investigation; there is a preponderance of evidence to prove that there was a Lack of Supervision/Neglect when it came to staff protecting participants in care safety needs and a violation of participants personal rights. Exit interview was conducted with Administrator and the program was cited under California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Sections Personal Rights and Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. Appeal Rights were provided and deficiencies were cited. A copy of the report was left at the facility with Administrator.

narrative: day notice. In addition, (P1's) authorized representative and attorney requested a written notice from (S1) on several occasions. However, the facility failed to submit it and did not obtain a copy to LPA Mendoza upon request. LPA Mendoza obtained a copy of the facilities agreement around termination from the program and reviewed the facilities program statement. The facility failed to follow its policies around discharge and removals. Furthermore, the facility did not arrange a CFT meeting with (P1) and (P1's) authorized representatives. On allegation, the facility did not provide (P1) infant supplementation. Based on confidential interviews and documentation. The facility received several checks from the county. Unfortunately, the facility cashed the checks without knowing what the money was or to whom the money was owed too. In addition, the facility was unable to provide the exact figure to (P1). Due to the facility's negligence, (P1) hired an attorney and was able to get the facility to pay (P1) a total of $3,483.00 for (P1's) infant supplementation from August 2021 to December 2021. Based on the information obtained, there is a preponderance of the evidence to prove, (P1) was illegally evicted and the facility did not provide NMD's infant supplementation. Therefore, the above allegation is substantiated. Appeal Rights were provided and discussed with the facility, and deficiencies were cited and a copy of the report was left with the licensee.

narrative: On 4/24/2023 at 12:45PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Selena Hood conducted a visit to the office of the above agency. On 4/24/2023, Community Care Licensing (CCL) was informed that an 18 year old resident of the facility had died by shooting on 4/23/2023 in Richmond, California. LPA met with Claudia Nelson, Program Manager. LPA collected copies of the Transitional Independent Living Plan and Needs and Services Plan for the resident. LPA discussed the details of the incident and the who had reported the incident with Program Manager (see LIC812). The resident's probation officer and biological mother have been informed. The facility has begun informing other residents in the home. Program Manager is checking in with the other residents and offering grief counseling today, 4/24/2023. The facility is also working with the resident's mother to receive their belongings. LPA conducted an exit interview with Claudia Nelson, Program Manager at 1:01PM. Facility will provide the incident report when they have been granted more information about the location and circumstances of the incident.

met_with: Isela Sahagun, Case Worker/ Social Worker
investigation_findings: 13On 4-17-24 10:47AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) George Karkazis made and unannounced inspection at Stability Through Enhanced Peer Support (STEPS), and met with Isela Sahagun, Case Worker/ Social Worker. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above allegations. The investigation was conducted by Community Care Licensing (CCL) Investigation Branch (IB), Investigator Blake Williams. The complaint alleged that staff did not prevent a minor from sustaining a burn while in care, and staff did not prevent a client from being attacked while in care. During the course of the investigation, IB conducted confidential interviews with staff, clients, witnesses, and authorized representatives. IB obtained documentation, police reports, medical records, facility records and communication records. Confidential interviews and document research conducted provided conflicting information. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the allegations occurred. Therefore, the allegations are UNSUBSTANTIATED. A Technical Assistance was issued. A copy of this report was given to Isela Sahagun, Case Worker/ Social Worker. UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) George Karkazis made an unannounced required Annual inspection to Stability Through Enhanced Peer Support (STEPS). LPA met with Claudia Nelson, Program Manager. The Transitional Housing Placement Plus Foster Care program (THP-FC) services non-minors dependents. At 1:10PM, LPA did a walk through inspection with Claudia Nelson, Program Manager of the office. The office has sufficient space for confidential meetings, all participant files and staff files are located in a locked cabinet in the front office. The agency has their license posted in their office. The office is in compliance with Community Care Licensing (CCL) regulations. LPA spoke with Claudia Nelson, Program Manager about the residential units. Claudia Nelson, Program Manager stated that all residential units have at least one toilet, sink and tub in working order. Claudia Nelson, Program Manager stated that all disinfectants and cleaning supplies are locked up and inaccessible. Claudia Nelson, Program Manager notified LPA that the program provides all participants with household essentials and that there are no weapons or firearms stored in the housing units. At 11:15AM, LPA reviewed 5 participants files and 4 staff files. There are a total of 4 employees in this office. LPA observed all Participants files to be complete and found no deficiencies. All documents are complete and up to date. LPA observed staff files to be complete, all documentation is up to date and all staff training were up to date/current. During inspection, LPA requested a updated copy of the LIC Personnel Report, LIC Disaster Plan, and LIC Administration Organization, to maintain their file current. All staff are fingerprint cleared. Per Title Regulations, no deficiencies were cited during this inspection. Exit interview conducted and a copy of the report was given to Claudia Nelson.

This agency serves as a 726 - Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP). LPA Singh-Sood explained that the purpose of the inspection was to conduct a Case Management as a follow up to the incident that occurred on 12/20/2020 at THPP unit 3. On January 25, 2021, LPA Carolyn Flynn conducted an unannounced inspection at the facility. Additionally, LPA Flynn requested copies of the involved client's file (assessment, admission paperwork, case plan, incident reports, and medication list), AWOL log for client, copy of the staff schedule, staff training tracker logs - certificates in binder in office, staff contact information, Google note from staff that conducted check at 5: PM on 12/20/20, Incident Report that they sent to the County with more details, Certificates of Approval for each of the four units, residents of the unit and their contact information. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shikya Belfield made an unannounced case management inspection to the above facility on 7/6/2022 at 4:00PM. LPA Belfield met with Program Administrator Vicky Taylor, who assisted with the inspection. The purpose for this case management inspection is to obtain information regarding an incident involving a non-client death( see LIC811 dated 7/6/2022) that occurred at the Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) residential apartment. On July 2, 2022, facility staff emailed this LPA and informed the department that a death occurred of a 16-year-old female guest of a participant in the THPP, who passed away due to an overdose. Program case manager went to the participant's apartment on July 1, 2022, and met with the participant regarding their visitor policy and following the rules of the program. On July 2, 2022 the THPP staff reviewed surveillance camera footage displaying firefighters arriving to the apartment unit for the participants. A third party notified law enforcement. The participant left the apartment. At 1: PM a parent (mother) arrived at the apartment and stated that her daughter was inside (second guest of the participant). Staff looked in the apartment and found the youth in another participants bedroom. Due to her being pale and her lips were blue in color, staff contacted law enforcement and the youth was taken to the hospital. Participant returned to the apartment and was met by the staff to check in. Participant was discharged from the program on 7/5/2022. Follow up: Case manager checked in with the remaining clients in the unit. A plan is in place to increase the checks being done on the apartments. Participants have not requested any services, however a plan is in place to follow up again by 7/7/2022 with participants regarding counseling services and other resources available. Due to other friends of the participant having the codes to access to the apartment and these friends entering the apartment without permission, the locks have been changed and additional cameras were installed in the outside common areas. Administrator Vicky Taylor states that Incident Reports will be submitted by Friday 7/8/2022 or no later than Monday 7/11/2022 regarding the incident. There were not citations issued. An exit interview was conducted a copy of this report will be sent to administrator Vicky Taylor.
