Licensing Program Manager Angela King and Licensing Program Analyst Michelle Kyane conducted a case management inspection on October 20, 2022 at 11:20AM, based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 7 out of Direct Care Staff and 8 out of 18 youth files were reviewed. 1 out of Direct Care Staff and 2 out of 18 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated October 20, 2022. The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments,THPP Interview Questions, and safety plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPM Angela King observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their emergency intervention plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Christina Faraone Transitional Aged Youth Program Coordinator.

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Paul Simien made an unannounced visit to the above listed facility main office to inform them of the findings for the above listed allegations. LPA met with Vicky Taylor, Administrator at 2: PM on 7/29/24. Based on confidential interviews conducted it was determined that the allegations listed above are Substantiated. Witnesses interviewed stated that during the summers their apartments too hot. Although, their apartments have a through-the-wall AC, it only cools one area of the apartment and doesn't reach clients' rooms. Witnesses stated that they are unable to sleep in their rooms at night because it was too hot. One witness stated that their apartment gets up to 95 degrees during the day. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be SUBSTANTIATED. As a result of this visit, there is one General Licensing Standards violation ( Furniture, Fixtures, Equipment, and Supplies(a)(1))The facility will be cited (see 809-Ds for details). Appeal rights were discussed and provided. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was emailed to Vicky Taylor, Administrator. SubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

On today's date, at 3: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Singh-Sood made an unannounced Case Management inspection regarding a serious incident to the above facility. LPA Singh-Sood met with Administrator, Vicky Taylor, who assisted with the inspection. The purpose of this inspection was to close an open incident investigation. The investigation was conducted by reviewing confidential documents, Title Regulations, the Facility's Program Statement, Plan of Operation, and interviewing confidential witnesses. This LPA also attempted to obtain the Police Report, and Coroner's Report, which were not available at this time. It is noted that during this serious incident, an emergency discharge had occurred due to a Participant's arrest. According to Title 22 regulations, subsequently following an immediate discharge in an emergency circumstance, which includes but is not limited to, removal by law enforcement officer(s), when a participant is arrested or when the participant in the home is endangered by their continued presence in the home, immediate removal of a participant is allowed as to ensure the safety of other participants in care. Additionally, according to Title Regulation, 86168,4(d)(1)(A) THPP personnel shall not prevent the removal of the participant from the THPP participant living unit under emergency circumstances by an authorized representative. Facility staff followed all protocols as indicated in their Plan of Operation, and Program Statement. Participants in care are required to sign an admission document which does outline immediate discharge is allowable for participants in care if the situation arises. Moreover, facility staff scheduled an emergency providers' meeting with the Participant's Social Worker, mutually agreeing to discharge the Participant in care who had been taken into custody, as for the safety of other participants in care. Upon the Participant's release from custody, where no one had been given confirmation the day of the release, the Participant had arrived on site at approximately 10: PM. The Participant was advised of the discharge, allowed to go to his room, gather anything pertinent, and return the following day for his remaining belongings. The Participant agreed to do so and advised his former facility Case Manager (CM) he would be going to a family members home, whom the CM was familiar with, as well as the location of the home. The Participant typically took public transportation, which was still within operating hours, so the C/M did not have any concern with the Participant leaving the premises on his own. Due to all protocols being followed by facility staff, the facility providing all necessary documentation which included incident reports, reporting the incident in a timely manner, scheduling a team meeting with the Social Worker, agreeably deciding to discharge the Participant, following the guidelines of Title Regulations, as well as STAR THPP's Plan of Operation, CCL will not be issuing a citation for this incident as there were no Title Regulations which were violated. As such, an exit interview was conducted Ms. Taylor at 4: PM, and a copy of this report concluding this incident was provided.

Licensing Program Analyst Brian Bertoli conducted an unannounced inspection to the THPP/THP+FC Administrative office to conduct an Annual/Required inspection. LPA met with Administrative Assistant Casha Cory and was joined later by Housing Director Vanessa Guevara. The THPP has a capacity of 60 and service both THPP and THPP+FC participants and THPP Plus contracted through the County. There are currently 27 participants in care (Three minors and NMDs). The facility uses a scattered site model and currently has both host homes and apartment units. LPA reviewed six Certificate of Compliances and they were valid. LPA inspected the THPP office, which has two stories and a basement. The first floor has a reception area, open meeting room, kitchen/lunch room, and restroom. The second floor has private offices and a restroom, and the basement has private meeting spaces. The license and Emergency Disaster Plan (LIC610C) forms are posted. LPA's reviewed participant records - three minor files and three Non-Minor Dependents. All participant files are acceptable. Staff records are maintained at the TLC administrative office on Gravenstein Hwy North in Sebastopol. Facility was able to coordinate with Human Resources Manager Amanda Atkinson to acquire staff records promptly electronically. A review of Licensing Information System on June 16, 2021, indicates that all facility staff associated to the facility had DOJ, FBI and child abuse index check clearances. During inspection, LPA's reviewed three staff files and all files were complete and had all required documents and required training. There were no Title 22 deficiencies cited during todays inspection. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report was left at the facility .

investigation_findings: 13On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brian Bertoli met with Assistant Program Director Nancy Campbell and Housing Director Vanessa Guevara at the facility office. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. During the course of the investigation, the LPA reviewed records and conducted confidential interviews. It was confirmed that the Resident Advisor was intoxicated in the home, made inappropriate comments, made the residents uncomfortable, offered residents illegal substances, and showed inappropriate photos to residents. Based on the information obtained, there is a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the Resident Advisor did not ensure that residents were able to live in a safe, healthy, and comfortable home. Therefore, the above allegations are substantiated. Title 22 deficiencies were cited and Appeal Rights were provided and discussed. Advisory Notes were issued. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report was given to the facility. SubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion: 0

narrative: On the above date Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brian Bertoli conducted an unannounced inspection at the facility and met with Casha Cory, Resource Center Manager in person and Nancy Campbell, PsyD (see LIC 812 dated 4/5/24) by phone regarding two Special Incident Reports (SIRs) that were submitted to Community Care Licensing. The first incident took place on 04/03/2024 and the SIR was written to report an incident regarding the participant being arrested for domestic battery on her boyfriend. The second incident was on 4/2/24 and was for a participant being arrested for possession of narcotics, firearms, ammunition, and controlled substances. LPA Bertoli discussed the incident with Dr Campbell. In the course of reviewing the incident, the Administrator stated that they were still reviewing the incidents and would share whatever information became available. LPA Bertoli will order police reports on the incidents and review further details with the facility. Nancy Campbell inquired about Law Enforcement Contacts being reported even when they are incidental occurrences not requested by the facility. LPA Bertoli stated that all contacts need to be reported regardless of the initial source. LPA Bertoli also reviewed the 24-hr or next business day notification requirement for incident reports. This section was not discussed at the previous meeting with Administrator Shelby Means, but will be adhered to by the facility. No deficiencies were cited and an exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report was provided to the facility.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shikya Belfield conducted a change of location inspection with the new facility office. LPA met with administrator Meg Clark who assist with the tour of the office. The purpose of this Pre-licensing inspection is due to the change of location, the previous location was Ocean St Suite B Santa Cruz Ca 95060. The new location is now located at Encinal St, Suite 200, Santa Cruz Ca 95060. This program a Transitional Housing Placement Program(THPP). The program is licensed to provide services and Transitional Housing Placement plus Foster care ( THPP+FC) services to Non-Minor Dependents. The new office location was toured and the following areas were observed: - Reception Area was observed with the proper guidelines being followed regarding the pandemic with the following; plastic dividers / separators placed on the counter tops, masks are worn inside, signs are posted with emergency exists and floor plans on every doorway. Administrator states that all protocols for COVID are in place including taking temperature of all who enter and recording it. - Offices spaces; Due to the Pandemic, there are no private offices spaces and there are three private conference rooms that are available for use upon scheduling. - Storage: Client files are kept double locked by key box and the file cabinets are stored in the main office area in the center of building. No clients enter in this area unless absolutely necessary. There are no work stations for staff at this location and all files are kept locked. - Conference Rooms / Board Rooms: meetings are located at Encinal St, Suite 200, Santa Cruz Ca, 95060. This location has adequate space to conduct meetings and training's. - Office floor space/ plan has sufficient space for the staff, file cabinets and desks / works stations. There are three bathrooms. First aid supplies are located nest to the file cabinets in the main building. There are two fire extinguishers at this location and both are currently out of date and need to be serviced ( expiration dates are April 2020). Administrator Clark states they will schedule the servicing of the new fire extinguishers or purchase new extinguishers as soon as possible and will send photographs to this LPA. Upon receipt of this information the inspection shall be complete. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report will be sent to Administrator Meg Clark.

On February 7, 2024, at 9: AM, Licensing Program Analyst's (LPA's) Darlene Almaraz-Oseguera and Emina Preciado arrived at Trident Living, Transitional Housing Placing Program (THPP). LPAs met with, Facility Administrator, Monique Bautista. The purpose of the visit was to conduct a pre-licensing inspection of the facility. LPAs did a tour of the facility with Monique Bautista for a pre-license of a Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) for Non-Minor Dependents (NMD). There are four bedrooms, four bathrooms, and one office. LPAs observed two living rooms furnished with couches and chairs. The common areas for residents are the kitchen, two sitting areas, a living room with ample sitting space, television, and a fireplace with proper coverings for safety. There is ample parking for residents and staff. The facility has Wi-Fi accessibility. Downstairs: The administrative office is located downstairs. The office is equipped with a desk, a locked file cabinet, and a printer/scanner. Client and personnel records will be kept electronically, and physical copies will be stored and available for review at the administrative office. The administrative office is in the process of being relocated. Upstairs: Four bedrooms and three bathrooms. LPAs observed there are clean mattresses, linens, pillows, and beds in good repair. The participant bedrooms have locks placed on the bedroom doors and each participant will have their own key to their room. The administrator will keep a master key in case of emergencies. The windows had shutters for privacy. The laundry room is equipped with a washer and dryer. The facility outside grounds were also inspected and it was observed to be clean and well maintained. LPAs observed an underground pool and spa. * LIC 809-C* During the inspection the following was discussed: During the meeting component II and component III were discussed. LPA's discussed Post Licensing visits that Community Care Licensing (CCL) may provide, solutions to problematic areas, overview of Title 22, THPP regulations, personal fingerprint requirements, abuse reporting requirements, and licensing fees. LPAs communicated about LPA's responsibility; Special Incident reporting requirements, for LIC624, CC: internal procedures, AB388 reporting form 624LE. The facility will be notified once they are provisionally licensed as a THPP/NMD facility. The license will expire one year from effective date. Facility will be licensed for a capacity of 4 participants. Facility accepts only ambulatory clients. It was discussed that the administrative office is in the process of being relocated to be utilized for storage of pertinent records, staff trainings, and meetings with participants; As well as the possibility of future expansion for the facility license as stated in the program statement. LPA provided applicant with a copy of the special incident report and provided applicant the email address and directions on reporting incidents to Community Care Licensing, Riverside North office. The certificates of compliance will also be submitted to LPA. After a final file review, the facility will be submitted for licensure. Exit interview conducted a copy of this report was provided to Licensee.

met_with: Regional Program Manager Dyese Hunt, Compliance Director Deb Miller
narrative: On 11/09/2020, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins met with Regional Program Manager Dyese Hunt and Compliance Director Deb Miller for a case management visit to discuss the THPP program model and supervision and to provide technical assistance. Due to COVID-19 social distancing orders, this visit was conducted as a tele-visit. The THPP plan of operation was approved with a nonstandard THPP model. Due to a history of incidents that pose a risk to the residents, including frequent AWOLs, staff misconduct, youth possession of weapons, youth overmedicating psychotropic medication, and compliance concerns regarding lack of required documentation for case plans and medication administration, LPA Hawkins is advising that the THPP review the following regulation sections. Per Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. Per Definitions Health and Safety Code Section 1559.110(d) The sections were read in full to Dyese and Deb and discussed. A technical assistance was provided to Dyese and Deb, which provided in writing the above sections. LPA requests that if any program updates are made the revised sections and policies are submitted to CCL for approval. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report left with Regional Program Manager Dyese Hunt and Compliance Director Deb Miller, who agreed to sign the report emailed by LPA Hawkins and return a signed copy to LPA.

met_with: Regional Program Manager Dyese Hunt, Compliance Director Deb Miller
narrative: R2 has a known history of being prescribed psychotropic medication but was not currently prescribed to any. R1 was prescribed three psychotropic medications and two other medications. Licensee has no documentation from R1's doctor stating in writing that the minor is able to self-administer medications. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and therefore the above allegations are found to be Substantiated. The facility is being cited per California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section Health Related Services. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report left with Regional Program Manager Dyese Hunt and Compliance Director Deb Miller, who agreed to sign the report emailed by LPA Hawkins and return a signed copy to LPA. The youths appeared to be playing but were using the weapons in a menacing way, pretending to target another resident by aiming the gun at them and making repeated stabbing motions with the knife. Licensee confiscated the dangerous items once it was learned through the camera feed that the residents had them. The security camera feed was viewed from the THPP office. The house model is a remote site with scheduled staff check-ins, because the staff do not reside in the house and provide supervision. While increased supervision may have provided greater safety to the residents, it is still possible that the youths could have hidden the items in the house and brought them out while staff was away, as there is no specific stipulation for 24-hour supervision in THPPs. Therefore, it is unclear that a lack of supervision resulted in the youths having access to weapons. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, based on LPA's observations and interviews with residents and staff, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violation(s) did or did not occur. Therefore, the allegation is Unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report left with Regional Program Manager Dyese Hunt and Compliance Director Deb Miller, who agreed to sign the report emailed by LPA Hawkins and return a signed copy to LPA.
investigation_findings: 13On Monday 11/09/20 at 10AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a visit to deliver findings of a complaint investigation of the above allegation(s). LPA met with Regional Program Manager Dyese Hunt and Compliance Director Deb Miller. Due to COVID-19 social distancing orders, this visit was scheduled as a tele-visit. During the investigation, LPA Hawkins conducted confidential interviews with program staff and resident. Based on confidential interviews, minor participant R1 (See LIC Confidential Names) was self-administering his prescribed psychotropic medication. R1 also informed staff that he was overmedicating, and staff observed the resident to be unstable and have frequent hallucinations and nightmares and talk frequently about conspiracy theories involving feared persons. R1 reported to staff that he was overmedicating due to fear of another resident, R2, who was known to have weapons, as a month prior to the incident in question, R2 was observed on security cameras in the house brandishing a knife with another youth with an airsoft gun. SubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

narrative: However, Unity Care did not develop a needs and services plan with input from the case worker(s) or previous case plans. The needs and services plan submitted to LPA was marked the admission copy and dated 4/16/20, which is after the date LPA Isabel Mendoza conducted the initial visit and requested the plan on 4/9/20. The TILP was dated 2/18/20. Further, the plan listed R1's needs as "no needs...per the youth" for socialization, emotional support, and mental health support and "youth presents as highly functional." The only need identified is "weight management / physical fitness." Additionally, the plan was handwritten but did not include an authorized representative / case worker signature. R1 turned 18 twenty (20) days after admission to the program, but the needs and services was not developed until fifty-eight (58) days after admission. The plan only pulls from the youth's statements rather than considering the youth's case history, indicates no input or authorization from the case worker(s) or previous case worker(s), and is incomplete with few needs listed despite being drafted after video footage showed the incident at the center of this complaint. The THPP did not ensure that it was safe for youth to be placed in the remote site with little supervision by not assessing the youth's needs at placement nor within the mandated timeframe. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and therefore the above allegations are found to be Substantiated. The facility is being cited per California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 86068.2(a) Needs and Services and Transitional Independent Living Plan. See Section 86068.2(c), which requires needs and services plans to be completed within 30 calendar days from the date of placement. Because R1 turned age 18, LPA advises the facility to review Sections 86168.1(c) and 86168.3(f) as well. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report left with Regional Program Manager Dyese Hunt and Compliance Director Deb Miller, who agreed to sign the report emailed by LPA Hawkins and return a signed copy to LPA. Therefore, it is unclear that a lack of supervision resulted in the youths having access to weapons. The facility has since hired an on-site staff to provide support and supervision. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, based on LPA's observations and interviews with residents and staff, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violation(s) did or did not occur. Therefore, the allegation is Unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report left with Regional Program Manager Dyese Hunt and Compliance Director Deb Miller, who agreed to sign the report emailed by LPA Hawkins and return a signed copy to LPA.

During the investigation, LPA Hawkins conducted confidential interviews with program staff and resident. Based on interviews and camera footage, residents R1 and R2 (See LIC Confidential Names) were upstairs in their remote site house playing with an airsoft gun and a knife while another resident did not engage. R1 was 'play-threatening' a youth in their room, and R2 was 'play-stabbing' the knife, both to be 'playfully menacing.' R1 was placed in the program as a minor but was age 18 at the time of the incident. R2 was 17. The house model is a remote site with scheduled staff check-ins, and no staff reside in the house and provide supervision. met_with: Deb Miller (Complaince Director), Dyese Hunt (Program Manager), Picha Watkins (Director of Operation), Kenya Kennedy (Interim Program Manager)
narrative: On 11/24/020, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Isabel Mendoza and (LPA) Britanee Windom from AB388/Law Enforcement review unit met with Regional Program Manager Dyese Hunt, Compliance Director ,Deb Miller, Director of Operations, Picah Watkins, Interim Program Manager, Kenya Kennedy for a case management visit to discuss incident reports, reporting requirements, law enforcement contact, and AB 388 requirements. Due to COVID-19 social distancing orders, this visit was conducted as a tele-visit. On 11/12/ LPA contacted the facility regarding the following SIRs that need to be transferred on LIC 624LE. Total of SIRs. The following SIRs regarding the following participants (please refer to LIC 811 for confidential names, dated 11/24/20): (C1) 4/18/20, 4/19/20, 4/20/20. (C2) 4/21/20. (C3) 4/22/20. (C4) 4/22/20 and 08/11/20. (C5) 04/28/20, (C7) 4/30/20 and 5/13/20, 5/16/20 (C6) 5/2/20 (C8), 8/11/20, and C9 08/11/20. All incident reports were submitted on LIC 624, but need to be completed on LIC624LE. LPA's requested the facility to transfer these incidents on LIC 624LE, because there was law enforcement contact. Also, LPA has not received a follow-up on any of these incident reports, and is requesting a follow-up incident report. On (C4) incident dated 4/22/20, incident report is lacking information. The incident report does not include antecedents that lead up to the incident. LPA needs more details on this incident report. If the facility is unable to obtain this information, because resident is gone, or staff member is no longer working with the agency. LPA advised the facility to include this information in the SIR. Also, LPA found incident report for (C7) with date occurred 2/13/20, and body of incident report date is 05/13/20. LPA asked what the correct date is and also asked the facility to update the incident report because the report is lacking detail. (C7) did not return to the facility by their 10pm curfew, and missing awol report was completed. SIR also was documented on LIC 624 and not LIC 624LE. LPA Mendoza requested the facility to include more specific information, if the facility contacted (C7), when was the last time they spoke to (C7) and where was the (C7) last whereabouts. The facility confirmed incident occurred on 05/13/20, and it was a typo. The facility will submit all updated SIRs to LPA no later than 12/15/20. During meeting, LPA Mendoza and LPA Windom informed the facility the importance of documenting all incident reports on its appropriate incident report form. LIC 624 or LIC 624LE. If there is any law enforcement contact the facility needs to complete LIC 624LE. All LIC 624LE are forwarded to AB388 unit for review. LPA Windom explained what her role is within the AB388 unit and the importance of following AB388 regulations and submitting LIC 624LE. In addition, LPA's gave specific details on how to write an appropriate incident report. Compliance Director asked LPA's if they had a perfect sample incident report (LIC 624 or LIC 624LE) that they could share with the facility. LPA Windom will reach out to her manager and see if LPA can share one. LPA Mendoza will also look for some and share with the facility by end of day tomorrow 11/25/20. The facility will continue working with all staff members and monitoring all incident reports and ensuring that they are following all reporting requirements and AB 388 requirements. Exit interview was conducted and report was emailed to Compliance Diretor (Deb Miller) for signature. No deficiencies cited during todays inspection.

On 06/10/21 at 3: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Isabel Mendoza made a case management visit for deficiencies discovered during LPA Mendoza investigation for Complaint Control#114-CR-20210302161119. LPA met with Administrator Dyese Hunt regarding the below items: 1. On 03/26/ LPA Mendoza requested copies of ( P1's and P2's) [please refer to LIC 811,dated 06/10/21 for confidential names] Needs and Service Plan and Transitional Independent Living Plan (TILP). The facility did not have Needs and Service for (P1) or (P2) or TILP for (P2). Also, the facility had no documentation of the facility requesting TILP from authorized representatives. 2. Based on interviews and documentation the facility conducted room searches on 2/3/21 and 2/4/21 at Foster City remote site because facility staff received information the night before that participants were doing drugs inside home. On 2/4/ Administrator, Dyese Allen and Case Manager, Frank Delgado conducted a room search and found illegal substances and other drug paraphernalia in (P1's) bedroom. The facility transported these items to Foster City Police Department. The facility failed to contact Community Care Licensing of this incident within 24 hours. During inspection, Administrator Dyese informed LPA Mendoza that they contacted CCL's Desk Duty Line however they were not able to leave a voicemail. LPA advised the facility if this happens again the facility needs to contact LPA Mendoza and report critical incident. [ Please refer to LIC 809-C for cont.] 3. Based on confidential interviews and documentation (P1) stole two driver licenses and a social security card from a couple. Images were sent to Case Manager, (S1) on 2/3/21 and (S1) failed to report this to their supervisor, Community Care Licensing and (P1's) authorized representative. Also, (S1) received specific dates back in January when participants (P1-P3) were doing drugs and (S1) did not do anything about it. The facility will be cited under California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 86168.3(b) Needs and Service Plan, Section 86161(b)(4) Reporting Requirements, and 86172(b) Personal Rights. An exit interview was conducted and copy of the report and appeal rights were provided to Administrator.

met_with: Frank Delgado- Interim Lead Case Manager & Deb Miller, Compliance Director
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Isabel Mendoza made an unannounced required Annual inspection to Unity Care's Administrative office. LPA met with Interim Lead Case Manager, Frank Delgado, and Deb Miller, Compliance Director arrived later during the inspection. This agency provides services to Minors and Non-Minor Dependents, licensed for 43 participants and currently have a census of 22 participants- (1) minor and (21) NMD's. At 9: AM, LPA inspected the premises, and did a walk through inspection with Case Manager, Frank. The office has sufficient space for confidential meetings. The facility only had 8 participant files in a locked cabinet in a secure location. All other participant files are being kept at each remote site. The agency has their license posted in their office. LPA spoke with Case Manager about the residential units, and obtained copies of all Certificate of Compliances. The facility currently has 4 sites. Compliance Director confirmed that all residential units have at least one toilet, sink and tub in working order. At 10: AM, LPA reviewed 3 participants files. LPA could not locate Needs and Service Plans for(C2 and (C3), (please refer to LIC 811, dated 09/08/21 for confidential names). The facility did not have personnel staff files or staff training at administrative office. LPA reminded the facility that all personnel records shall be at the administrative building. The Case Manager attempted to contact Human Resources but there was no response. All personnel files are stored electronically, and only HR has access. The facility informed LPA Mendoza that they will now request copies of all required documents and will start keeping them on file. During inspection, Case Manager located one staff file for (S1), however the file was incomplete and did not have all required documents. (Please Cont. To Lic 809-c) The facility informed LPA Mendoza, that they have found former Administrator replacement. The new Administrator will start on 9/16/21. Former Administrator, Dyese Hunt resigned, and her last day was on 8/30/21. The facility agrees to submit all LIC documents and letter from the board, no later than Friday 9/24/21. During inspection, LPA obtained copies of LIC 610, current client roster, and LIC 500. LPA Mendoza requested the facility to submit an updated LIC 309 (Administrative of Organization) later than Friday 9/17/21. The facility has been cited under Title Regulations, and a copy of the report was left with Compliance Director.

narrative: unauthorized absences, per the consumer notes, which were not reported to Licensing, and which could not be confirmed as reported to the authorized representative due to lack of submission of written report: 3/3/21-3/4/21, 3/20/21-3/31/21, 4/25/21- 4/26/21, 4/28/21- 5/3/21, 5/4/21, 5/18/21 -5/19/21, 5/29/21, 5/31/21, 06/01/21. In addition, interviews and documented submitted to LPA indicated that the facility did not maintain in C1's file C1's valid work permit or work schedule, and authorized representative was not able to confirm C1's employment. Also, when C1 would leave on unauthorized absences, staff would check in on C1 via text, and C1 would check in with staff via phone or by text. However, on-site supervising staff did not always directly notify C1's case manager of unauthorized absences the night priors or authorized representative. It was reported that the facility would allow C1 to leave without a pass or authorization from authorized representative due to feeling that C1 was working hard at work and school. Per authorized representative, when they spoke to the school, they learned that C1 was failing their classes. LPA obtained a copy of (C1) school transcripts, report cards, and this was confirmed to be true. Also, obtained a copy of (C1) progress report from March and (C1) had a total of 9 unexplained absences from 02/22/2021 to 03/16/21. Based on the information obtained, there is a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the facility staff allowed the minor to AWOL, staff did not notify the minors authorized representative of the AWOLs, staff not meeting clients' needs, and staff not checking in on minors. Therefore, the above allegation is substantiated. Appeal Rights were provided and discussed with the facility and deficiencies were cited. Exit interview conducted and a copy of the report was left with the facility.

narrative: On Thursday, March 24, 2022, at PM, Community Care Licensing (CCL) conducted an office meeting virtually via Microsoft Teams. The following individuals attended the Teams meeting: Licensing Program Managers (LPMs) Carolyn Flynn, Helga Wong, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA's) Isabel Mendoza, Vaishali Singh-Sood, Jennifer Baca, Tamara Hill, and Mary Shelton. In addition, CCL met with Deb Miller, Alexander William, Sander Trent, and Frank Delgado. This meeting aimed to discuss the "SF Resident Deduction" sheet that LPA Mendoza observed posted in one of the THPP's remote sites on 2/14/22. Unfortunately, our department has not approved the deduction sheet. After further discussion with LPM Jodean Hall, LPA Hill informed the facility the above deduction sheet was not approved or included in the facilities revised program statement which is under review. CCL informed the facility that it was determined that the listed items in the SF deduction sheet were all violations of the client's Personal Rights. All parties on the call agreed that CCL would not accept this, and the facility will no longer use the above deduction sheet. Currently, the facility is working on their final revisions for all three THPP sites out of the Sacramento office. Once the program statement has been approved, the facility will submit a hard copy and an electronic copy to the San Jose regional office (SB and SJ). An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report was emailed to Deb Miller for signature.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Britanee Windom and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Angela King conducted a case management inspection on September 27, 2022 at 10: AM based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 7 out of Direct Care Staff and 6 out of 7 youth files were reviewed. 2 out of Direct Care Staff and 3 out of 7 youth were interviewed.(See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, September 27, 2022). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the Transitional Independent Living Plan & Agreements and Safety Plans, the licensee uses trauma informed and evidence based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Windom and LPM King observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their policies and procedures when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to THP Program Manager Frank Delgado and Director of Compliance Deb Miller.

met_with: Program Manager Frank Delgado; Director of Compliance Deb Miller
narrative: On 1/6/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility office for a case management visit. LPA met with Program Manager Frank Delgado and Director of Compliance Deb Miller and informed of the purpose of the visit. The purpose of the visit was to meet to discuss recently submitted incident reports regarding a participant bringing dangerous contraband on the grounds and engaging in inappropriate activities, and a participant permitting a disallowed guest on the grounds. LPA obtained additional information about the incidents from Deb and Frank and obtained resident documentation and case worker information. No deficiencies have been found during this visit. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with Program Manager Frank Delgado, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 8/16/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a required annual inspection at the facility office. LPA met with Regional Director Jeffrey Jefferson and informed of the purpose of the visit. LPA reviewed personnel and resident records and toured two living units. The CARE Inspection Tool was used to complete this inspection. LPA observed the living units to be clean and organized with kitchen and bathrooms maintained in sanitary condition. The living units had postings of emergency plans and emergency numbers as well as grievance procedures. Certificates of compliance were maintained in facility records. Participants provided positive feedback in interviews. Staff are knowledgable, and personnel files reflected appropriate training. Participant files were complete, and case plans were current and up to date. No deficiencies were observed during today's inspection. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with Regional Director Jeffrey Jefferson, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 12/4/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a random annual inspection. LPA met with Program Manager Deandra Doyle and informed of the purpose of the visit. LPA observed the transitional housing placement program (THPP) office to house individual client files. Personnel files were made available on site. Some portions of the files were unavailable due to the HR director being out of the office. LPA obtained a current LIC 500 and verified all staff have a background clearance and eligible-to-work status. LPA observed client files to be complete with consent forms, transitional independent living plans and/or needs and services plans, admission agreements, personal rights, and rule agreements. Each housing unit has a valid certificate of compliance. During the visit, LPA obtained contact information for staff and clients in order to contact them for interviews. No interviews were conducted during the visit. A continuation visit will be conducted to complete the review of personnel files. No deficiencies were observed during today's inspection. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were discussed, and a copy of this report was left with Program Manager Deandra Doyle, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 8/5/25, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins visited the facility. The purpose of the visit was to discuss a submitted incident report. LPA met with Program Manager Deandra Doyle and informed of the purpose of the visit. LPA discussed the incident in question with Program Manager and obtained additional information pertinent to the incident. LPA requested that a copy of the current housing agreement form used by the program be sent to LPA by Friday 8/8/25. No deficiencies were observed, and a copy of this report was provided to Program Manager.

The purpose of this report is to correct the discrepancy with multiple facility numbers for Unity Care Group. The facility moved from one suite in the building located at Enterprise Way, to a suite with the address of Enterprise Way. The effective date of facility # 317006116 is 06/01/2020.

On 9/1/21 at 10: AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Tammy Hill and Robin Sullivan met with Deb Miller, Compliance Manager and Pam Carter, N. Cal Regional Program Director of Unity Care. The meeting was held on MS Teams to discuss a plan for the submittal of a new Program Statement (PS) and Plan of Operation (POO). Areas discussed include changes of site names which are now (1) staffed site, (2) host family, (3) Remote Site, certification from applicable county, uniformity of program, and update procedures for Program Statement. Unity Care will use a program statement review tool and the PS and POO table of contents as a guide for required content. Unity Care will provide the CCL Regional Offices in Sacramento, San Jose, and San Francisco a tabbed hard copy binder and an electronic version of the final approved PS/POO.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Robin Sullivan met with Pam Carter, Regional Program Director, on 8/8/21 at 11: AM to conduct a pre-license inspection for a relocation of the facility office. The office has four private offices, a private conference room, and a six unit multi-station work space. The office has an integrated fire alarm system connected to the building system. LPA observed client files are locked in a multi-drawer cabinet in the open office space. The employee files are stored in a locked cabinet inside the Regional Program Director's office. LPA discussed the single site locations with the Program Director and Program Supervisors. Locations with minors have overnight and live-in staff. LPA discussed the relocation process with Regional Program Director. It is required that CCL receive an LIC200 application and a relocation fee along with a Board of Director's Resolution approving the relocation prior to a physical move. The relocation occurred prior to CCL receiving the required notification. The facility is cited for violation of California Code of Regulations Title 22 Operation Without a License. A copy of this report will be left with the Regional Program Director. An exit interview was conducted.

narrative: A tele inspection meeting via Microsoft Teams was held on 10/22/21 at 1: PM and in attendance were individuals representing Community Care Licensing Division and Unity Care Group. The meeting was called for by Unity Care Group to discuss the facility and agency progress since the Non Compliance Conference meeting held on August 25, 2021. Community Care Licensing representatives included Margo Castaneda, Jodean Hall and Tamara Hill from the Sacramento Regional Office and Helga Wong and Zaid Hakim from the San Jose Regional Office. Unity Care Group representatives included Andre Chapman, Pam Carter, Deb Miller, Sharae Gary, Devin Johnson, Tai Batov and Lynn Thull (consultant for Unity Care Group). The purpose of the meeting is to establish a collaborative dialogue between Unity Care Group and Community Care Licensing in areas of concern and to discuss the status of plans for improvement for the success of the program moving forward. Items discussed included Unity Care's Internal Improvement Plan, Technical Support status, Reporting Requirements, Staffing and Supervision, Neighborhood Relationship Improvements, and Program Statement review. Discussed was that the Plan of Operation and Program Statement will be submitted to the Sacramento Regional Office via FedEx on November 5, 2021. Once the Plan of Operation and Program Statement is complete and finalized by the Sacramento Regional Office, it will be shared with the other regional offices. Exit interview was conducted with Deb Miller, Compliance, and the document was provided for signature and return.

On 12/13/21 at 3: PM Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Mary Shelton and Robin Sullivan conducted a case management inspection for the Non-compliance issues discussed on 8/11/21. The facility is complying with the following: (1)The facility will follow relocation procedures by notifying CCL in advance of a relocation. (2) The facility has submitted a Program Statement which is under review at this time. (3) The facility has conducted staff training for required incident reporting. All incidents involving law enforcement will be reported as required and authorized representatives will be notified along with CCL. (4) Facility will create a good neighbor policy. The facility has included a good neighbor policy which is included in the submitted Program Statement. Assigned LPA will continue to monitor the compliance of the above. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was emailed to the facility.

On 12/13/21 at 10: AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Mary Shelton and Robin Sullivan made an unannounced Post-licensing inspection at the facility's administrative office. LPAs met with Devon Johnson, Supervisor. This facility provides services to minors and non-minor dependents (NMD), is licensed for 74 participants and currently has a census of 33 participants. LPAs observed the office has four private rooms; one office is for the Regional Program Director, the two supervisor's share one office, one is the therapist's office, one is a large conference room used for meetings and trainings. A multi-compartment cubicle with space for four employees is located in the middle of the main office and two additional cubicles on the back wall. The office has a bathroom and kitchen facilities. LPAs observed the client files are stored in a locked file cabinet in the main office area. The employee files are stored in a locked file cabinet inside the Regional Program Director's office. LPAs observed the facility sketch, license and emergency disaster plan are posted. LPA observed the facility has posters regarding COVID-19 practices. LPAs observed Certificates of Compliance on file for the housing units. LPAs reviewed five client files and six employee files to have all required documents. No Title 22 deficiencies were cited. An exit interview was conducted and this report was emailed to Devon Johnson.

met_with: Devin Johnson, Supervisor and Deb Miller, Compliance Officer
narrative: (page 2) It is alleged that client funds are mismanaged. The investigation revealed that clients do not know how much their stipend payments will be until they receive the funds or the money is deposited in their account. The clients report the amount of payments are never the same which makes budgeting hard. The clients state they do not get an explanation or supporting documents showing what deductions are made or the date of the deduction. When LPA requested accounting documents for additional clients, with details on deductions, staff stated it would take while as they had to gather the data to create a spreadsheet each time a client statement was requested. LPA observed client stipend checks with "pay to the order of" in a staff's name and staff's address. Staff stated the checks are made payable to them until a client has a direct deposit set up. Staff cashes the check, gets the client's signature, and then gives the money to the client. Two clients and two county social workers reported money was withheld from emancipation funds after clients exited the program. Staff state that deductions for excessive cleaning or damages to the living units may be withheld from emancipation funds. The facility withholds $100 for non-minor dependents (NMD) and $50 for minors, per month, from their total monthly stipend amount. The facility Plan of Operation does not include a section on emancipation funds. The Plan of Operation does not describe how the facility will account for or handle funds held in a client emancipation account. Client housing agreements indicate deductions may be taken for infractions of the housing policies and cleaning fees may be withheld from an emancipation fund or the monthly stipend. It is alleged that the regional program director (RD) made derogatory remarks to a client. A Placer County Supervisor (PCS) stated that during a Child and Family Team (CFT) meeting the RD made several statements that escalated the youth. PCS stated RD was accusatory and hostile and the youth was escalated by this. PCS stated, "at one point (the youth) even called RD on her attitude saying she had been rude and disrespectful to others in the meeting by constantly interrupting and negating what they were saying." PCS intervened in the CFT meeting because RD said the youth put other residents at risk and was endangering their safety by leaving after curfew. PCS challenged the statement by RD because the other residents were non-minors without a curfew and therefore not at risk by a minor leaving. Two other participants confirm hearing RD speak in a demeaning manner and confirm the youth called RD out about being rude. A Placer County worker (PCW) stated that the lack of professionalism is troubling at best. PCW stated, "their lack of support is continued trauma and emotional upheaval for participants. There is long-term harm to the youth participating in the program." One facility staff and RD deny derogatory remarks were made. One CFT participant refused to speak on the matter. It is alleged that a minor was not provided supervision after a dental sedation procedure. The investigation revealed that a minor was sedated for a tooth extraction and bone graft procedures on 8/28/21. The minor was transported to and from the appointment by a Placer county worker. The facility did not make arrangements for adult supervision at the housing unit the day of the procedure. The regular live-in staff was on a scheduled vacation. Staff stated that the youth only had a tooth pulled and did not think sedation was necessary. A CFT meeting on 5/11/2021 indicates the need for a tooth extraction and bone grafting. CFT meeting notes from 8/11/2021 state dental needs still need to be addressed. (continued on p3) (page3) CSW stated that the minor had high anxiety leading up to the procedure and Unity Care was well informed of the date and the sedation. The facility offered to arrange a Lyft ride. CSW stated staff was reminded that minor would be fully sedated and could not take Lyft. CSW knew staff was on vacation but RD would get a fill-in. Staff knew that minor was struggling with serious mental health issues and had stopped taking medications prior to the dental procedure. The minor was left in the house with two other residents and an on-call phone number written on a white board. Minor stated they were in excruciating pain. Minor went to the refrigerator for something to eat and ended up throwing food and causing destruction all over the house. Help was called and it was determined that minor required hospitalization for a psych evaluation the evening of 8/28/21. Based on the information from interviews conducted and documents obtained the allegations, that client funds are mismanaged, Regional program director made derogatory remarks to a client, and a minor was not provided supervision after a dental sedation procedure, are substantiated. The facility is cited for California Code of Regulations Title 22, division 6, chapter 7, Transitional Housing Placement Program for Minor Foster Children and Non-Minor Dependents Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision and Personal Rights. Although the allegation that client funds are mismanaged is substantiated no citation is issued at this time due to a citation issued on 11/18/21 for this violation. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and appeal rights discussed and will be emailed to Mr. Johnson and Ms. Miller.

During the investigation LPA interviewed three clients, two Placer County Children's System of Care managers, two Placer county social workers (CSW), 2 facility staff and the regional program director between 8/30/21 and 12/09/21. met_with: Devon Johnson, Supervisor and Deb Miller, Compliance Officer
narrative: It is alleged that a client's needs and services are not met. The investigation revealed that clients are offered therapeutic services once per week or more often if determined necessary. According to a confidential interview the client was participating in therapy and then stopped going. It was stated that the client withdrew from facility workers which made providing additional services challenging. The client's case manager stated the client refused in-house therapy and refused to participate when another option was scheduled. Case manager stated that the client was a no show for their weekly meetings 75% of the time. Client did not participate in monthly Independent Living Skills. Client refused to complete a dental appointment due to provider not offering nitrous oxide. Placer County authorized dental sedation however the facility was unable to support a Saturday appointment. It is alleged that incident reports are not sent to authorized representatives. One social worker reports only receiving incident reports on a client after a 14-day notice to move the client was submitted. One social worker stated getting phone calls and emails from the case manager if there are concerns about a client but did not get regular written reports. Case managers state that staff are trained to write reports when an incident occurs while they are on shift or when they are notified of a situation. The reporter submits the initial incident report to their supervisor or the regional program director who in turn submits the report to CCL and authorized representatives. The facility is participating in a Technical Advisory Program addressing issues with reporting requirements. Based on interviews conducted and documents reviewed the allegations that a client's needs and services are not met and incident reports are not sent to authorized representatives are unsubstantiated. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, appeal rights, and the LIC811 were discussed and emailed to Mr. Johnson and Ms. Miller. .

narrative: C1 is the victim and declined to be interviewed regarding the investigation. C1 and C2 both orally copulated each other. Both C1 and C2 are the same sex. C2 stated the sexual interaction only occurred once and was consensual. C1 signed an "Unity Care Group Admission Agreement" it states Dating: Participants in single site setting are prohibited from dating one another and physical contact is prohibited between residents. C1 is a minor and C2 is over the age of 18. The Case Manager at Unity Care interviewed both C1 & C2 and at that time they both denied ever engaging in any sexual activity. However, the victim C1 later reported the incident to the Police and then declined to be interviewed. C1 is currently living out of the state. Based on information the investigator obtained during the investigation; the facility staff have no expectation of supervision for residents regardless of age. The residents of the facility are mostly adults and come and go from the facility as they please but must be back at the facility prior to curfew at 2200 hours Sunday through Thursday and 2300 hours Friday and Saturday. As a result of the investigation conducted, the allegation that minor was sexually assaulted in care is UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning the allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. An exit interview was conducted with the Program Manager, and document/appeal rights were provided. No citations were issued on this date.

On 8/2/2022 at 10: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mary Shelton made an unannounced Annual inspection visit at the facility's administrative office. LPA met with Devin Johnson, Program Manager. LPA did advise the agency that the inspection is being completed with the use of the CARE Tool. However, due to technical issues the CARE Tool was not implemented. There were no clients present during the inspection of the administrative office. This facility provides services to minors and non-minor dependents (NMD), is licensed for 74 participants and currently has a census of 30 participants. LPA observed the office has four private rooms; one office is for the Regional Program Director, the two supervisor's share one office, one is the therapist's office, one is a large conference room used for meetings and training's. A multi-compartment cubicle with space for four employees is located in the middle of the main office and two additional cubicles on the back wall. The office has a bathroom and kitchen facilities. LPA observed the client files are stored in a locked file cabinet in the main office area. The employee files are stored in a locked file cabinet inside the Regional Program Director's office. LPA observed the facility sketch, license and emergency disaster plan are posted. LPA Shelton inspected and/or reviewed the following: · Postings of facility license and Personal Rights Poster were appropriately posted · LPA observed a working telephone on the premises · Carbon monoxide detectors/Smoke Detectors were present and functioning · First Aid Kit was present and fully stocked as required · LPA reviewed five (5) client files. No children were present to interview · LPA reviewed five (5) staff files and one staff was interviewed. · Fire extinguishers were visible (2) around the office. There are smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors in the office. The tags on the extinguishers are in compliance. · LPA reviewed complaint procedures for clients. · Board Minutes were reviewed · Staff training was in compliance · Criminal record clearances were verified by LPA and in compliance · Certified Administrators certificate was valid and current · Staff job titles/qualifications were verified along with the required Hours of initial training. LPA verified that for staff that have been here longer than a year, the Hours of annual training was also present. · Trauma informed practices are implemented as needed (including specialty mental health services and extracurricular activities and social supports) per discussion with social worker. The following items were reviewed for compliance in the regional office prior to the facility inspection: Agency file, Administrator Certificate, fire clearance and Fees. LPA discussed fees and the agency is aware an amount is due. No citations were issued at the conclusion of the inspection. Exit interview was conducted and documents were provided to the facility.

The Department has investigated the complaint that the participants are not properly supervised to meet their needs and facility is in disrepair. There is one staff from 3: PM until 12: AM, weekdays at the home. There needs to be a staff who lives on site for minors placed in the home. According to the Program statement "Staffed Sites: Participant (Minors and/or NMD) live in an independent setting in a Unity Care home and do not require constant (24-hour X7 day) supervision. Our Staff Sites are separate for male and female participant. Staffed Sites have Residential Advisors who live at the site." This states that Unity Care is not following the Program Statement. There is not a staff available on site during the weeknight and none on weekends. The non-minor dependents are not properly being supervised. Most of the clients in the home are 18 years old. However, there have been incidents of clients sneaking in friends and family members that intrude on other clients in the house. In addition, the Department has investigated the complaint that the facility is in disrepair and found no one in the home have witness or heard of yard fighting, someone being taken to jail on a warrant, cars being broken into, the fire department and ambulance was called for a resident with a medical emergency and the front gate was replaced due to erosion. It was also stated the home could be more organized and cleaner due to clients not cleaning up after themselves. However, it was founded that garbage is being left outside on the side of the home and not properly placed in a trash can. The residents sometimes forget to take out the trash and it piles up. The trash is picked up once a week. Based on LPA's interviews which were conducted and record reviews(s), the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation(s) (ARE) found to be Substantiated. The facility is cited on the attached LIC 9099D under the California Code of regulations, 86078(B) RESPONSIBILITY FOR PROVIDING CARE AND SUPERVISION: The licensing agency retains the authority to require additional staff, including social workers when the agency determines it is necessary to provide for the appropriate care and supervision of the participants and Buildings and Grounds(a) The facility shall be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair at all times for the safety and well being of clients, employees and visitors. A copy of this report was reviewed and given to the Administrator with appeal rights.

narrative: Regarding the allegation that staff poses a risk to participants in the home: During the complaint investigation it was found that staff did not pose a risk to participants in the home. C1 was the aggressor in the altercation, that occurred between C1 and S1. The agency provided video footage and it showed C1 would not stop advancing on S1. Interviews conducted with clients concluded the same results, that C1 was the aggressor. Based on the Investigators observations, interviews which were conducted, and records reviewed, the preponderance of evidence standard has not been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be UNSUBSTANTIATED. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. Regarding the allegation that staff chocked participant and/or pulled participant hair: During the complaint investigation it was found that C1 stated S1 pushed, grabbed, then choked C1 with two hands for "at least 30 seconds. However. Client statements and surveillance do not support the claim that C1 was choked at all. C5 was present throughout the entire incident and stated S1 acted in self-defense when he pushed and grabbed C1. At one-point S1 did grab C1 by the neck but C5 could see S1 was not squeezing or choking C1. S1 was attempting to control C1 who was actively trying to hit S1. The surveillance video provided by the agency does not show S1 choking, hitting, or punching C1. C2 stated it happen so fast that C2 could not tell if S1 pulled C1's hair. Based on the investigation, records reviewed, and interviews conducted, the complaint findings are UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. An exit interview was conducted with Program Manager, Devin Johnson, a copy of this report and appeal process were email due to technical difficulties.

narrative: It was alleged that the facility is abusing the emancipation funds release process. Interviews revealed that the emancipation funds process required Unity Care to assist the clients who were interested in participating in the Emancipation Funds process, to save their money while Unity Care would match the amount saved by the clients up to 20% which they would receive at graduation. However, the program was discontinued in January of 2022. Records of eight clients reviewed showed clients received funds at the end of the program. LPA attempted to interview these eight clients. Two clients responded, while a third client was deceased. C4 stated that his understanding was that he received a monthly stipend from UCG and from this stipend UCG opened a savings on his behalf where they saved his money and when he graduated, he was supposed to receive this money. He added that he received money at graduation but does not remember how much. C8 stated that he received some funds but that he did not understand the emancipation funds process or what the amounts he received were for. He also stated he did not remember how much he had received at graduation. A review of the bank's ARH payments from Heritage Bank of Commerce from what appeared to be a checking account containing routine checking transaction. Payments on the statement highlighted wire transfers to three clients while other debit transactions were blacked out. The payments were in the amount of $800.00 to C2, $1,000 to C3 and, $10,492.91 to C4, after their graduation from the program. LPA was unable to determine if the amount refunded was the amount owed to the clients. Based on LPA's confidential interviews and records reviewed, the allegation that facility is abusing the emancipation funds release process is unsubstantiated, meaning that the allegation lacks a preponderance of evidence to prove that the violation occurred. However, LPA did find that funds were commingled in the process. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report along with the Appeal Rights were provided to the Administrator.

On Monday, December 2nd, 2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brittany Crass, conducted an unannounced, annual inspection at the Administrative Office. Administrator Devin Johnson, assisted with the inspection. LPA Crass toured the administrative office and observed the office to be clean, safe and sanitary. The office consisted of a lobby, administrative office, file room, large conference room, three private offices, kitchen, six cubicals, and a bathroom. LPA noted the license and Evacuation Plan were posted. Currently, the facility has 25 participants in placement. All apartments are located within two hours from the administrative office. The THPP has apartments in Rocklin, and Sacramento, as well as a house in Rocklin. There are three Case Manager/Social Workers. The facility is current with their annual fees. LPA reviewed five client files, the administrators file, and four other staff files. The facility is being cited two Type B citations. One for Interim Licensing Standards, Section 86268.3(d) Needs and Services Plan, and another for Health and Safety Code 1565(b). See attached LIC D page. The Facility was also given multiple Technical Violations, and Technical Advisories, which are not citations. An exit interview was conducted with Devin Johnson. On Friday, August 8th, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brittany Crass, conducted an Unannounced, annual inspection at the Administrative Office. Administrator Devin Johnson, assisted with the inspection. LPA Crass toured the administrative office and observed the office to be clean, safe and sanitary. The office consisted of a lobby, administrative office, file room, large conference room, three private offices, kitchen, six cubicles, and a bathroom. LPA noted the license and Evacuation Plan were posted. The Agency has done an annual training on the Emergency Disaster Plan, but has not been conducting quarterly drills of various emergency scenarios with staff. Currently, the facility has 26 participants in placement. All apartments are located within two hours from the administrative office. The THPP has apartments in Rocklin, and Sacramento, as well as a house in Rocklin. There are three Case Manager/Social Workers. The facility is current with their annual fees. LPA reviewed five client files, and three staff files. LPA observed no deficiencies in the staff files. In the client files, LPA observed that the Needs and Services Plans for 5/5 clients did not match the Transitional Independent Living Plans, were missing planned length of placement, and were also missing the required signatures. (Continued on LIC 809-C). On the attached LIC 809-D page, the facility is being cited four Type B citations for: 1) Health and Safety Code Section 1565(c), 2) Interim Licensing Standards Section 86268.3(c)(1) NEEDS AND SERVICES PLAN, 3) Interim Licensing Standards, Section 86268.3(a) NEEDS AND SERVICES PLAN, and 4) Interim Licensing Standards, Section 86268.3(d) NEEDS AND SERVICES PLAN, which also has a Civil Penalty attached for a repeat violation within 12 months. Three out of the four citations given today, were already given as Technical Violations on the Agency's prior annual inspection on 12/2/24. The Agency was also given one Technical Violation for NON MINOR DEPENDENT RECORDS, and two Technical Advisory's for PARTICIPANT MEDICAL ASSESSMENTS and REGISTER OF PARTICIPANTS, which are not citations. An exit interview was conducted with Devin Johnson. A copy of this report and Appeal Rights were given.

It was alleged that Staff do not prevent the facility from being in disrepair. The participant alleged multiple repair problems with their unit, including black mold in the HVAC and bathroom, disconnected water heater exhaust, high humidity, leaking dishwasher, missing vent cover, and more. The participant stated they told their Case Worker about these issues and the Case Worker let them know that maintenance requests must be done by the apartment, not by Unity Care. Although the Agency and the Apartment Complex encourage participants to be independent and to notify the Apartment of any maintenance repairs themselves, it was revealed that sometimes, whoever is working at the Apartment, will turn down residents because Unity Care is who is on the lease, not the Non-Minor Dependents. The Case Worker for NMD1 inaccurately told LPA that they cannot put in a maintenance request for the participant, and that the apartment will not accept repair requests from anyone other than the residents. Contrastingly, the Case Worker (CW2) for NMD2 stated they put in maintenance requests for the participants often, especially if the Apartment makes it difficult for the participant to do so. CW2 stated they can do it verbally for small things, or if it is a large repair, such as an HVAC issue, the Apartment will ask Unity Care to put it through "the portal". The Community Director of the Apartment Complex stated 90% of the maintenance requests come from Unity Care Case Workers, and not from the participants themselves. When LPA asked the participant if the Case Worker had checked in on the repairs not being completed yet, the participant stated they had not told the Case Worker that the complex hadn't fixed it yet. Although the Case Worker was not aware of the status of the maintenance request and thought the participant was working it out with the Apartment Complex, the Case Worker did not follow up with the participant or assist them when they stated the Apartment Complex would not let them put in the maintenance requests. The Case Worker's response was, repeatedly, that they could not do anything about it and that it must come from the participant, which is not true. NMD2 confirmed that they would overhear CW1 and NMD1, and CW1 sounded like a "broken record", continuing to tell the participant the same thing. Because Unity Care knew about the issues within the Apartment, and they did not assist the participant in addressing the concerns, this allegation is Substantiated. (Continued on LIC 9099-C). Regarding the allegation that Staff did not prevent a participant from being exposed to harmful conditions, it was reported that there was mold in the HVAC system and bathroom. CW1 told the participant to contact the Apartment Complex to put in a maintenance request, but the Apartment Complex told the participant the request needed to be put in the "portal". The participant asked how to put it in the portal and the Apartment Complex told the participant they couldn't give access to the portal because they aren't the name on the lease. The participant told their Case Worker, who told them to go back to the Complex because they couldn't do anything about it. An interview with the Case Worker revealed that they did not know the Agency process for how to request something to get put in the portal. The Administrator stated the Case Workers contact S3 themselves, who will put it in the portal for them, while CW2 stated they do not contact S3 directly, they tell the Administrator, who gets the request put in the portal for them. As a result of the conflicting statements from Unity Care and staff not providing direct assistance to handle the maintenance issues in the apartment, this allegation is substantiated. Regarding the allegation that Staff did not ensure the HVAC system is properly operating, according to the participant, the HVAC would not keep up with high temperatures and was also bringing in humidity which caused mold to grow and caused breathing problems for the participant. Interviews revealed the Case Workers' only solution to help the participant was to offer to move them to a different unit within the complex. The participant stated they did not want to move, due to the feeling that they have always been moved around too much throughout their life and wanted to establish a home somewhere. When the participant stated they didn't want to move, CW1 did not seek additional solutions to help the participant get the HVAC system properly working. The Participant and the Case Worker both corroborate that when the participant brought up any issues, the Case Workers response was that they needed to file a maintenance request. When the participant tried to with the Complex but couldn't because they told them it needs to be done through the portal, which the participant didn't have access to, the Case Worker told the participant again to go back to the apartment because they couldn't do anything. It was revealed that it is the Case Worker who tells the Administrator, who ensures maintenance requests go through the portal. NMD1 and NMD2 stated CW1 told the participant what they need to do but did not assist the client directly, which is required of the Transitional House Placement Program in teaching participants independence. (Continued on LIC 9099-C). It was also alleged that the participant saw a doctor for respiratory issues due to the unit having high humidity, and the Agency did not take it seriously. The participant stated they began having respiratory issues about a month after their move-in date on 1/9/2025. The participant saw a doctor for respiratory issues on May 30, 2025. The doctor's note revealed the doctor also believed the respiratory issues were from high humidity. The participant told their Case Worker they were having breathing issues from the mold and humidity. The Participant stated the Case Worker's response was, "Let them handle it". In an interview with the Case Worker, CW1 told LPA they knew the client went to the doctor, as the participant had told the Case Worker that they took the note to the Apartment Complex, in the hopes that it would speed up the maintenance requests. When asked if CW1 believed they should have assisted the participant in bringing the doctor's note to the office, CW1 stated, "They want them to do it themselves. I don't think there would be a difference if I went there with the same request." Additionally, the Case Worker told the participant that there was, "nothing Unity Care can do". When LPA asked CW1 why they didn't tell the Administrator, CW1 stated they did not think there was anything that the Administrator would have been able to do. This Department has investigated the complaints alleging Staff do not prevent the facility from being in disrepair, Staff did not prevent a client from being exposed to harmful conditions, Staff did not ensure the HVAC system is properly operating, and Staff did not address a client's change in medical condition. We have found the complaints to be Substantiated meaning the preponderance of the evidence standard has been met. The Agency is being cited for Interim Licensing Standards Section 86278(b) RESPONSIBILITY FOR PROVIDING CARE AND SUPERVISION, Interim Licensing Standards Section 86065.3(f)(4) SOCIAL WORK PERSONNEL, and California Code of Regulations Section 86030.5(a) IDENTIFICATION OF THPP PARTICIPANT LIVING UNITS on the attached LIC 9099-D pages. Exit interview conducted with Devin Johnson. A copy of this report and appeal rights were given.

narrative: C1 stated he was greeted by an unidentified male saying something about heard you ordered me up and the male touched C1's waist. S2 stated he may have put his hands up, about stomach high, as a means to motion hey it's okay calm down. S1 stated S2 grabbed the client by the hips. S1 and S2 verify it was meant to be funny but the client reacted in anger. C1 stated S2 made other comments about his attractive appearance and beautiful blue eyes which made C1 feel uncomfortable. S2 confirmed he spoke to C1 about becoming a model. S3 and S4 stated they independently wrote an incident report detailing the above event. CCL did not receive an incident report detailing the interactions between S1, S2 and C1. CCL received an incident report stating S1 had boundary issues and used vulgar language. A verbal report from RD to LPA Sullivan indicated the interactions and language were in the presence of other staff members but did not involve a client. The facility was advised to send a written incident report to CCL and refer the staff's behavior to human resources. Based on the interviews conducted and incident reports reviewed the allegations that staff inappropriately touched minor, staff made sexual advances towards minor, and the facility did not notify licensing of an incident are SUBSTANTIATED. The facility is cited for violations of Interim Licensing Standards AB Nonminor Dependents, THPP Article 6, Personal Rights.
