narrative: Five clients reported that the payments are never the same. Clients report not getting an itemized accounting of what the deductions were for or how much each deduction was. Records indicate two client's checks were made payable to staff who in turn gave the cash to the clients or signed the checks over for clients to deposit. Three clients report not receiving the full amount of their emancipation funds after existing the program. The facility withholds cleaning fees and property damages from the emancipation fund if the amount is in excess of the security deposit. An orientation booklet, initialed by the clients at admission, states that a cleaning fee for smoking inside a housing unit will be withheld from the emancipation fund or monthly stipend. The booklet states funds will be withheld from the emancipation fund to cover damages. The facility Plan of Operation does not include a section on emancipation funds. The Plan of Operation does not describe how the facility will account for or handle the client's funds for an emancipation account. Based on the interviews conducted and the financial documents obtained from the facility the allegation that resident's money is mismanaged in SUBSTANTIATED. The facility is cited for California Code of Regulations Title 22, division 6, chapter 7, Transitional Housing Placement Program for Minor Foster Children, Safeguards for Cash Resources, Personal Property, and Valuables of Residents, and Transitional Housing Placement Program for Nonminor Dependents, Safeguarding for Cash Resources, Personal Property, and Valuables. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and appeal rights discussed and left with Devon Johnson.
investigation_findings: 13On 11/18/21 at 2: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Robin Sullivan went to the facility for the purpose of delivering findings for the allegation that resident's money is mismanaged. LPA met with Devon Johnson, Supervisor. During the investigation, LPA interviewed seven clients, three staff, one probation officer, and one social worker, between 4/27/21 and 11/1/21 and obtained the following documents: financial payment and deduction information for eleven clients, copies of payment stubs, Needs and Services Plans, THP Orientation booklet,Transitional Independent Living Plans, reviewed program statement and Plan of Operation. The investigation reveal that clients do not receive a detailed accounting of their bi-monthly income and expenses. Non-minor dependent clients receive a stipend paid twice a month from which rent, gas and electric, other utilities, expenses for damages incurred, and deductions if infractions of the housing policies occur. Minor clients receive a weekly stipend and are charged if chores are not done. Six of seven clients interviewed stated they did not know how much money they would get each month until they received their payment. SubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

investigation_findings: 13On 11/18/21 at 4:00 , Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Robin Sullivan went to the facility for the purpose of delivering findings for the allegation that the living units are not in good repair. During the investigation six clients, four staff, one probation officer, and one social worker were interviewed between 4/14/21 and 10/26/21. LPA obtained and reviewed the following documents Needs and Services Plans, Transitional Independent Living Plans, physician reports, medical and dental reports, budget plans, and photographs. The investigation revealed that living units are not in good repair. LPA observed multiple holes in bedroom walls, broken cabinet doors, and property fencing with missing planks. On a return inspection, LPA observed unrepaired holes in the bedroom wall and missing planks in the fence. Two clients stated that when they moved in, the bedroom walls had existing holes. Based on observations and interviews the allegation that the living units are not in good repair is substantiated. The facility is cited for violation of Transitional Housing Placement Program, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 7, Personal Rights for minors and Personal Rights for Non-minor Dependents. SubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:
allegations: SubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion: Estimated Days of Completion: Estimated Days of Completion:

narrative: LPA obtained information that staff are trained to write incident reports when they are present during an incident or they obtain information that requires a written report. After the report is written, staff submits to their supervisor or regional manager for review. Management reviews the reports for thoroughness of content and accuracy and then enters the report into a computer system. It is alleged that the living units are not clean. LPA obtained photographs of one house with a sink full of dirty dishes and the kitchen trash can overflowing. During an unannounced inspection, LPA observed the same house to be clean and clutter free. The kitchen sink was clean, the floors were clean, the trash was half full, and the main living area was clean and tidy. LPA observed a client washing dishes at a second location upon entering the house. The client stated that chores rotate and this was his day to wash the dishes. Client stated that sometimes he lets the pots and pans stacked up and then washes them all at once. Client stated that everyone in the house rotates chore duties. It is alleged that client information is not being kept confidential. One staff reported that cabinets used for client files are not locked properly. One staff reported that one drawer of a file cabinet was broken but no client files were stored in the broken drawer. LPA has observed all client files to be locked and secure in the regional office. It is alleged that clients are not receiving necessary services. Clients have access to weekly individual counseling, group counseling, and case management sessions. Two clients confirm they go to individual counseling. One client stated not needing anything. Two clients declined to talk about using services or if services are offered. One case manager had concerns for two clients that present with mental health issues but may not be getting additional services. One of the two clients verified he attends therapy sessions and the probation officer confirmed the client's attendance. The other client stated there is no need for additional services. Based on interviews and observations the allegations that staff are falsifying incident reports, living units are not clean, clients are not receiving necessary services, and client information is not being kept confidential are unsubstantiated. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, appeal rights and the LIC811 were discussed and left with Devon Johnson.
investigation_findings: 13On 11/18/21 at 4: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Robin Sullivan went to the facility for the purpose of delivering findings for the allegations that staff are falsifying incident reports, living units are not clean, clients are not receiving necessary services, and clients information is not being kept confidential. The staff were concerned that some reports may get modified or not reported to the proper authorities because they can no longer track reports in the system. narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sam Raissi conducted a case management tele-inspection on January 20, 2021, at 8: AM via Tele-visit (due to COVID 19). LPA Raissi met with Administrator, Kenya Kennedy, via Facetime. The purpose of the case management was regarding an incident involving a resident at the TRANSITIONAL HOUSING PLACEMENT PROGRAM (THPP) Staff Site (House 8). Refer to ( Confidential Names list, dated January 20, 2021). Kenya Kennedy (Administrator), An NMD Client (C1) cut herself at a park. The client was taken to the emergency room. Per Administrator, due to insurance, C1 was transferred to a hospital in Freemont. C1 still has suicidal ideation. Due to the level of care and increased supervision the above agency gave C1 a seven-day notice. The county social worker informed the Administrator that C1 will be transferred to a psychiatric inpatient treatment center (long term). The Administrator will update LPA Raissi with the situation. No citation was given for this visit. A copy of this report was emailed to Kenya Kennedy for review and signature.

During this investigation LPA Raissi informed this agency of the complaint allegation and reviewed participant and staff files. IB Investigator Farquhar and LPA Raissi made attempts to conduct an interview with the confidential witness. The confidential witness did not want to cooperate with IB Investigator and did not reply to attempts made by LPA Raissi. IB Investigator Farquhar and LPA Raissi attempted to conducted confidential interviews of four participants. LPA Raissi conducted three confidential interviews of two Unity Care representatives [Staff 1 (S1) on October 21, 2020, Staff 2 (S2) on March 29, 2021] and [C1's Probation Officer (PO) on February 18, 2021]. LPA Raissi made attempts to contact C1's case manager Staff 3 (S3). LPA Raissi obtained an Incident Report from this agency and other documents pertaining to the investigation. Based on interviews with two Unity Care representatives the clients are no longer participants with this agency. On October 20, 2020, the Department received a complaint alleging, "clients are smoking illegal drugs while in care". Based on confidential interviews, there were no further witnesses or information that corroborated clients smoking Methamphetamine at the THPP staff site. All participants have since left placement from the THPP staff site (House 7) and could not be located. Based on three out of three confidential interviews and IB Investigator Farquhar's report findings, the allegation that, "clients are smoking illegal drugs while in care" could not be proved. The complaint findings are Unsubstantiated. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is Unsubstantiated. No deficiencies were cited. Exit interview conducted, appeal rights discussed, and a copy of the report was left at the agency with Administrator, Kenya Kennedy.

On June 10, 2021, at 11: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sam Raissi was met by Administrator, Kenya Kennedy at the agency listed above this report (announced visit due to COVID-19 precautions). The purpose of the case management was regarding an incident involving a resident at the Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) residential apartment. Refer to ( Confidential Names list, dated June 10, 2021). On May 17, 2021, Eddie Brown, property manager texted (911) at 9: PM to Samara Lacapa, case manager. Samara called Eddie and informed her that Client 3 (C3) called him stating that his roommate, Client 2 (C2), raped his girlfriend, Client 1 (C1). All clients are residents of the THPP. Eddie was advised to call San Jose Police Department (SJPD). Samara and Kenya went to the residential apartment (UP1) to wait for SJPD to arrive on the scene. SJPD arrived and took statements from staff C1, and C3. C2 was not at his apartment when the report was made and when the SJPD came to the apartment. C1 reported to SJPD that C2 raped her on Saturday, May 15, 2021. SJPD transported C1 to the hospital for observation. A restraining order was put on C2. SJPD communicated C2 was able to return to the house. Due to the circumstances Unity Care THPP representatives moved C2 to another THPP residential site, were there is increased staff supervision. On June 9, 2021, C2 moved back to residential apartment (UP1). The above agency is monitoring the situation and will keep this LPA informed of any developments. No citation was given for this visit. A copy of this report was given to Kenya Kennedy for review and signature.

On July 29, 2021, at 11: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sam Raissi was met by Administrator (Admin), Kenya Kennedy at the agency listed above this report. The purpose of the case management was regarding an incident involving a resident at the Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) residential apartment. Refer to ( Confidential Names list, dated July 28, 2021). On Saturday, July 24, Client 1 (C1) and his girlfriend were arguing/yelling for a lengthy period. Per Admin, PM called the police. PM arrived at the property; the police cars were lined across the block. PM was told by the police officers that C1 said his girlfriend stabbed him with a knife. When police arrived C1 told the police officers that he did not want to press charges. C1 told the police officers that his girlfriend had a seizure. The police officers requested to speak with the girlfriend. C1 ran into his room, locked the door, and barricaded themselves. After several verbal requests, C1 opened the door and pulled out the girlfriend. C1 proceeded to charge towards the police officers. The police eventually took C1 into custody, on a gurney (handcuffed). C1 was taken to the hospital. The girlfriend was also taken to the hospital. Per Admin, C1 was released from custody and discharged from the THPP program. Admin said she does not have any more information and wants to see the police report before she describes what accurately happened. Admin notified C1's Alameda County Social Worker. The girlfriend is not placed with Unity Care THPP. Admin sent an Incident Report (IR) describing what had taken place. An updated IR will be submitted following the police report. Admin will update LPA regarding this matter. No citation was given for this visit. A copy of this report was given to Kenya Kennedy.

The clients that resided at the home are no longer participants with this agency. LPA Raissi could not make further contact with the witness. Based on interviews and a inspection at the residence (THPP staff site) there is no further information that could be obtained. Therefore, the complaint findings are Unsubstantiated. Although the allegation(s) may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation(s) are Unsubstantiated. No deficiencies were cited. Exit interview conducted, appeal rights discussed, and a copy of the report was left at the agency with Administrator, Kenya Kennedy.

narrative: On February 6, 2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Vanessa Galvan traveled to the Unity Transitional Housing office located in Visalia CA. LPA was met by Administrator, Rose Churchill, Program Director, Mary Beth Irons, and ILP Specialist Noe Lara for the purpose of a scheduled pre-licensing inspection. A general overview of their program and a tour of the facility was provided. This facility has a reception area, waiting area, and office space for staff. Observed fixtures and furniture, equipment and supplies necessary for this operation. Also observed locked cabinets for client and staff files in order to ensure confidentiality. Discussed daily ongoing functions including incident reports. There is ample confidential space for meeting with clients on an as needed basis. The above licensee meets the requirements to be licensed as a THPP serving clients age 18-21 within a two hour driving radius pending approval of updates requested during the component II orientation. Once licensed the applicant will submit updated version of the program statement to Rates. On a quarterly basis, facility is to submit a roster of THPP clients that includes client names, dates of birth, county worker and current address of placement.

met_with: Rose Churchill, Mary Beth Irons, Noe Lara
narrative: On March 4, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Vanessa Galvan traveled to Unity Transitional Housing located in Visalia, CA, and met with Administrator/Social Worker Supervisor Rose Churchill, Program Director Mary Beth Irons, and Case Manager Noe Lara. The purpose of the inspection is to conduct an Annual/Required inspection. LPA conducted a physical plant inspection and included the following observation and checks: clients and staff files are kept in locked filing cabinets. The agency has adequate confidential meeting space, space for Social Worker and Case Manager to complete job duties. The facility has a current copy of the license, Facility Sketch, Client Personal Rights, LIC 610C, fire clearance, and "Let Us No" reporting hotline poster posted in a common area, . The agency has a client register roster LIC 9120, with all required information. The agency's office is located within two hours of travel time of the THPP participants living units. The agency employs (1) Administrator/Social Worker Supervisor, (1) Program Director, and (1) Case Manager. LPA reviewed three staff files. A review of the staff files on this date indicates that all facility staff has received child abuse index, DOJ, and FBI clearances. Agency staff meets the requirements of respective job descriptions. Staff files meet regulatory standards. The agency currently has (15) THPP Non-Minor Dependent (NMD) participants. LPA reviewed (6) THPP NMD Participant files on this date. Client files meet regulatory standards. LPA reviewed an updated LIC 500, roster of clients, certified THPP units certificated, and Disaster Preparedness Plan. No deficiencies were issued on this date. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Rose Churchill at the conclusion of the inspection.

Statements obtained from confidential interviews reveal that NMD1 receives 2 types of checks - regular allowance and mentor check. Mentor checks are only issued to participants who perform voluntary tasks for the program. Currently, NMD1 is the only participant who receives a mentor check. Participants receive their allowance checks every 1st and 15th day of the month. However, if the 1st or 15th day of the month falls on a weekend, participants receive their checks the following business day. On Monday, 3/2/20, NMD1 received her allowance check only. It was discovered that NMD1's mentor check had not been signed by the CEO. NMD1 usually receives her mentor check the same day she receives her 1st allowance check for the month. NMD1 stated that she did not receive her mentor check until the following day, 3/3/20. In reviewing the THPP's Program Statement specifically the policies and procedures on handling NMD's funds and allowances, LPA Herring found no written procedures for determining the amount of allowance provided to each participant, and the schedule for disbursement. The THPP also has no procedures for issuing mentor checks. An Advisory Note (LIC 9102) will be issued to the licensee to ensure appropriate procedures are in place. Based on the information gathered, although the allegations may have happened or is valid, the preponderance of evidence to prove the allegation was not met, therefore, this complaint is determined to be unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report, Confidential Names Form and Appeal Rights were provided to the facility representative. There were no deficiencies cited during this tele-inspection.

narrative: Additionally, Administrator stated no incidents were documented or recorded from NMDs that staff 1 or any staff members were treating NMDs the way that was depicted in the complaint allegations. Interview conducted with NMD 3 state that staff 1 and additional staff were respectful, supportive and resourceful. Additionally, NMD3 stated he only flourished under the care and supervision of Valor Educational Facility. NMD3 stated that NMD1 was his roommate and he felt as though staff were not as helpful to NMD1 as they were to him but that staff did provide NMD1 with some resources but was unsure of what services. Furthermore, he stated he never discussed with NMD1 how NMD1 felt about the treatment provided by staff. NMD 3 was also unable to provide clear information as to which staff was providing specific services to NMDs but that he received allowances and did not know if others received theirs. Interview conducted with NMD1 identify S1 as being very rude by making personal statements or opinions to others about NMD1. However, NMD1 stated that staff did not communicate well. NMD1 stated staff did not communicate well when issuing allowances or assisting clients with daily needs but that needs were eventually resolved or handled. No interviews conducted identified observing or hearing of staff pushing clients or being physically abusive. LPA was unable to interview NMD2 and associated county social worker. LPA reviewed incident reports and did not observe any reports made of allegations presented. met_with: Katrecia Short, Board Member; Ryan Smith, Board Member; and Jill Howard, Administrator
narrative: On January 14, 2021 at 2: PM, a case management tele-inspection was conducted by the Department via Microsoft Teams Meeting. Remote "tele-inspection" of facilities is a part of Community Care Licensing Division's emergency response to the spread of Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19). The tele-inspection was conducted for the following purposes: Issue deficiency citations revealed during a solvency audit completed by the Department. Conduct a Non-Compliance Conference (NCC). Present in the meeting representing the Department were: Monique Turner-Marshall, Regional Manager (RM); Tira Logan-Shanks, Licensing Program Manager (LPM); and Jean Herring, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA). Present in the meeting representing Valor Residential & Educational Services (VRES) were: Katrecia Short, Board Member; Ryan Smith, Board Member; and Jill Howard, Administrator. The following was discussed: Per Fiscal Audit Summary of Exit Conference dated January 9, 2020, the Provider expended AFDC-FC program funds totaling to $82,534.43 for expenditures without proper/adequate supporting documentation which resulted in disallowed costs. It was concluded that this was due to the Provider's lack of written internal control policies and procedures. On July 23, 2020, a solvency audit engagement letter was emailed and certified mail delivered to the licensee. A solvency audit was performed by Community Care Licensing Division - Audit Section with the following objectives: (continued...) - Determine if the licensee has sufficient resources necessary to meet operating costs for proper care of their residents and ensure compliance with section 80062, Finances. - Determine if solvency is the issue for not paying facility operational expenses timely. - Determine if the facility funds are used for operational expenses and for the benefit of the children in placement. Based on the information gathered during the solvency audit, the following was revealed: - The licensee does not have sufficient resources necessary to meet operating costs and does not have an adequate financial plan to meet its obligations. - Solvency is the issue for not paying facility operational expenses timely. The licensee is not generating enough income and is unable to meet its operational expenses. - The former executive director (Staff1) entered into an office lease agreement for personal use. The expense does not have a program benefit. Based on the solvency audit report, it was determined that the licensee was in violation of the following regulations: - California Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Section 80062 (a) Finances - California Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Section 80063 (a) Accountability - Health & Safety Code (HSC) 1558 (a) (2) Persons prohibited from employment; dismissal or removal; appeal(Conduct Inimical) All citations and Plan of Corrections (POCs) were discussed. The tele-inspection ended at 2: PM. A signed copy of this report was provided to the licensee along with LIC809-Deficiency pages, Confidential Name/s list (LIC 811) and Appeal Rights.

narrative: It was alleged that the former Chief Executive Officer (CEO) was using the facility's name to raise personal funds. It was also alleged that the former CEO was disseminating false or misleading statement regarding the facility. LPA was unable to conduct an interview with the former CEO. Based on records reviewed, the former CEO requested funding via Facebook, for his non-profit that was allegedly affected financially by the Coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic. The former CEO also stated in the Facebook posting, that all the donations would be put into the organizers personal checking account. One staff was made aware of the above allegations but did not witness it, two staff denied the above allegations and did not witness it. LPA was unable to determine if there were donations received due to the Facebook posting being removed. LPA was also unable to gather enough information to substantiate the allegations listed above due to new employees not able to gather or find information that was requested. LPA Martin did not find corroborating evidence to substantiate the allegation. Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, a copy of this report as well as the LIC 811 was provided to the facility representative via email with signatures. The appeal rights were emailed to the facility representative.

narrative: On 03/23/2021, the Department received a complaint alleging that, there are individuals working at the facility without background clearance. Reporting Party alleged that on 03/19/21 there were two uncleared adults (A1) and (A2) reviewing clients files which contain personal information. Administrator denied the allegation stating that (A1) was hired as a bookkeeper consultant for the facility. That there were no clients present at the facility while (A1) was conducting bookkeeping duties. Administrator provided the Board of Director's Unanimous Written Consent dated 03/10/2021 to prove that (A1) was authorized to be present in the facility as a bookkeeper consultant. Administrator denies having any other unauthorized person present in the facility reviewing any type of documentation. After conducting confidential interview with Staff 1 (S1) it was determined that (S1) was laid-off before 03/19/21. Also, (S1) & (S2) confirmed that (A1) was present in the facility but did not witness any unauthorized person reviewing client's files and there were no client's present at the time. The facility is permanently closing effective July 15, 2021. All of the clients were sent to different facilities. Therefore, based on the information received, the above allegations are determined to be unsubstantiated. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report along with the (LIC 811) was sent via email and by courier to the address on file.

met_with: Russel Johnson, CEO and Petra Gil-Vigie, FFA Administrator
narrative: On January 20, 2021 at 1: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Herring conducted a Pre-licensing tele-inspection of the facility via Microsoft Teams Meeting. Remote "tele-inspection" of facilities is a part of Community Care Licensing Division's emergency response to the spread of Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19). LPA spoke with Russel Johnson, CEO and Petra Gil-Vigie, FFA Administrator. This Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) will share the same suite with Victory Family Services -Foster Family Agency (FFA). Currently, the THPP office is staffed by one (1) Administrator and one (1) Social Work Staff. LPA completed a virtual tour of the THPP's administrative office. The office is conveniently located for the public. LPA observed individual offices for the administrator and the social worker, cubicles for Life Coaches, conference room, and copy room. The THPP participant records will be filed in a locked filing cabinet in the Administrator's office and the THPP employee records will be filed in a locked cabinet in the CEO's office. The THPP will have available computers and printers for participants' use. This THPP will use Host Family and Remote Site models to place non-minor dependent (NMD) participants. Currently, the program has a contract with an apartment landlord for eight (8) apartment units. Each unit has two (2) bedrooms and one (1) bath. LPA requested a copy of the lease agreement and a sample floor plan. The THPP will complete and sign a Certificate of Compliance for each THPP participant living unit, as defined in Section 86001(c)(2), that verifies that the participant living unit meets the requirements of the Health and Safety Code Section 1501(b)(5). (Ref. California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 7, Article 3, Section 86030.5.) The THPP has not identified any host families at this time. The applicant will notify the Department once host families are identified. LPA concluded the tele-inspection at 1: PM. A signed copy of this report was provided to the applicant.

LPA met with Gregorio Aguinaldo, During this inspection, LPA reviewed four(4) participant records, including but not limited to: Admission Agreement; ID and Emergency Information; Health and Education Passports including mental health information and immunization record; education and/or work documents; Needs and Services Plan (NSP) and Transitional Independent Living Plan (TILP); modifications to NSP; Removal/Discharge Policy; and medical assessment. On December 03, 2021 at 12: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Herring conducted an unannounced Post-Licensing inspection at the above named Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) for non-minor dependents (NMDs). LPA met with Petra Gil-Vigie, Administrator. Currently, the THPP office is staffed by two(2) Social Work Personnel, one(1) Social Work Supervisor, two(2) Peer Life Skills, one (1) Office Manager and an Administrator. BUILDINGS AND GROUNDS A tour of the THPP administrative office was conducted with the administrator. The THPP administrative office shares the same suite with Victory Family Services- Foster Family Agency and Adoption Agency. The office is conveniently located for the public and less than two hours' travel by automobile from the THPP participant units as required. The office has a reception area, file room, copy area, conference room, break room, cubicles and individual offices. THPP participant records and personnel records are kept locked at all times in file cabinets. The administrative office has telephone service at all times. The program has 11 remote sites and 20 participants in placement. Per Administrator, the program has no non-ambulatory participants in placement. OPERATIONS The THPP maintains on file a current, written, definitive Plan of Operation. The THPP's governing body is active and functioning in order to ensure accountability. The THPP maintains a listing of all participants and living units. DISASTER PREPAREDNESS The THPP has a current Emergency and Disaster Preparedness Plan which includes emergency information, instructions and phone numbers including a 24-hour emergency number for the licensee and the participant's responsible party. The facility provides training on the plan to each staff member. (cont...) STAFFING During this inspection, LPA reviewed two(2) Social Worker Personnel files, one(1) Social Work Supervisor's file and Administrator's file. All personnel have obtained criminal record clearances and child abuse index checks. All personnel are associated to the THPP's facility number. During this inspection, the THPP was cited for violation of: Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 7, THPP regulation, Section 86030.5(e) - Record review reveals THPP does not maintain a Certificate of Compliance for each THPP living unit. Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 7, THPP regulation, Section 86071(a)(1)(A) - Record review reveals current participant roster does not contain information on the following: participant's ambulatory status; name, address and phone number of attending physician; authorized representative information. Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 7, THPP regulation, Section 86071(a)(1)(B) - Record review reveals current participant roster does not contain information on the following: participant's ambulatory status; name, address and phone number of attending physician; authorized representative information. Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 7, THPP regulation, Section 86071(a)(1)(C) -THPP's register of participants does not contain authorized representative information as specified in Section 86170(b)(7). A Case Management - Post-licensing Continuation inspection is required to complete the inspection. A signed copy of this report was provided to the THPP representative along with LIC 809C, LIC 809Ds, LIC 9102TV (Advisory Notes-Technical Violation), LIC 811 (Confidential Names list) and Appeal Rights.

narrative: On 5/17/22 at 3: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Herring conducted an unannounced case management inspection at the THPP administrative office address above. LPA met with Petra Gil-Vigie, Administrator and Gregorio Aguinaldo, Social Work Supervisor. The purpose of the inspection was to follow up on an incident report received by the Department on 2/9/22 involving NMD1 and NMD2. An initial follow up call was conducted by LPA Herring on 2/16/22 and an in-person inspection was conducted on 5/9/22. On 5/10/22, LPA Herring interviewed S1, S2 and S3. The following information was obtained: On 2/4/22 at around noon time, the father of NMD1's children (Adult#1) entered the residence from the back door and entered NMD1's room. Adult#1 arrived upset and started physically assaulting NMD1 in the presence of her children. The physical assault continued until NMD2 and NMD2' family arrived and intervened. NMD2's child's grandmother called 911 and threatened Adult#1 with her gun by telling him to leave or she would use what what she had in her purse on him. Adult#1 exited the residence quickly by running out the back door. Law Enforcement officers responded to the residence. A neighbor notified the THPP of the presence of law enforcement in the home. THPP staff immediately responded to the home. Per Law Enforcement Contact Report, the THPP notified the Department (on-duty worker) of the incident by phone on 2/4/22. Based on record review and interviews, the THPP was found in violation of Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Subsection 86175(c)(3)(4) Health-Related Services. (See deficiency page for citation.) LPA also provided six (6) Advisory Notes - Technical Violations and Technical Assistance. A signed copy of this report was provided to the THPP representative along with LIC 809D, Appeal Rights, LIC 811 (Confidential Names list) and LIC9102s.

On 12/30/22 at 11: A.M. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Demetris Teal conducted an unannounced case management inspection at the THPP administrative office. LPA met with Petra Gil-Vigie- Administrator, to deliver the Conclusion of the Case Management from an in-person case management inspection performed on 12/16/22, by the LPA Demetris Teal. Interviews were conducted with Staff associated with Victory Family Services, Ronald (Ron) Hernandez, Petra Gil-Vigie, Jasmeet Aujla and Dept.of Social Services with Kern County, Social Worker Somphou Siripane. Interviews were conducted with NMD 1 and an attempt to interview NMD 2 was made, without success. Based on review of files, interviews conducted and all available information, LPA did not find any personal rights or Interim Licensing Standards violated regarding Victory Family Services, where it involves a weapon produced by NMD 2 with intent to use said weapon against NMD 1. No injuries were reported by NMD 1. NMD 1 did feel threatened and called the police. Incident appears to have been isolated between two participants who lived together. NMD 2 is no longer a part of the THPP program. No further follow up is needed at this time. Exit Interview. A signed copy of this report was provided to the THPP representative along with LIC 811 (Confidential Names list).

On March 26, 2024 at 11: A.M, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Demetris Teal and Ashley Ruacho conducted an unannounced Annual Inspection at the above named Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) for non-minor dependents (NMDs). LPA's met with Petra Gil-Vigie, Administrator. Currently, the THPP office is staffed by three (3) Social Work Personnel, one (1) Acting Administrator, three (3) Peer Life Coach's, one (1) Support Staff Manager, three (3) Support Service Aide's, one (1) Office Manager and an Administrator. PHYSICAL PLANT A tour of the THPP administrative office was conducted with the administrator. The THPP administrative office shares the same suite with Victory Family Services- Foster Family Agency and Adoption Agency. The office is conveniently located for the public and less than two hours travel by automobile from the THPP participant units as required. The office has a reception area, file room, copy area, conference room, break room, cubicles and individual offices. THPP participant records and personnel records are kept locked at all times in file cabinets. The administrative office has telephone service at all times. The program has 26 remote sites and 32 participants in placement. Per Administrator, the program has no non-ambulatory participants in placement. OPERATIONS The THPP maintains on file a current, written, definitive Plan of Operation. The THPP's governing body is active and functioning in order to ensure accountability. The THPP maintains a listing of all participants and living units. Continued.... ......Continued DISASTER PREPAREDNESS The THPP has a current Emergency and Disaster Preparedness Plan which includes emergency information, instructions and phone numbers including a 24-hour emergency number for the licensee and the participant's responsible party. The facility provides training on the plan to each staff member. STAFF RECORDS Staff records are available upon request. LPA reviewed two (5) personnel records (refer to Confidential Names form LIC 811 dated March 26, 2024 and interviewed five (5) staff. All individuals who work, or have contact with clients, have a current criminal record clearance or exemption and Child Abuse Index Check clearance/Live-Scan fingerprints and/or request for association have been submitted for that purpose. The Administrator meets required education and experience. Social workers have the required education and experience. Personnel records contain documentation of staff training. CLIENT RECORDS LPA reviewed five (5) client records. Client records are maintained onsite in the administrative THPP office. Client record are in a locked cabinet. Administrative office is locked. Client record contained the name, address, telephone numbers of physicians, pertinent client information including ambulatory/non-ambulatory status. Client records were made accessible when requested. A deficiency citation was issued at the time of the inspection. An exit interviewed was conducted and a copy of the LIC 809, LIC 809C, LIC 809D and appeal rights were provided to Administrator.

Licensing Program Analyst Dina Camara conducted a case management inspection on 04/18/24 at 9: AM based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 6 out of Direct Care Staff and 5 out of 29 youth files were reviewed. 3 out of Direct Care Staff and 2 out of 29 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, 04/18/24). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, and youth case plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Camara observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Administrator Petra Gil-Vigie.

On January 27, 2025, at 1:15PM, Humberto Flores, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), conducted an unannounced Case Management inspection, Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) and met Administrator Petra Gil-Vigie. On Thursday January 23, 2025, the THPP reported to the Licensing agency that Child Ref #1 (C1) (see Confidential Names List LIC811 dated 01/27/2025) was found death on Sunday January 19, 2025, in the Alleyway of F Street and A Street, Bakersfield, with an overdose. LPA Flores interviewed Petra Gil-Vigie. Copies from C1's file were provided upon request. Further inspection is needed to deliver the findings of this case management. On February 19, 2025, at 11:40AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Humberto Flores, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), conducted an unannounced Case Management inspection at Victory Family Services Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) and met with Administrator Petra Gil-Vigie and Agency Social Worker (ASW) Zohie Earnshaw. The purpose of the inspection was to initiate investigation regarding the below incident reported via Special Incident Report (SIR). On 02/12/2025, the THPP reported to Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD) that on 02/11/2025 around 5:07PM, Participant Ref #1 (P1) (see Confidential Names List LIC811 dated 02/19/2025) called Peer Life Skills Coach (PLSC) Irais Maldonado and reported to her that P1's neighbor's caregiver broke into P1's apartment. LPA Flores investigated the incident and interviewed Administrator Petra Gil-Vigie and ASW Earnshaw. A review of the documentation submitted to CCLD was conducted. The information revealed that on 02/11/2025, an unknown woman (UW), who apparently is the caregiver of P1's neighbor, broke into P1's apartment for an unknown reason. P1 called Bakersfield Police Department (BPD) and reported the ongoing incident, right after P1 called PLSC Maldonado and informed her about the incident. P1 was advised not to engage with UW and avoid her when possible and called BPD immediately. PLSC Maldonado took immediate action and reported the ongoing break-in to BPD, and she was informed that officers were on their way, which PLSC Maldonado informed to P1 right after the call. cont.# P1 informed PLSC Maldonado that BPD informed her that P1 can file charges against UW. P1 stated that she will file a restraining order against UW. Administrator Gil-Vigie and ASW Earnshaw disclosed that P1 refused to relocate from the building and stated to both that she feels safe and neither she nor her son are in danger. ASW Earnshaw disclosed to LPA Flores that she has a package ready for P1 with the steps on how to file a restraining order with Kern County Sheriff Department but has not been able to deliver it because P1 is not answering her phone calls and P1's phone does not have a set up voicemail. LPA Flores suggested to ASW Earnshaw to send the package via electronic mail and go over the paperwork with P1 when she would make herself available. No further inspection is needed. No citation was issued. A copy of this report and LIC811 was provided to the facility representative. Exit interview conducted.

On April 25, 2025, at 3:30PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Humberto Flores, conducted an unannounced Case Management inspection, at Victory Family Services Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) and met with Administrator, Petra Gil-Vigie. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings about the below incident reported via Special Incident Report (SIR). The THPP reported that on 1/20/25. agency received a phone call from a THPP participant being concerned they had not seen Participant #1 (P1) since Saturday night 1/18/2025. On 1/20/ THPP Social Worker (SW) Lina Frost made phone calls to P1 at 10: 51AM, but unsuccessful because it went straight to phone mailbox that has not been set up yet. THPP SW Frost attempted additional phone calls at 2:10PM and 8:22PM, with the same outcome as the prior ones. On 1/20/25 at 3:20PM THPP SW Frost travelled to P1 apartment to confirm if she was home. As there was no answer THPP SW Frost used agency master key and prior to entering announced self and proceeded to enter the apartment which was found undisturbed and P1 was not present. On 1/22/ THPP SW Frost Lina contacted P1's school to verify last days of attendance of P1. On 1/22/ THPP SW Frost contacted Bakersfield Police Department to file a missing person's report which THPP SW Frost was directed to call all hospitals, morgue and conduct inmate search to search for P1. cont.# On 1/23/2025, Bakersfield Police Department (BPD) provided the following information, that on 1/19/2025, the missing person, P1, had been death, in the Alleyway of F Street and A Street, with an overdose. LPA Flores investigated the report and interviewed Petra Gil-Vigie. On February 19, 2025, LPA Flores submitted a request for Coroner, Autopsy and Toxicology report. On April 22, 2025, the Coroner Office of Bakersfield, Kern County, replied to LPA Flores that it could take from 150 to 180 days to finalize these reports. No further action is needed currently. No citation was issued. A copy of this report and LIC811 was issued to the THPP representative. Exit interview conducted.

There is not enough evidence to prove the allegations; as the information provided during the investigation is conflicting. Based on information obtained by LPA Palmer, there is not a preponderance of evidence to support the allegation therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated. No deficiency cited. Copies of the following reports were provided at the conclusion of the inspection: LIC 9099 and LIC 9099-C..

(See Form 811 - Confidential Names List Dated 5/28/25). During the investigation, confidential interviews revealed conflicting information. There was concern regarding the need to make repairs by the above named facility, and that the repairs were not completed by the facility and the repairs needed to be completed with the clients money. However, the facility was able to provide documentation regarding repairs completed on 10/05/24, 11/27/24, 1/24/2025, 4/07/25, 4/28/25, 4/30/25, via the maintenance log. narrative: On Tuesday July 29, 2025, at 1:15PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Humberto Flores conducted an unannounced Case Management Inspection, at Victory Family Services Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) and met with Petra Gil-Vigie. The purpose of the inspection was to gather information about the incident below reported via Special Incident Report (SIR). On 7/25/2205 at 3:57PM, THPP Admin Petra Gil-Vigie received a phone call from THPP Social Worker (SW) Zohie Earnshaw stating that she received a message from THPP staff that two young children, ages 2 and 1 year old, were trying to open the front door from inside the Apartment #1 (A1), the children are the sons of Nonminor Dependent (NMD). According to the SIR, THPP staff made several attempts to knock on the apartment door, but no one answered. The Local Police Department (LPD) was contacted immediately. When THPP SW Frost and Peer Life Coach Vanessa Vega arrived at the apartment complex they met with NMD. The THPP staff was informed by an officer that NMD was sleeping inside her unit. NMD was counselled by the THPP staff regarding children safety and how she needs to always be vigilant of her own children. A full report is still pending by the THPP to be submitted to the Licensing agency. A copy of this report and LIC811 were provided to the facility representative. Exit interview conducted.

On Wednesday September 17, 2025, at 2:00PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Humberto Flores conducted an unannounced Case Management Inspection, at Victory Family Services Transitional Housing Placement Program (THPP) and met with Petra Gil-Vigie. The purpose of the inspection was to gather information about the incident below reported via Special Incident Report (SIR). An initial inspection was conducted on 7/29/2025. On 7/25/2205 at 3:57PM, THPP Admin Petra Gil-Vigie received a phone call from THPP Social Worker (SW) Zohie Earnshaw stating that she received a message from THPP staff that two young children, ages 2 and 1 year old, were trying to open the front door from inside the Apartment #1 (A1), the children are the sons of Nonminor Dependent (NMD). According to the SIR, THPP staff made several attempts to knock on the apartment door, but no one answered. The Local Police Department (LPD) was contacted immediately. When THPP SW Frost and Peer Life Coach Vanessa Vega arrived at the apartment complex she proceeded to knock on the door loudly, unlocked the front door, and were met with a 1-year-old in a playpen in the middle of the living room, and another 2-year-old that was walking freely. Right after NMD stepped out of her closed-door room and looked as if she had just woken up. NMD stated that she was taking a nap. THPP staff informed NMD that there were multiple concerns that the children were left alone in the apartment unattended due to no one answering the door and her 2-year-old son banging on the window. cont.# THPP staff then proceeded to let NMD that she needs to be more vigilant and pick a better nap time for her to rest. Local Law Enforcement was contacted. After their arrival they interviewed NMD and stated that they could not take further action. No further action is needed. A copy of this report and LIC811 were provided to the facility representative. Exit interview conducted.

On 11/10/2021 at 10: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Marisol Lopez conducted an unannounced required annual inspection at the facility above. LPA met with Program Representative (P1) Stephanie Wahl. The Agency utilizes apartment buildings and housing model throughout San Diego County. Currently, there are 36 participants in the program. Participants residences are inspected by agency social worker once a week. Staffing: The agency employee's the following assigned staff under the THP program. Chief Operating Officer/Administrator, Social Worker Supervisor, Social Worker, Housing Specialist; Case manager, Enhanced Services Support Worker, and Employment Specialist. All employees have the required experience, and training for their current job employment. LPA reviewed 10 of 10 staff files (S1-S10) and interviewed 2 of 10 staff (S1, S2). All staff files met the minimum qualifications for training requirements. The facility provided a list of clients and certified apartment information, current Personnel Report (LIC 500), Designation of Facility Responsibility (LIC 308) and all staff have current CPR certificates on file. (see continuation form LIC 9099-C dated 11/10/21) Staff and client files are available for review and maintained online password protected. Due to time constraints, the annual inspection is being extended for 10 of 10 client (C1-C10) file reviews and 8 of 10 staff (S3-S10) interviews. An exit interview was conducted, and this report, and LIC 811 was reviewed with Program Representative Stephanie Wahl and a copy of this report was provided.

On 11/12/2021 at 9: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Marisol Lopez conducted an unannounced required annual continuation inspection at the facility above. LPA met with Program Representative (P1) Stephanie Wahl. The Agency utilizes apartment buildings and housing model throughout San Diego County. Currently, there are 36 participants in the program. Participants residences are inspected by agency social worker once a week. LPA reviewed ten of ten client files (C1-C10) and interviewed six of six staff (S3-S8). Two staff (S9-S10) were unavailable to be interviewed. (see confidential name list, LIC811, dated 11/12/2021) Based on records review, the licensee did not comply as four (C2, C3, C4, C6) out of ten clients (C1-C10) did not have a medical assessment in the client file which poses a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to persons in care. The facility is being issued a citation in accordance with the Title 22, section 86069(a) Participant Medical Assessments. (See LIC809-D dated 11/12/21 for the cited deficiency.) An exit interview was conducted, and this report, appeal rights and LIC 811 was reviewed with Program Representative Stephanie Wahl and a copy was provided.

On December 21, 2023 at 8: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jacob Salem arrived at the above facility and met with Edith Pedroza, Program Director. The purpose of this Case Management inspection is to conduct an annual continuation from 12/18/2023. LPA reviewed five staff files (S1-5), all of which were provided to LPA upon request. The files contained the required personnel information, criminal record clearances, health screening, and documented training from the online system Relias. Records for S1 and S2's training upon hire in the previous online training system will be sent to LPA after the human resources supervisor returns to the office on 1/8/2024.. LPA also conducted a review of the facility's written disaster preparedness plan, which was updated and signed this year. The written disaster preparedness plan includes the signed LIC 610C and signed training log for disaster drills. Additionally, the emergency plan includes a 24-hour number for clients to contact and an alterative location for clients to go in the case of emergencies. Based on observations made during the inspection, there were no deficiencies cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted with Edith Pedroza and a signed copy of this report was provided.

On December 18, 2023 at 10: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jacob Salem arrived at the above facility's corporate office for the purpose of conducting an annual inspection. LPA met with Edith Pedroza, Program Director and explained the purpose of the visit. LPA began by conducting an inspection of the office's physical plant. The office consists of a lobby, several office spaces, and a conference room that can be used for confidential interviews. LPA observed the facility license to be prominently posted near the entrance. Client files are kept in a secure online system called Extended Reach. LPA conducted a review of five client files (C1-C5), which were provided upon request. All five client files reviewed contained the required demographic information, health and educational records, signed discharge policies, and signed and up-to-date Needs and Services Plans. All five client files reviewed did not contain a written medical assessment prior to entering the program, but documentation of the clients decision to opt-out of the assessment was documented in their files. Due to time constraints, the annual is being extended to conduct an inspection of the staff files and emergency disaster plan. Based on observations made during the inspection, there were no deficiencies cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted with Edith Pedroza, Program Director, Administrator and a signed copy of this report was provided.

On 02/10/2022, Licensing Program Analyst's (LPAs) Lorena Valenzuela and Jessica Rubio, arrived at the agency for the purpose of conducting an annual inspection for the agency's Transitional Housing Program (THPP +NMD). LPAs met and toured the facility with Chief Operations Officer, Sue Evans. The facility is licensed to provide Transitional Housing Placement for Non-Minor Dependents (NMD). Facility utilizes apartment complex housing model. The agency currently has Apartment Complexes utilized for NMD. The facility provides care for 200 participants ages eighteen (18) through twenty-one (21). There are currently 113 participants residing in the program, which includes remote sites throughout San Bernardino, Riverside, Orange counties. Administrative Office is located at Arlington Avenue, Suite 106, Riverside CA, 92506. The office is located on the first floor of a retail business establishment. The office consists of a lobby/reception area, a play room/computer for the participants, furnished with chairs and tables. Cubicles/offices for the Program Director, Social Worker Supervisor, Case Managers and Social Workers. There is a kitchen area for the staff, and an additional conference room. There are working telephones and office equipment, furniture, and supplies located throughout the office space. The facility has all client records in an online database. Personnel files are also in the online database with some documents being physical files being kept at the facility. LPA reviewed 10 personnel records. All staff have Criminal Background and Child Abuse Clearances which are complete and current for all employees. Currently the facility is staffed with four Case Managers, eight Social Workers, one Housing Specialist, and one Social Worker Supervisor. All employees have the required experience, and training for their current job employment, or exceptions on file. LPA's reviewed NMD records with the assistance of Program Director Meghan Anderson. During the inspection, LPA's observed three of ten client files (C5, C7, C8) did not contain a signed Needs and Service Plan by either the authorized representative, non-minor dependent and/or social worker. Based on the record review and interviews, the agency did not ensure the participants needs and service plans were signed, the facility is being cited under Interim Licensing Standards the Nonminor Dependents regulations (AB 12), Section 86268.3 (d) Needs and Services Plan. LPA's observed 10 of 10 client records did not have a written medical assessment on file which is required within 30 days to determine the agency's ability to provide necessary health related services to the participant. Based on record review and interview, the agency did not ensure a medical assessment was obtained and kept in client records. The facility is cited under Title 22, Division 6, Section 86069 (a) Participant Medical Assessments. At 2:25 pm, Program Director Meghan Anderson assisted LPA's with the inspection at two remote sites. A smoke alarm and carbon monoxide detector were observed. Apartments were clean and organized. An exit interview was conducted, a copy of the LIC 809, LIC 809D, LIC 9102 (TA) Technical Assistance and Appeal Rights was provided to Program Director, Meghan Anderson

The THPP is being issued a citation for violations of the Interim Licensing Standards, Chapter 7, Version 2, Sections 86272 (a)(12) Personal Rights. See attached LIC 9099D for cited deficiency. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained and a copy of this report was provided to Patrick Taylor, along with the LIC 811.

Confidential interviews and documentation reported that NMD2 had stolen a package worth over $100 from NMD1's front porch on 03/08/2024. This stealing was caught on camera and reported to the facility, and NMD1 filed a police report. Confidential interviews reported that NMD2 did not receive any discipline for this action. Confidential interviews reported that NMD1 had to call the cops due to NMD2 harassing NMD1 multiple times by standing at the front door of NMD1 and not leaving, causing NMD1 to feel harassed. Confidential interviews reported that NMD1 had requested to move, but the facility was not accommodating the request. Additional confidential interviews reported that the facility had asked NMD1 if they wanted to move, and NMD1 requested to stay in their current apartments because they were close to school and work. Additional confidential interviews reported that NMD1 was asked if they felt safe to continue living at the apartment, and NMD1 stated that they felt safe. Confidential interviews reported that NMD2 was not reprimanded for the stealing due to the mental health background and felt keeping NMD2 was in the best interest of NMD2. Confidential interviews also reported that the facility encouraged NMD1 and NMD2 to leave and avoid each other. Confidential interviews reported that NMD1 moved apartments at the end of July 2024. Based on inconsistent confidential interviews, the allegation that Facility staff did not ensure that the participant (NMD1) was accorded a safe and healthful home accommodation is unsubstantiated. The allegations may have happened or are valid, but there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report LIC 9099 and the appeal rights were discussed and provided to Patrick Taylor, Program Director.

Continued from Interviews with two youth and Social worker confirmed the mentor did misuse the youth's funds, as documentation revealed. The payment documentation received from THP office determined a payment for the THP participants, which were made out in the mentor's name, was not received by the THP participant. The documentation determined the THP Program reimbursed THP participant what the mentor owed the participant. The mentor never submitted documents, determining THP participant had spent the money and was not owed it, to the THP office. The mentor stopped communications with the THP Program following their request for the documentation of expense by THP participant. The THP Program decertified mentor on 7/12/2021. Based on interviews and documentation the preponderance of evidence has been met, therefore the allegations are substantiated, meaning the allegations are valid because the preponderance of evidence standard has been met. Regulatory Statute Facility cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division and Chapter Six, regulation 80026(h)(1)(A): Each licensee shall maintain accurate records of accounts of cash resources, personal property, and valuables entrusted to his/her care, including, but not limited to the following: Records of clients' cash resources maintained as a drawing account, which shall include a current ledger accounting, with columns for income, disbursements and balance, for each client. Supporting receipts for purchases shall be filed in chronological order. Receipts for cash provided to any client from his/her account(s) shall include the client's full signature or mark, or authorized representative's full signature or mark, and a statement acknowledging receipt of the amount and date received. Conclusion An exit interview was conducted with CEO. This report was given to the facility office at the time of the delivery of findings. Appeal Rights were emailed with a copy of this report.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Hillary Hall arrived unannounced at the facility for the purpose of delivering a case management investigation. LPA met with Brooke Wells, Administrator. LPA determined through record review that two staff persons listed on the LIC- Personnel Report did not have criminal background clearances. One staff had been employed since May 2020 and the other staff had been employed since December 2021. Per Title 22 regulations, Division 6, Chapter 2, Article 03. Application Procedures, Section 88019(e) All individuals subject to a criminal record review pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1522 shall prior to working, residing or volunteering in a licensed facility: (1)Obtain a California clearance or a criminal record exemption as required by the Department. The facility is being assessed a citation and immediate civil penalty of $100 per day, for a maximum of 5 days, resulting in a $500 civil penalty, for each of two employees. A signed copy of this report, the LIC 809D and LIC 421BG were provided to the facility. Exit interview was conducted and Appeal rights were provided.

LPA conducted an inspection of the physical plant and checked for all necessary requirements. The facility was clean and organized and maintained an acceptable room temperature. LPA observed the proper postings including: facility license, complaint hotline, and emergency disaster plan. The restrooms for clients and staff were clean. Smoke alarms were in working order, fire extinguishers were current, and a first aid kit was fully stocked. Evacuation drills for the facility were completed quarterly. LPA observed client files were stored in locked cabinets. The facility has no outstanding fees. The facility currently has no minor clients and ten Non-Minor Dependent clients. Clients live in remote site apartments. No client resides more than two hours from the facility. The facility employs two Social Worker(s) and one Case Manager, and one Supervisor/Program Manager. LPA reviewed five employee personnel files. Social work personnel had completed criminal record clearances and met minimum education and experience qualifications. All First Aid and CPR certifications were up to date for personnel. LPA reviewed five client files. All clients had signed Admission Agreements. Client files had current Needs and Service Plans. Needs and Services Plan detailed adequate supportive services the facility offers to the clients. No citations were issued. An exit interview was conducted.

On 12/07/ Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Wendy Brown met with Brooke Wells, Program Manager (PM) to discuss and review progress on the Facility's Program Statement for their Transitional Housing Placement Program. An updated Program Statement was provided by PM on 11/13/23. LPA provided direction and PM will made adjustments and resubmit the Program Statement to LPA by 01/15/24.

On 02/025/ Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Wendy Brown met with Program Manager/Administrator (PM) Brooke Wells at the Chico office of Community Care Licensing, to review the Program Statement information submitted to date and briefly review additional documentation provided during our meeting. The original submittal was short and not comprehensive and included some Plan of Operation information. Discussion to move the process forward included -layout (specifically section headings); -specific required and sometimes repetitive wording; -the need to address discharge policies and procedures and retaining the signed discharge plan in client files; -wording to indicate how the agency can and will request information, such as medical records, but cannot require it of THP participants; and -clarity when addressing some policies and procedures (i.e. "we will encourage staff" versus "staff will"). LPA advised PM to discontinue efforts on revamping the Plan of Operation, but to focus on the Program Statement at this time. It was established that the Agency will submit three new sections of the Program Statement to LPA by email each week for review. Sections to be provided as follows: 02/16/2024: Sections 1 - 3 02/23/2024: Sections 4 - 6 03/01/2024: Sections 7 - 9 03/08/2024: Sections 10 - 12 03/15/2024: Sections 13 - 15 03/22/2024: Sections 16 - 18

narrative: At 11AM, Community Care Licensing (CCL) representatives met with the facility above over Microsoft Teams for the purpose of conducting an Annual Review of the facility's program, needs, population, and overstay logs. In attendance in this meeting were: -CCL Regional Manager (RM) Nelson Martinez -Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Helga Wong -Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Madi Fremont -Kelsey McCoy (Associate Government Program Analyst - Child Protection Policy Unit) -Julie Waters (Child Protection Policy Unit Manager) -ACAC Administrator Mia Buckner-Preston -Michelle Love (Alameda County SSA-CWS Child Welfare Director) Background: The purpose of this meeting was to review the utilization of the receiving center, to evaluate and discuss the Population Reports and Overstay Logs provided monthly by the facility, and to collaborate with the facility on ways that CCL can support the facility going forward. (Continued on Lic809-c) Proposed Questions: At the last Annual Review Meeting with Alameda County, Alameda County shared they had implemented new strategies to help build capacity in home-based care and Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Programs (STRTPs). Question #1: What activities has Alameda County Implemented that have increased capacity in home-based care and STRTPs? Alameda county has continued the following activities: -Recruitment through their website -The use of consultant Hill and Co. -Recruitment efforts with their consultant the Experience, i.e. FFAs and engagement strategies with staff and difficult-to-place youth -Quarterly meetings with FFAs -Preferred placement with REFUGE STRTP -GHs transitioned to STRTPs. Questions #2: What efforts has Alameda County found to be effective in building capacity and reducing the use of the TSCF? Alameda County is still engaged with all strategies to build capacity and expect all will support the goal of locating timely placements and reduce the number of overstays at the AC. Alameda County has identified there will always be a need for the TSCF and none of the strategies will significantly reduce the use of the AC. The County's plan for the next 12 months to continue to build capacity and transition away from using the TSCF is to continue with their recruitment plan to increase homes in Alameda County. The County is currently working with a consulting agency to assess and make recommendations to he County regarding ways to recruit families and agencies, i.e. FP Recruiter, Experience, Meeting with SFAY, M&M with Jim Hill and Company, Client Advocate, and Foster Family Association. (Continued on Lic809-c) Barriers to Placement: What methods is the County using to reduce the repeat overstays from 46 children in 2019 to 13 children (from Jan to Oct) in 2020? -72 hours to conduct a placement search -CFT/Teaming meetings -Case mining for potential relatives -Sharing resources From 2019-2020, in order to decrease the number of repeat overstays, Alameda County re-engaged with two FFAs, and utilized the ability to youths in newly licensed STRTPs. In order to provide more support to caregivers, Alameda County utilized the following strategies/resources: -Placement stabilization services/Technical Assistance -LOC -Foster Parent Association -Funding assistance through gift cards and Discretionary Funds Alameda County has identified that more kids are staying in the county over the 2020 year, over 50%. Impact of COVID-19: Alameda County identified that come challenges or barriers to placements in 2020 directly caused by COVID-19 were reduction in capacity and fear of exposure. The impact of COVID-19 on capacity of home-based care versus STRTP level of care has been identified by the County as follows: -Decreased capacity -Lower wait times on waiting list -Longer intake process -Required COVID-19 tests -Excessive paperwork prior to placement -No transportation support -Limited support with technology (school, visits with parents, visits with social workers) (CONTINUED ON LIC809-C) Alameda County has identified that the cause for delay with Emergency Resource Family Approval (ERFA) is that once children are placed in the home, the process slows down. There have also been delays with submitting paperwork, delays with completing LiveScan clearance, and delays with completing pre-service training. Alameda County is taking the following actions in order to reduce these delays: -Support of assigned placement/RFA CWW to assist with paperwork completion -Financial support and client advocacy Alameda County's timeframe to complete the ERFA remains at 90 days. One barrier identified in the monthly Overstay Reports is lack of capacity. Alameda County has identified the following specific placement types that are lacking in capacity: -Homes for older youth and teens, youth with behavioral and mental health needs, sibling sets, pregnant/parenting teens, and Non-Minor Dependents. -Out of 500 homes throughout Alameda County, only 11 take teens and most of those homes are relatives who do not want to foster when their relative leaves. At the end of this meeting, ACAC representatives inquired about resources regarding the Administrator Certification process, and how to complete Administrator Training during COVID-19. LPA Fremont will research recent Provider Information Notices (PINs) and provide to the facility. This concluded CCL's Annual Review of the Alameda County Assessment Center. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was emailed to Administrator Mia Bucker-Preston with read receipt due to COVID-19 precautions. Administrator Bucker-Preston will sign all documents and return to LPA Fremont over email.
