met_with: Mickie Allen, Ivette Ochoa, Adam Weiner, Ivette Ochoa
narrative: On January 22, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sam Raissi and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Helga Wong conducted a pre-arranged pre-licensing tele-inspection. Aspiranet (Cherish Receiving Center) has submitted an application for a Transitional Shelter Care Facility (TSCF) license for a capacity of six (6) ambulatory children ages 0-17. The application, Plan of Operation and Program Statement have been reviewed and approved. This inspection was conducted with (Mickie Allen, Ivette Ochoa, and Administrator, Adam Weiner) and included observation of the following: 1. The facility and grounds are in good repair, free of mess, and free of obstructions. 2. There is adequate indoor activity space and materials. 3. Chemicals are stored in a locked cabinet. 4. Locked and centrally stored medications observed. Observed medication logs and discussed procedures for psychotropic medications. 5. First aid kit complete 6. Adequate storage space observed. 7. Individual beds are in good repair, equipped with good springs, clean mattresses and pillows observed. Individual beds and crib were observed with appropriate clean linens in good repair. Adequate supply of additional bedding and linens observed. 8. Facility has three (3) client bedrooms, all located on one single level. Bedrooms are accommodating of all required furnishings. 9. Adequate food storage space observed. Supply of two days of perishable foods and a week of nonperishable foods observed upon inspection. 10. Weekly menu are accessible to clients. 11. Dining room equipped with large table and chairs accommodating all clients. 12. There are three (3) full restrooms in this facility, all are operable. 13. Hot water measured within required range (kitchen sink). (Administrator measured water temperature at 109 degrees Fahrenheit). 14. All smoke detectors were tested by a fire inspector and appear to be in proper working order. 15. Carbon monoxide detector observed. 16. Fire extinguishers properly charged. 17. Adequate supply of additional bedding and linens observed. 18. Facility maintains a current fire certificate. 19. Sharp objects are stored in locked cabinet. 20. Appropriate forms are posted in view of facility clients. 21. Facility does not have any open bodies of water. 22. No firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. The following items were discussed and reviewed by LPA and LPM during Inspection: 1.LIC 500 reviewed to ensure appropriate staffing ratios, including Administrator, Social Work personnel, and Direct Care staff. 2. Personnel files obtained/reviewed to ensure staff meet regulatory requirements. All appropriate personnel who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemptions. Personnel Files are retained at the office and are available to the department for review upon request. 3. Facility procedures for 30-day updates to CCLD regarding participant Overstay logs discussed 4. Facility is to ensure all clients considered for future placement have been assessed as meeting placement eligibility requirements. Facility has process in place to contact authorized representatives to ensure assessment for clients' continued placement. On this date, Cherish Receiving Center is recommended for licensure on a provisional basis (pending fire clearance approval). Facility will be licensed for a capacity of six (6) (MALE/FEMALE) clients ages zero (0) through seventeen (17). Facility accepts only ambulatory clients. A copy of this report was sent to Adam Weiner.

On February 5, 2021, at 3: PM Regional Manager (RM) Nelson Martinez, and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Helga Wong, and Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sam Raissi met with Aspiranet Facility Representatives (FR). Vernon Brown, Mickie Allen, and Laurie Walsh via Microsoft Teams tele-visit. Aspiranet operates an unlicensed transitional shelter care facility commonly known as Cherish Receiving Center, located at Baldwin Street, Salinas, California, for temporary placement of foster children. The purpose of the meeting was to clarify the next steps to obtain licensure. The following terms and conditions were addressed: - Essential Terms: Review and process to sign and submit ET's (wet signature required) back to the Community Care Licensing San Jose Regional Office ( N. First St. Ste 350, San Jose, CA 95131) Attn: Nelson Martinez or Helga Wong. - Overstay report and Population reports monthly (distinguishing clients per placing agency and county): The Licensee shall provide a monthly written report to the CCLD where more than one child in care has overstayed the 72 hour limit in any given month, and where any child in care has overstayed the 72 hour limit by 48 hours or more, as set forth in Operation Standards, 84468.4. FR agreed to submit timely submission of Overstay and Population reports, no later than the 5th of each month and distinguishing reports for the 3 counties they serve. - Incident Report requirements: Upon the occurrence, during the operation of the facility, of any of the events as specified Reporting Requirements, 80061 (1-2) a report shall be made to the licensing agency within the agency's next working day during its normal business hours. In addition, a written report containing the information specified in (2) shall be submitted to the licensing agency within seven days following the occurrence of such event. For further information, refer to Operation Standards, 84061. A copy of this report will be emailed to Aspiranet Chief Executive Officer, Vernon Brown and to be signed and sent back to LPA Raissi to confirm receipt.

On 12/8/23 at 10: AM, a meeting was coordinated between Department of Social Services representatives, Aspiranet, Monterey (MC), San Benito (SBC), and Santa Cruz Counties (SCC), and Cherish Receiving Center Representatives. The attendees were as follows: Nelson Martinez - Regional Manager, Community Care Licensing (RM) Helga Wong - Licensing Program Manager, Community Care Licensing (LPM) Paul Simien - Licensing Program Analyst, Community Care Licensing (LPA) Alicia Bernstein - Manager of Placement Support Services, Family Intake and Engagement Unit Chadwyck Moore - Associate Governmental Program Analyst Roderick Franks - Assistant Director, Monterey County Lori Medina - Director of Social Services, Monterey County Eva Jeronimo - Deputy Director, Monterey County Jackie Chavez - FCS Program Manager, Monterey County Edward Juarez-Lefevre - Management Analyst III Gloria Carroll - Division Director, Santa Cruz County Joshua Mercier - Deputy Director, San Benito County Jyotti Pannu - Core Divison Director, Aspiranet Vernon Brown - CEO, Aspiranet Laurie Walsh - COO, Aspiranet Adam Weiner - Core Program Director, Aspiranet During the meeting the attendees discussed the Cherish Receiving Center (CRC) Annual Review Responses. County and Aspiranet representatives were notified that CRC's License expires in February 12, 2024 and that an extension must be formerly requested before then. Dept. of Social Services representatives suggested the request be submitted as soon as possible. Continued on LIC809C... County representatives discussed the action MC, SBC, SCC has taken to lower overstays at the receiving centers. Including working with providers to increase ISFC (Intensive Treatment Foster Care) Resource Family Homes (RFH), efforts to increase relative placements, focusing on converting relative placements into continual RFHs, various methods to increase RFHs, and providing wrap around services for current ISFC/RFHs. Countty representatives expressed that despite increased efforts to decrease use of CRC there are many challenges they encounter and that CRC will continue to be needed. Aspiranet representatives discussed the coordination/partnership it has with the Counties (MC, SBC, SCC), highlighted the successes and challenges of operating crc, reiterated the challenges the Counties are facing, and the continued need for CRC. Aspiranet and County representatives stated the intention to renew CRC's license. The meeting was adjourned at 12: PM

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Paul Simien made an unannounced visit to the above listed facility to inform them of the findings for the above listed allegations. LPA met with Adam Weiner, Administrator (ADM) at 9: AM on 4/5/24. Due to LPA Simien only being able to interview one person involved in the incident, it was determined that the allegations listed above are unsubstantiated. LPA attempted to contact the other individual involved in the incident via their social worker but as of 4/5/24 has not gotten a response. LPA was able to contact an individual that witnessed the incident, but they declined to be interviewed. The facility attempted to send incident reports (IR) to San Jose Children's Residential Regional Office (RO) but RO didn't receive them due to server issues at the facility. The facility re-sent the IRs when informed of this. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are UNSUBSTANTIATED. As a result of this visit, there were no title 22 deficiencies observed. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to ADM. UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

narrative: On February 28, 2024, at 3:30PM, a meeting was held between Community Care Licensing (CCL), San Jose Regional Office and Facility Representatives. The attendees were as follows: Nelson Martinez - Regional Manager, Community Care Licensing (RM) Helga Wong - Licensing Program Manager, Community Care Licensing (LPM) Adam Weiner- Core Program Director, Aspiranet Ivette Ochoa, Core Program Supervisor, Aspiranet Gabriela Berteaud, Program Coordinator, Aspiranet Facility Representative requested this meeting with CCL to discuss overstays at the facility. The past few months, there was an increase on overstays at the facility due to limited placement availability for the County. CCL suggested to the facility to submit incident reports on overstays include daily discussion notes with the County on their search with placement plan and have open discuss with the County on additional resources for the clients in care. CCL provided information on Technical CDSS Assistance Call if the facility need additional support for their clients and County. The meeting was adjourned at 4: PM

On 3/3/25 at 10: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Paul Simien and Omar Sawyer conducted an unannounced visit to the above facility. The purpose of this visit was to conduct the required annual inspection. LPA met with Adam Weiner, Administrator (ADM) at the above facility to conduct the required annual inspection. LPAs reviewed five staff files and completed plant inspection and disaster preparedness sections of the CARE tool. No deficiencies were cited at this time. The inspection is not complete at this time. LPA conducted an exit interview and a copy of this report was emailed ADM.

On 3/5/25 at 10: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Paul Simien and Omar Sawyer conducted an unannounced visit to the above facility. The purpose of this visit was to conduct the required annual inspection. LPA met with Adam Weiner, Administrator (ADM) at the above facility to conduct the required annual inspection. LPAs completed Emergency Intervention, Operation, Staff and Client record sections of the CARE tool. LPAs interviewed three staff members. No clients were interviewed due to no clients being in care at the facility. At this time, the inspection is complete. Five technical assistances were issued. LPA conducted an exit interview and a copy of this report was emailed ADM.

On July 31, 2023, Community Care Licensing met with several Riverside County agencies, via Microsoft Teams, to discuss the review of the Riverside County Transitional Shelter Plan of Operations and Program Statement edits and revisions submitted to Community Care Licensing on April 26, 2022. Children's Residential Program Licensing Program Manager, Natasha Dunlap, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Darlene Oseguera, Larry Fluharty, California Foster Care Ombudsperson, Systems of Care Analyst, Gina Jones, Provider Policy Implementation Unit Manager, Alicia Bernstein, met with Deputy Director, Dana Young, Administrator, Heidi Lombardi, Administrator Analyst Ross Jenell and Administrative Service Manager, Nicole Ford. During the meeting the following was discussed: revisions to Application and Supporting Documents, Plan of Operation, Program Statement, Core Services and Supports and possible name change. The opportunity for questions about the revisions was provided to facility representatives with a summarized review of revisions. The 2nd revised plan of operation and program statement, and any application and supportive documentation will be due on August 30, 2023 (per facility request). Children with developmental disabilities should be checked in this section as the program statement says the facility takes children with developmental disabilities. In this section under "other" please add parenting minors as you indicate you want to be licensed for this population in your program statement and will need to include those sections of the Operating standards that apply. narrative: On November 09, 2023, Community Care Licensing met with several Riverside County agencies, via Microsoft Teams, to discuss the review of the Riverside County Transitional Shelter Plan of Operations and Program Statement edits and revisions submitted to Community Care Licensing on April 26, 2022. Children's Residential Program Regional Manager, LaCresha Cook, Licensing Program Manager, Natasha Dunlap, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Darlene Oseguera, Systems of Care Analyst, Gina Jones, Provider Policy Implementation Unit Manager, Alicia Bernstein, met with Deputy Director, Allison Donahoe, Administrator, Heidi Lombardi, Administrator Analyst Jenell Ross and Administrative Service Manager, Nicole Ford. During the meeting the following was discussed: revisions to Application and Supporting Documents, Plan of Operation, Program Statement, Core Services and Supports and possible name change. The opportunity for questions about the revisions was provided to facility representatives with a summarized review of revisions. The revised plan of operation and program statement, and any application and supportive documentation will be due on November 27, 2023 (per facility request). The following is a summary of the review of the revisions to the Plan of Operation/ Program Statement completed by LPA Darlene Almaraz-Oseguera, Systems of Care (SOC) Policy Analyst Gina Jones,Family Intake and Engagement Unit, Adele Carlson and California Foster Care Ombudsperson, Larry Fluharty. CCL Review: Pink SOC Review: Green Family Intake and Engagement Unit Orange: Foster Care Ombudsman: Blue Part I Program Identification Part II Program Population, Services and Capabilities Part III Program Narrative A. PROGRAM DESCRIPTION Sec 3. PROGRAM DESCRIPTION, PURPOSE, METHODS GOALS In this section you mention several times that you are designed to provide care and therapeutic services up to 90 days from date of admission and site the Health & Safety code 1502.3. We recommend instead that you be consistent throughout with the use of the wording in the Operating Standards for Transitional Shelter Care Facilities (TrSCFs), February 2023, section 86622 (l) Plan of operation which states "The plan of operation shall provide that no child may stay in the facility longer than 72 hours...". As all counties are working with their local system of care to reduce reliance on shelters, 72 hours is the goal of Transitional Shelter Care facilities. Pg 26. In this section, you briefly discuss services, please expand to include more about the type of therapeutic activities, counseling and services to families, transition services and wraparound, that are evidence based and trauma informed (Provide a summary of your services here as discussed in section 5 etc.). How will the facility support the differing needs of children and their families including LGBTQ+, those with developmental disabilities, CSEC youth, pregnant and parenting youth, those under six years of age, those needing STRTP level of care and those being removed from their home for the first time. The information provided needs more development. Sec 4. PLANNED ACTIVITIES/USE OF COMMUNITY RESOURCES Pg 27 you discuss how the facility will partner with the case carrying social worker to provide access to community resources. List all the community resources available in your area. In section Please explain what these agencies are and what are the services they will provide. For example, what kind of agency is Faith in Motion? the family resource center and what services will they and the community college provide? List them out. create more of a chart with types of service and contact information, and how will these resources be used to support the populations you are serving at your facility? What are your community resources for youth with developmental disabilities- name the regional center etc, LGBTQ+, Pregnant and parenting youth, CSEC, children under six and families etc.? The resource list should be more fully developed for your area. WIC 16001. Please clarify extracurricular activities that include but are not limited to access to computer technology and the internet, consistent with the child's age, maturity, developmental level, sexual orientation, and gender identity and expression. Visits and contact with siblings, family members, and relatives, social contacts with people outside ethe foster care system including teachers, coaches, religious or spiritual members, mentors and friends. Please clarify the activities suitable for under six. Pg 28- activities that meet needs identified in the youth's case plan. This should include not only case plan but individual program plan (for those youth receiving regional center services) p. Exclusion from Extracurricular Activities based on psychotropic meds. FYR violation and discrimination based on a disability. Sec 5. PERSONAL SERVICES/PROGRAMS OFFERED Disaster response Do mention relocation sites and safe temporary accommodations for clients, please provide more information about where are the relocation sites? 86623© please explain how the licensee shall instruct all clients, age and abilities permitting, in their duties and responsibilities under the disaster response plan. In your runaway response section you provide the ratio of staff to children so could label this information so its easier to find or also add it to your program description section. Please include as stated in 86665.5 © that if the children require special care and supervision because of age, behavior or other factors, the number of on duty child care staff shall be increased. What culturally relevant trauma informed services will youth have access to and how the facility will be culturally responsive? Please provide more information on What kind of cultural and religious groups will you connect youth to? For example you say individual and group activities "are culturally responsive" or "support culture, ethnicity and identities of the youth" , Please explain how. For example how will you ensure your facility is accepting of all youth? LGBTQ+, different race and ethnicities, those with disabilities etc. H& S Code 1522.45; 86678.2 how will you ensure fair and equal access to all services, placement, care and treatment and benefits. How will facility ensure after assessments, services are received timely? Including to a mental health provider? Please ensure what's discussed in section 5 regarding screenings and assessments aligns with section 6. Pg 31 under intervention and practices "screening and assessment", the third sentence says " after assessment, " within one week, referrals are made to mental health providers when necessary." Please clarify, given this is a three-day facility, please provide a more expedited time frame to meet the needs of the child while at the facility. Per 86668.1 screenings to identify the child's mental and medical needs shall happen within 24 hours. How will you meet the needs of the child as identified through screening and assessments with reasonable promptness and enable timely transitions from the facility. WIC 16001.9. Please note this time frame for mental health screenings is different in section 6 where you say 24 hours. Sec MEDICAL/DENTAL Please clarify how screening and assessments are used. Are screenings used to initially identify needs that may trigger a more thorough assessment? What is the criteria for a more thorough assessment? Given the differing level of needs, why would all youth need an assessment? How will you ensure screening and assessments are trauma informed? ☐How are the screening and assessment procedures modified to meet the needs of youth with special health care needs? 86610.1- don't see ☐How will you ensure screening and assessments are trauma informed? - don't see this Please explain how the facility will ensure the health and safety of children during their entire stay at the facility, including a plan to ensure appropriate levels of care and supervision is provided as determined by the screenings and assessments OS 86622 ☐If separation from others is required how will the separation room be used in a trauma informed way for medical or mental health purposes? What will a separation room not be used for? 86675 (c) Page 33 2nd to the last paragraph: In above section it states that staff will evaluate if they can go on outing recreational outing based on if they are refusing psychotropic medications. This statement seems to be a contradiction. p. Medication storage: appears to conflict with CCL guidance for youth who can administer their own medication Sec TRANSPORTATION You state "communication is is maintained with the region "Please explain what you mean by "the region" You state that "while youth are staying at the facility staff will ensure there isn't a lapse in care services. " and "the decision for staff to transport a youth is dependent on both the availability of a vehicle and if staff are available, otherwise, the social worker is responsible for transporting the youth." In those situations where the social worker is responsible for transporting the youth how will the facility ensure this happens so there isn't a lapse in care services? A. ADMISSION/ASSESSMENT/DISCHARGE POLICIES AND PROCEDURES Sec 8. ADMISSION/INTAKE Pg 37 in the section titled "Prior to youth arrival" what does 7) mean WC does not utilize an admission form. This statement is confusing is this different than an admission agreement? consider deleting unless you think its necessary and explain what an admission form is. OS section 86668.1 says medical and mental health screening shall be performed by a licensed physician or designee, who is also a licensed professional. You state that social service supervisors I/II are not licensed professionals. Please explain how social service supervisors I/II will meet the OS requirements? If a screening indicates a more thorough assessment is needed. At intake you mention creating a child's file. How will you ensure all screening and assessments, including QI assessments and services needed and provided at the shelter, will be documented in the child's file? How will you ensure that information is entered timely, accurately and is complete in the child's file? Don't see this - Please explain commonality of need considerations for youth assessed as requiring STRTP level care. How will you ensure the safety of all children with differing level of needs? - don't see this what are the timeframe for responding to referring agencies regarding acceptance or rejection of referral - dont see this Please explain how the "weekly think together Thursday meetings", are described more -in your reporting requirements and continuous quality control section. and briefly describe here how these meetings will support the county placing agencys efforts to secure an immediate STRTP placement for a child assessed as meeting the applicable criteria for placement in an STRTP. Will there be a list of STRTPs that the county will have a relationship with for example? Sec 9. CLIENT PLANS (NEEDS AND SERVICES PLANS) /ASSESSMENTS Although you are not using a needs and services plan, how will the case plan be used and updated? Will this also be kept in the client folder? How will the facility ensure screening and assessments are documented? How will the facility ensure services provided meet the treatment needs of the child as assessed? Sec 10. DISCHARGE/REMOVAL You added information about working with the county with the transition plan and discharge. Please clarify contact information for State level TA calls as discussed on this website. Child-Specific Technical Assistance Calls Website - This website provides information on types of TA calls, resources for reducing barriers to placement for complex care youth, and funding. If these are the TA calls you are referring to, please add the provider or shelter staff familiar with the youth, will be on the call when needed (not just the case carrying social worker) Sec 11. VISITATION RULES AND POLICY Will the child have a prior meeting with the new placement or visit before being transferred? GENERAL POLICIES AFFECTING CHILDREN PLACED Sec 13. DISCIPLINE POLICIES The plan of operation discusses how children, and authorized representatives shall receive copies of discipline policies and procedures. Please explain how Signed copies of the discipline policies and procedures are maintained in child's files. Health and Safety Codes (HSC) Section 1501, 1531,- don't see this Page 44 when discussing physical control techniques, and that the WC staff will be trained in CPI, nonviolent crisis intervention...Please spell out the acronym CPI - is this evidence based? Please provide citation. Please provide a description of how trauma-informed practices are embedded in the provider's discipline procedures, as well as how discipline policies account for the nature of youths' trauma (including specialized populations). Health and safety Code, Section 1522. Please clarify that calling or threatening to call law enforcement is prohibited as a form of discipline 86672. Sec 14. EMERGENCY INTERVENTION PLAN Pg 42. Although you have begun to develop your EIP and have provided a list of early interventions and expected outcomes, and have stated you are not using manual restraints, Please explain the process more for having the Special investigations unit and peace officers to assist in your emergency intervention plan. Is this verbal Judo: the gentle art of persuasion and post certification" model approved by a behavioral specialist? You mention an LCSW only. How does the model follow the requirements of the OS section 86700, 86700.1, 86722, 86722.1.? note: In addition to techniques specified in Section 86700.1(a), how will you ensure that any emergency intervention technique not approved for use as part of the licensee's emergency intervention plan are not used at any time? 86700.1 (e ) please clarify Law enforcement must not be contacted as a substitute for effective care and supervision or the facility's approved continuum of emergency interventions. Please explain more about when you would involve law enforcement or not and how it will be used as a"last resort." 86722 (e )(B). Please add names of facility personnel including security personnel trained to use emergency interventions. (86722)(d)(1). Pg 45- please clarify the community resources listed and how they will assist. Pg When you say ongoing training is required for all WC staff in this section, please clarify what kind of training you are referring to. CHILDREN'S COMPLAINT/GRIEVANCE PROCEDURES p. Seem to be conflating CCL and Ombudsperson's office. Please ensure that the facility manager meets the following requirements: OS 86665(q) we need to see they meet minimum education and experience requirements in the OS. Os Missing duty statement for social supervisor I. The temporary community services support representative is not found on the lic 500 nor the activity planner. Please indicate who is the manager on the lic 500 and duty statement as well as in the body of the text. Os 86669(a) requires a licensed physician or designee who is also a licensed professional to do screenings please clarify at intake and client medical assessment section as well as on the duty statements. Who does the assessments?. are they a licensed professional? Sec 23. JOB DESCRIPTIONS Sec 24. INSERVICE TRAINING FOR STAFF/ADMINISTRATOR Please explain the process for emergency intervention training orientation for new staff and ongoing training 86722- please clarify what is required for orientation vs annual training. Cultural competency and sensitivity; including but not limited to best practices for providing adequate care, services, and supports for children across diverse ethnic and racial background, as well as children identifying as lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, or nonbinary. - don't see ☐ Please describe your training on methods to behaviorally support children as appropriate for children impacted by trauma or child abuse and neglect; and- don't see ☐ please describe how your training includes best practices for addressing the permanence, well-being, and educational needs of children, including children with disabilities.- don't see In section The OS state the annual training plan shall include for each subject please provide the following: - don't see Title, subject matter Learning objectives and activities Number of hours per training Qualifications of trainer Training evaluation p. Why is youth rights ½ hour but RPPS is 2 hours? This is out of balance. OFCO rights trainings are typically 2 hours or more to cover FYBOR and RPPS. Sec 26. VOLUNTEERS- N/A Sec 27. CONTROL OF REAL PROPTERTY Sec 28. FACILITY SKETCH (LIC 999) Sec 25. ADMINISTRATION- cant read organizational chart Sec 29. BOARD OF DIRECTORS STATEMENT ADDITIONAL NOTES: Reporting Requirements and Continuous Quality Control- ok The System of Care and Reducing Reliance on Shelters Please create a summary timeline of how things occur at the facility from the first to last day of placement for the following areas: intake; screening and assessment; health, mental health, behavioral health, or other services as needed, CFT meeting, placement finding, and placement/discharge, reporting requirements. - see the timeline can you indicate what is planned on day 1-3? Please indicate how you will work with your local team to coordinate services in the timeline including schools, regional centers, BCBA and mental health providers and families. - Don't see p. Exclusion from Extracurricular Activities based on psychotropic meds. FYR violation and discrimination based on a disability. p. Medication storage: appears to conflict with CCL guidance for youth who can administer their own medication p. 41 rules Touch only Siblings (this may violate FY rights, it would be difficult to enforce and clinically backwards), getting dressed changing only in bathroom or shower p. Seem to be conflating CCL and Ombudsperson's office. Need to specify that these are separate and youth can complain to both confidentially and without fear of retaliation. p. Allowance. What is the plan if youth says longer than 3 days. This will happen. Need a plan for allowance if a youth is there more than a week. Ideally, youth should receive allowance for a week regardless of length of stay so that allowance is not an incentive to remain at the WC. p. Why is youth rights ½ hour but RPPS is 2 hours? This is out of balance. OFCO rights trainings are typically 2 hours or more to cover FYBOR and RPPS. In addition to the above information it was also discussed clarification of the fire clearance. The facility was advised by Regional Manager (RM) LaCresha Cook that CCL needed to know if the fire clearance was going to be for one or the four individual buildings/addresses. RM Cook also advised that if there were any staff fingerprints/clearances that were delayed 30 or more days or if the facility was having any issues with Guardian to please follow up with LPA or LPM to get those clearances expedited. It was also discussed clarification regarding a recommendation provided by Office of Foster Care Ombudsman (OFCO) in regard to client allowances. facility_name: HARMONY HAVEN CHILDREN AND YOUTH CENTER
narrative: On December 19, 2023, at 8:50am, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs), Darlene Almaraz-Oseguera and Emina Preciado, arrived at the facility for the purpose of conducting pre-licensing inspection at the facility. LPAs were greeted by facility administrator Heidi Lombardi. During the inspection, LPAs completed a health and safety assessment of cottages: 1, 2, 3, and 4 and gym inside and out. During the assessment LPAs observed that each cottage had two wings (A & B) and mirrors one another. Each wing has space for 7 placement's. Cottage #1 consists of 8 bedrooms, twin beds, closet and dresser space, desks, ample lighting, hygiene supplies, mattress covers, fitted and flat sheets, comforters, and pillows. Restroom with 8 sinks, 4 showers and 6 toilets. Kitchen area with a pantry for snacks. Dining room with tables and chairs for 8 clients. The smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and are in operable working order. The water temperature is no more than 120 degrees and there are no bodies of water on facility grounds. Each cottage has a family room with sofas and recreation space. Cottage #2 consists of 8 bedrooms, twin beds, closet and dresser space, desks, ample lighting, hygiene supplies, mattress covers, fitted and flat sheets, comforters, and pillows. Restroom with 8 sinks, 4 showers and 6 toilets. Kitchen area with a pantry for snacks. Dining room with tables and chairs for 8 clients. The smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and are in operable working order. The water temperature is no more than 120 degrees and no bodies of water. Family room with sofas and recreation space. Cottage #3 consists of 8 bedrooms, twin beds, closet and dresser space, desks, ample lighting, hygiene supplies, mattress covers, fitted and flat sheets, comforters, and pillows. Restroom with 8 sinks, 4 showers and 6 toilets. Kitchen area with a pantry for snacks. Dining room with tables and chairs for 8 clients. The smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and are in operable working order. The water temperature is no more than 120 degrees and there are no bodies of water. Family room with sofas and recreation space. This cottage also has 4 administrative office and staff lunch/break-room. Cottage #4 consists of 7 bedrooms, twin beds, closet and dresser space, desks, ample lighting, hygiene supplies, mattress covers, fitted and flat sheets, comforters, and pillows. Restroom with 8 sinks, 4 showers and 6 toilets. Kitchen area with a pantry for snacks. Dining room with tables and chairs for 8 clients. The smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and are in operable working order. The water temperature is no more than 120 degrees and there are no bodies of water. Family room with sofas and recreation space. This cottage also has one administrative office. Daily meals are prepared in a centralized kitchen and brought to each cottage. The laundry rooms are located in each cottage. There is a bulletin board in each cottage with all required documents posted; Personal rights, grievance procedures, emergency disaster plan, food menu, daily schedule, and activity schedule. Each cottage had its own medication office/staff office. The medications will be stored in a closet inside that office. Sharps and knives are also stored in the staff office. Cleaning supplies are all stored in a locked closet outside of each cottage. Based on observation, there are no deficiencies observed or corrections needed at this time, therefore the facility meets the Regulatory requirements. After a final file review, the facility will be submitted for licensure. Exit interview conducted a copy of this report was provided to Heidi Lombardi .

facility_name: HARMONY HAVEN CHILDREN AND YOUTH CENTER
narrative: On January 25, 2024, Community Care Licensing (CCL) met with Harmony Haven Children and Youth Center facility, via Microsoft Teams, to discuss the review of the Riverside County Transitional Shelter Plan of Operations and Program Statement revisions submitted to Community Care Licensing on December 15, 2024. Participants on the call were: CCL Riverside North Regional Manager LaCresha Cook, CCL Riverside South Regional Manager Natasha Dunlap, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Darlene Oseguera, Gina Jones Systems of Care Analyst, Alicia Bernstein Provider Policy Implementation Unit Manager, Ashley Bray Staff Service Manager II, Dana Young Deputy Director, Heidi Lombardi Administrator, Keisha Winder Admin Services Manager II, and Nicole Ford Administrative Service Manager. During the meeting the following was discussed: revisions to Application and Supporting Documents, Plan of Operation, Program Statement, Core Services and Supports, pool and gym (nearby but separate address), criminal record clearances for maintenance staff and security officers. The opportunity for questions about the revisions was provided to facility representatives with a summarized review of revisions. The revised plan of operation and program statement, and any application and supportive documentation will be due on February 07, 2024 (per facility request). The following is a summary of the review of the revisions to the Plan of Operation/ Program Statement completed by LPA Darlene Almaraz-Oseguera, Systems of Care (SOC) Policy Analyst Gina Jones, Family Intake and Engagement Unit, Adele Carlson and California Foster Care Ombudsperson, Larry Fluharty. Riverside County Transitional Shelter Care Facility - Program Statement /Plan of operation- System of Care Review Summary Are the peace officers, special investigations unit (SIU) apart of the staff? Do they go through staff training and evaluation? Are they listed on the LIC 500 and fingerprinted? Or how is there oversight of this unit by CCL? Is the Verbal Judo used by the SIU approved by the LCSW/behaviorist as part of the emergency intervention plan along with the CPI techniques? Section 15- Runaway Plan How is the runaway plan discussed with the youth's authorized representative at time of admission and how are they included in creating an individualized plan for those youth who need one? Not fully answered- please see 86722.2 (e) and 86722.2 (e) (1) (A) and (1)(B). Section 31 - Reporting Requirements and Continuous Quality Control For overstay reports, please include as it is written in OS 86661 (s)- "The licensee shall submit the report to the Department, through a process determined by the Department." At this time, please have the licensee email overstay and monthly reports to both licensing and the CCR performance mailbox: ccrperformance@dss.ca.gov.

facility_name: HARMONY HAVEN CHILDREN AND YOUTH CENTER
met_with: Harmony Haven Children and Youth Center Regional Manager (RM) Heidi Lombardi
narrative: Confidential interviews disclosed that the staff (RM1, RM2, and S1) did not speak to C1 inappropriately and spoke to C1 with respect. Confidential interviews indicated that facility staff (RM1, RM2, and S1) bribed C1 with money. Confidential interviews indicated that C1 had video recordings of RM1 and other facility staff disclosing clients confidential in front of C1 and other clients. Confidential interviews revealed that RM1, RM2, and S1 did not offer C1 one hundred dollars to review the cell phone recordings. Confidential interviews disclosed that RM1, RM2, and S1 requested that C1 share the cell phone recordings. Confidential interviews revealed that RM1 and RM2 offered a gift card incentive to C1 if C1 was being honest. Confidential interviews indicated that C1 requested one hundred dollars to share the video with RM1, RM2, and S1. Confidential interviews disclosed that C1 had a cell phone video recording of RM1 and other facility staff disclosing client confidentiality in front of C1. Confidential interviews indicated that C1 was unable to share video recordings. LPA could not determine if staff bribed C1, whether C1 asked for a monetary gift to show recordings, or if there were some recordings of staff conversation. The Department also received an allegation that the staff (RM1, RM2, and S1) made false allegations against minors (C1) in care. Confidential interviews revealed that C1 was residing at the facility because RM1, RM2, and S1 mentioned that C1 was recruiting for prostitution and attempting to get other clients to do things against their will. Confidential interviews stated that C1 was telling everyone that they (C1) were a "pimp." Confidential interviews indicated that facility staff (RM1, RM2, and S1) did not mention that C1 was recruiting other clients for prostitution. Confidential interviews indicated that there were no false allegations made against C1 recruiting other female clients for prostitution. Confidential interviews revealed that RM1, RM2, and S1 did make false allegations against C1. Other confidential interviews indicated that facility staff (RM1, RM2, and S1) did not make false allegations against C1. Confidential interviews denied the allegation. Based on inconsistent confidential interviews and facility record review, the allegations that staff (RM, RM2, and S1) made inappropriate comments towards minors (C1) in care, that the staff (RM, RM2, and S1) bribed a minor (C1) in care, and that the staff (RM, RM2, and S1) made false allegations against minors (C1) in care are unsubstantiated. The allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Harmony Haven Children and Youth Center Regional Manager (RM) Heidi Lombardi.

narrative: The alleged victim (C1) did not cooperate with the CCL investigation. However, other supporting documentation indicated that an internal investigation regarding the officer's behavior was also conducted. The internal investigation reported that multiple interviews with staff and residents did not provide any statements validating the alleged misconduct. In addition, it was reported that C1 provided inconsistent statements, and there was no recorded evidence to support the allegation. Furthermore, it was reported that C1 later recanted their statement, admitting to making a false allegation due to a personal dislike of the police deputy. This was supported by a confidential interview in which another client disclosed that they had been asked to lie about the deputy's behavior. Based on confidential interviews and records review, the allegation that minors (C1) are being inappropriately touched while in care is unsubstantiated. The allegation may have happened or be valid, but there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report, the LIC 811, and appeal rights were explained and given to the Regional Manager Heidi Lombardi.

facility_name: HARMONY HAVEN CHILDREN AND YOUTH CENTER
narrative: On February 25, 2025, at 10: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jessica Peete met with Harmony Haven Children and Youth Center Administrator Heidi Lombardi to conduct a follow-up visit regarding staff (S1) background clearance. During the document review conducted by LPA Peete on 02/24/2025, it was found that S1 did not have a criminal background clearance on file. LPA received information that S1 was hired on 05/04/2023. The Administrator confirmed that S1's clearances were not received and that S1 last worked at the facility on February 21, 2025. Based on a review of staff records and a staff interview, S1 did not have a criminal record clearance prior to working at the facility; therefore, the facility is being cited for violation of Title 22, Division California Code of Regulations (CCR) 80019(e)(2) Criminal Record Clearance which states (e) All individuals subject to a criminal record review pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1522 shall prior to working, residing or volunteering in a licensed facility (2) Obtain a California clearance or a criminal record exemption as required by the Department... An immediate civil penalty in the amount of $500.00 has been assessed for allowing S1 to work before a criminal background clearance was filed. A copy of this report, the LIC 421BG Civil Penalty Assessment Background Check, was discussed and provided to Administrator Heidi Lombardi, along with appeal rights and the LIC Confidential Names List.

narrative: On June 6, 2025, at 1:02 p.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jose Gonzalez met with Harmony Haven Children and Youth Center Transitional Shelter Care (TrSC) Residential Care Supervisor, Marivel Ocegueda, to deliver a report on case management deficiencies. Based on the information received, the facility has been using handheld metal detector wands on clients without approval from CCL. The facility is being cited for violation of Operating Standards (OS) Plan of Operation (e) any changes in the plan of operation that affect the services to clients shall be subject to licensing agency approval and shall be reported as specified in Section 86661 which poses a potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to clients in care. A copy of the report was discussed and provided, along with appeal rights, to the Harmony Haven Children and Youth Center Residential Care Supervisor, Marivel Ocegueda.

facility_name: HARMONY HAVEN CHILDREN AND YOUTH CENTER
narrative: Confidential interviews indicated that the clients would attend school. Confidential interviews indicated that some clients attend school by participating in online classes. Confidential interviews revealed that some clients are on home study/ independent study, and that the clients pick up school packets from their school. Confidential interviews with three clients who attend public schools. The Department also received an allegation that staff (unknown) do not ensure that there is a sufficient amount of food in the group home. Confidential interviews revealed that staff (unknown) do not provide the clients (unknown) enough food. Confidential interviews indicated that staff purchase enough food for clients and staff. Confidential interviews revealed that clients have access to fruits and snacks throughout the day. Confidential interviews disclosed that the clients are served breakfast, lunch, and dinner. During the visit, LPA observed three clients eating eggs and tatter tots. LPA also observed an adequate amount of food in the refrigerator, freezer, and pantry. The Department also received an allegation that the staff (unknown) prohibit children (unknown) from attending church. Confidential interviews revealed that staff did not allow the children (unknown) to attend church services. Confidential interviews indicated that facility staff did not prohibit the clients from attending church services. Confidential interviews revealed that on Saturday and Sunday, the facility staff walk through the cottages and ask the clients who want to attend church services. Confidential interviews disclosed that the clients would inform facility staff that they want to participate, and the clients attend church services on Sundays. Confidential interviews denied the allegation. The Department also received an allegation that the staff (unknown) do not maintain the facilities first aid supplies. Confidential interviews revealed that staff did not maintain enough first aid supplies in the cottage. Confidential interviews indicated that first aid kits are stocked with Band-Aids and other first aid supplies. Confidential interviews disclosed that facility staff maintain the first aid kit supplied. Confidential interviews revealed that a first aid kit is kept inside the staff office. Confidential interviews disclosed that additional first aid supplies are kept in Cottage 3A's medical supply room. LPA observed a 3B's first aid kit inside the staff office. LPA observed additional first aid supplies inside Cottage 3A's medical supply room. ******CONTINUED on LIC 9099c****** Based on confidential interviews and facility record review, the allegations that staff (unknown) do not ensure that children (unknown) attend school, that staff (unknown) do not ensure that there is a sufficient amount of food in the group home, that the staff (unknown) prohibit children (unknown) from attending church, and that the staff (unknown) do not maintain the facilities first aid supplies are unsubstantiated. The allegations may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Harmony Haven Children and Youth Center Regional Manager (RM) Brian Satterfield.

narrative: Confidential interviews revealed that the minor (C1) grabbed the staff member (S1) by the hair and dragged S1 towards the bathroom. Confidential interviews disclosed that the minor (C1) hit and kicked the staff member (S1). Confidential interviews indicated that the staff member (S2) intervened and got between minor (C1) and staff member (S1) to stop C1 from assaulting S1. Confidential interviews revealed that minor (C1) hit and kicked staff members (S1 and S2) when S2 intervened. Confidential interviews indicated that the staff member (S2) convinced minor (C1) to release staff member (S1). The Department also received allegations that staff members (S1 and S2) barricaded a minor (C1) in their room and staff members (S1 and S2) threw items at a minor (C1) resulting in an injury. Confidential interviews indicated that staff members (S1 and S2) barricaded a minor (C1) in their room. Confidential interviews disclosed that the staff member (S1) held the room door shut and prevented minor (C1) from walking out of the room. Confidential interviews disclosed that minor (C1) did not know why staff member (S1) kept minor (C1) in the room. Confidential interviews indicated that staff member (S1) threw a metal water bottle at minor (C1) and that the water bottle struck the minor (C1) in the face. Confidential interviews revealed that the water bottle left a bruise on minor's (C1) face. Confidential interviews indicated that the staff members (S1 and S2) did not barricade minor (C1) in the room. Confidential interviews indicated that minor (C1) was walking in and out of the room. Confidential interviews revealed that minor (C1) attempted to barricade themselves and lock staff members (S1 and S2) out of the room. Confidential interviews indicated that staff members (S1 and S2) did not throw a water bottle at minor (C1). Confidential interviews revealed that minor (C1) grabbed a water bottle and poured the water on staff member's (S1) head. Confidential interviews revealed that minor (C1) grabbed another water bottle and poured out the water on staff member (S1) a second time. Based on confidential interviews and facility record review, the allegations that minors (C1) are not accorded dignity or respect in their relationships with staff (S1 and S2), and that staff members (S1 and S2) barricaded a minor (C1) in their room and staff members (S1 and S2) threw items at a minor (C1) resulting in an injury are unsubstantiated. The allegations may have happened or are valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Harmony Haven Children and Youth Center Regional Manager (RM) Brian Satterfield.

narrative: On Wednesday 6/2/21 at 10:30AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted an announced prelicensing inspection at the facility site. LPA met with Core Program Supervisor Damian Nomellini and Administrator/Core Program Director Monique Nervis. COVID-19 safety precautions were taken during visit, including screening, sanitizer, disinfectant, and mask-wearing. There are two care staff and one child present. The child was asleep in the large bedroom. At 10:33AM, LPA conducted a tour of the facility and grounds. The facility is a blue, two-story, historical house that has received a fire clearance for 4 ambulatory only youth ages 0-17. The main entrance is on the side near the parking lot. The front entrance opens to the street. LPA observed the street to be a somewhat busy main road. The upstairs consists of the administrator's office, the nurse's office, and the storage room, and the downstairs consists of two double-occupancy bedrooms, the living room, kitchenette, and staff office space, hallway, bathroom with only shower/tub (no toilet) and laundry, and bathroom with no shower or tub (only toilet, sink, changing table). All rooms upstairs are kept locked. The upstairs offices are both clean and tidy, and the nurse's office is stocked with first aid supplies. The first aid kit is centrally stored in the black cabinet in the living room. A sign in sheet and a no contact thermometer are ready for screening upon entry and placed on a table near the main entrance. The locked upstairs storage room is organized and currently holds plenty of school supplies, backpacks, hygiene products, toilet paper, paper towels, and clothing of different sizes and styles to be appropriate for all groups of youth. The client files are kept in a locked cabinet in the storage room. All rooms and areas downstairs are tidy and free of obstruction. Both bedrooms are double-occupancy with single beds fitted with mattress pads. The facility stores a crib under one of the beds in the small bedroom that is to be set up and used as appropriate for admitted youth. Core Program Supervisor stated the crib is usually set up in the living room rather than the large bedroom so that staff can have eyes on the youth at all times. LPA recommends the crib be placed in a bedroom, per OS Section 84087(a)(4)-(5). The facility has plenty of cleaning solutions, detergents, and disinfectants stored in locked cabinets in the shower/laundry room. Bath linens are stored in this room as well. The bathroom with toilet is clean and in sanitary condition. Broom and mop are stored in a closet under the stairs. Craft supplies, toys, and entertainment are available for youth of varying ages. Furniture is sturdy and in good condition. The kitchenette is stocked with utensils and dishware to serve the intended population. There is currently perishable and nonperishable food that is in date and in supply to meet the needs of youth in care. Food items were date labeled. At 10:33AM, LPA observed that the stairs to the upstairs are very steep. Administrator stated that she needs to walk at an angle in order to support herself up the stairs. LPA also had to walk at an angle. The facility has placed gates at the top and bottom that could secure in place but did not have locks. Two signs were posted at the bottom of the stairs: one read "Children are NOT allowed on the 2nd floor if not accompanied by staff"; and the second read "Steep Stairs Use Hand Rail." At 10:40AM, LPA observed there to be a small, locked door in the storage room. Administrator and Core Program Supervisor were unable to locate the key to the door and stated they did not know what was behind the door but assumed it was additional storage. At 10:45AM, LPA observed there to be an attic access point in the middle of the upstairs hallway. There is no drop ladder and the door can be opened by pushing up while stepping on a ladder. A ladder was leaning against the wall at the end of the hall. Core Program Supervisor confirmed that there is no lock on the door. At 10:47AM, LPA inspected the balcony access door at the end of the upstairs hallway. There is an alarm on the door but it was observed to not be working. No alarm could be heard from upstairs or downstairs. At 10:49AM, LPA observed an exposed telephone cord poking out of the ceiling in the upstairs hallway. Core Program Supervisor stated he did not know what the purpose of the cord was. LPA recommends concealing the cord. At 10:50AM, LPA inspected the facility grounds and shed in the side yard. The shed is used as extra storage and is kept locked. LPA observed a painter's spatula near the shed and requested Core Program Supervisor remove the item from the yard. At 10:51AM, LPA observed the unused entrance on the left side of the house (facing the street). The porch is sturdy but not otherwise well maintained, as there is a large amount of insects and webbing on the wall, railing, and around the porch light. At 10:55AM, LPA observed there to be a white mattress and bag in the yard. Core Program Supervisor stated it may belong to a homeless individual. The homeless camp set up is on facility grounds. There is no fencing surrounding the lot, but there is a fence surrounding neighboring lots behind the facility. There is no physical barrier between the outdoor activity space on the facility grounds and the main road on which the facility is located. It is a potential concern if unknown individuals frequently camp on the grounds, as this has been observed at previous visits. At 11AM, LPA observed in the smaller bedroom that there is a small flat screen television mounted above the head on the bed nearest the street side of the house. Above the television is a mounted shelf with a DVD player on it. It is a potential concern that this television placement is not the most ideal and may be a hazard. LPA strongly recommends a more suitable location. Core Program Supervisor stated the facility already has plans to move the television to above the dresser so it is viewable from both beds. At 11:10AM, LPA observed that one of the downstairs windows in the living room was broken and boarded up with cardboard and tape inside and wood on the outside. The facility had notified LPA beforehand that this was caused by one of the youth in placement the week prior to the visit. Please review OS Section Buildings and Grounds, Line (a). At 11:14AM, the smoke detectors were tested. LPA requested that the sleeping youth be gently notified a few minutes prior to testing the alarm. LPA was in the upstairs administrator's office and observed that the alarm was fairly faint from the office. LPA stood in the upstairs hallway and noticed it was still faint and that the upstairs alarm was not beeping and appeared to not be synced with the downstairs alarm. Please review OS Section 80045, Line (c)(2)(A) and applicable Health and Safety Code sections related to fire clearances and smoke detectors. LPA recommends ensuring the alarms are synced. At 11:28AM, LPA inspected the first aid kit and observed the first aid manual and tweezers to be missing. At 11:35AM, Core Program Supervisor searched the nurse's office and confirmed the facility did not have a manual or tweezers. Please review OS Section Health-Related Services, Line (f)(1). The following items need to be completed in order for the facility to be granted full licensure. A follow-up virtual inspection will be conducted to verify completion. The follow-up visit is anticipated to be conducted within four weeks from today. 1. Notify LPA once access is obtained to the locked storage space in the upstairs storage room. 2. Notify LPA of the plan to secure the attic access door to ensure it is only accessible to authorized staff. 3. Notify LPA when the alarm on the upstairs balcony access door is in working condition. 4. Notify LPA when the side porch has been cleared of webbing and insects. 5. Notify LPA of plan/statement addressing unknown/unauthorized individuals camping of facility grounds. 6. Notify LPA once the mounted television in the small bedroom has been relocated to above the dresser. 7. Notify LPA once the downstairs window has been repaired. 8. Notify LPA of the plan to see if it is possible to sync the smoke detectors to ensure the alarm can be heard throughout the house. 9. Notify LPA once the first aid kit is complete with the first aid manual and tweezers. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report left with Core Program Supervisor Damian Nomellini and Administrator/Core Program Director Monique Nervis, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On Thursday 9/16/21 at 9:27AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a visit at the facility for a Post-Licensing Inspection. LPA met with Core Program Supervisor Damian Nomellini and informed of the purpose of the visit. Prior notice of the visit was provided to conduct a screening. Safety precautions were taken including mask-wearing and hand hygiene. There were three staff present, including Core Program Supervisor, and two youth in care. LPA observed the youth to be in good spirits and engaging well with staff. Staff were knowledgeable of facility procedures, reporting requirements, and trauma-informed care practices. LPA toured the facility and observed the site to be clean, in good repair, and free of obstructions and hazards. There are no bodies of water on the premises, and Program Supervisor confirmed there are no firearms. The exterior and entry way of grounds were well-maintained and clear of debris. The entry space has staff desks, and there is a staff office and a nurse's room upstairs. There is also a locked storage room upstairs. Resident records are stored in a file cabinet in the upstairs storage room. Staff files are maintained at the administrative office, but copies are kept on site as well. The first aid kits were stored downstairs and were observed to be complete. License, facility sketch, and personal rights were posted in the facility. Room temperature was comfortable and within permitted range. Hot water in the bathroom was measured to be both too high and too low. Initially and for about a minute, the water temperature reached high temperatures and for at least a second reached as high as F and was steaming. It then lowered and would not go above F, and the water pressure dropped significantly. Core Program Supervisor stated maintenance was working on the sink this morning and they would be called back to resume their work. For now, because the system appears to have malfunctioned rather than to be consistently delivering too hot water, LPA advises, per Operating Standards (OS) Section 80088, that the facility post a sign cautioning of hot water temperatures at the sink and continue monitoring temperatures. The kitchen and living room area was observed to be clean and tidy. The facility keeps clean and appropriate games and activities for all age groups. The kitchen space was sanitary. Chemicals are stored in a locked cabinet in the laundry/shower room. Medications and sharps are stored in a locked cabinet behind the staff desks downstairs. There are two double-occupancy bedrooms. Beds are single beds with clean linens. The facility has extra bed linens in storage. LPA inspected resident records and staff files. Records were complete and contained necessary forms and/or equivalents of required forms. LPA observed the following items and issued advisories per the facility Operating Standards (OS). 1) Files for staff S1, S2, and S3 (See LIC Confidential Names) are missing first aid certificates, LIC Criminal Record Statement, and LIC Statement Acknowledging Requirement to Report Child Abuse. LPA advises, per OS Section 80066(a) Personnel Records, that all staff files are updated to include current forms and certificates and be made available at the facility site. 2) Staff health screenings and TB tests are not maintained at the facility site. Also, the staff training record maintained on site does not include training record for all staff, and staff files do not contain training records. LPA advises, per OS Section 80066(e) Personnel Records, that the facility ensure that these records are available on site. 3) File for resident R1 (See LIC 811) has a medication administration record that does not reflect medication was administered on resident's first day in care. This is due to the facility not receiving the resident's medication until the following day. LPA advises as technical assistance that the facility note on the log why medication was not administered on any day medications are not administered for R1 and future youth. The facility has otherwise maintained compliance with applicable licensing requirements during the provisional licensure period. There are no pending items for the licensee to complete in order for the facility to qualify for full transitional shelter care facility licensure. The regular, non-provisional license will be generated and provided to the facility. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with Core Program Supervisor Damian Nomellini, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, based on LPA's observations and interviews with residents and staff, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violation(s) did or did not occur. Therefore, the allegation is Unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report left with Core Program Supervisor Damian Nomellini, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 6/26/2023 at 1:00PM, a meeting was coordinated between Dept. of Social Services representatives, Contra Costa County, and Facility Representatives. The attendees were as follows: Nelson Martinez - Regional Manager, Community Care Licensing (RM) Helga Wong - Licensing Program Manager, Community Care Licensing (LPM) Selena Hood - Licensing Program Analyst, Community Care Licensing (LPA) Alicia Bernstein - Manager of Placement Support Services, Family Intake and Engagement Unit Julie Waters - Manager, Family Intake and Engagement Unit Adele Carson - Program Analyst, Family Intake and Engagement Unit Lori Castillo - Division Manager, Contra Costa County Hannah Slade - Children and Family Analyst, Contra Costa County Kathy Marsh - Contra Costa County Vernon Brown - CEO, Aspiranet Laurie Walsh - Aspiranet Monique Nervis - Program Director of Receiving Centers, Aspiranet During the meeting the attendees discussed the Harmony House Annual Review Response initially sent on 6.9.2023 as well as Contra Costa and Aspiranet's response to the review. County representatives discussed the actions that Contra Costa County has taken to lower overstays at the receiving centers, including working with Dept. of Behavioral Health, supporting existing STRTPs and resource family homes, increasing relative placements, focusing on Intensive Services Foster Care (ISFC) homes, and contracting with a company that does extra family searching for relative placements. Continued on LIC809C... County representatives relayed that they have conducted outreach in the community for more placements. According to the representatives, this has included reaching out to other counties, current providers, and currently certified homes. Aspiranet representatives discussed that a youth would not be accepted in the facility if there was a consistency of not being able to provide services to the specific youth; however, youth with no history will typically be accepted into placement. Aspiranet representatives relayed that a youth would not be accepted if there was an inability to safely maintain the youth, but there is an option to accommodate these youth depending on the current status of the two homes. The meeting adjourned at 2:28PM.

On 6/27/23 at 10:30 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Paul Simien conducted an unannounced visit to the above facility. The purpose of this visit was to conduct the required two year inspection. LPA met with Damian Nomellini, Core Program Supervisor (CPS) at the above facility to conduct the required annual inspection. LPA reviewed and completed emergency interventions, operations, staff files sections. LPA conducted two staff interviews (only two staff members to interview) and one client interview (Only two clients available, one client declined). The staff section did not process correctly due to software error. LPA had to manually create eight Technical Assistance forms. The inspection is complete. Four Technical Violations, and nine Technical assistance were cited at this time. LPA conducted an exit interview with Damian Nomellini, CPS and a copy of the report sent to the facility.

Based on confidential interviews, four of the interviewees had relayed that there was a time that C1 was not received into the facility because the social worker had not arrived quickly. According to one of the confidential interviews, the interviewee felt that there was a mistake in calling the correct social worker's number and the number was corrected. Based on confidential interviews, the allegation that a staff member did not follow admission process for one client in care has not met the preponderance of doubt and is therefore unsubstantiated. LPA conducted an exit interview with Zeida Alvarez, Direct Care Staff at 1:50pm whose signature confirms the receipt of this document.

Control Number - 0001624-FN On April 14, 2025, at 11: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kristin Pierotti conducted an unannounced case management inspection at the above-referenced facility to follow up on a submitted Incident Report (IR). LPA met with Brieceida Lopez, Child Care Worker. At the time of the visit, two staff members and two clients were present. The IR was submitted regarding an incident that occurred on February 21, 2025. According to the report, C1 did not take their scheduled medication due to medication not being refilled on time. The incident report was received by the department on March 28, 2025. This is past the 7 day requirement for submitting written incident reports to the department. LPA is issuing a citation for California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Article 6, Section Reporting Requirements. See attached LIC809D page. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed, and a copy of this report was left with Brieceida Lopez, Child Care Worker whose signature confirms receipt.

Control Number - 001625-FN On April 14, 2025, at 12: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kristin Pierotti conducted an unannounced case management inspection at the above-referenced facility to follow up on a submitted Incident Report (IR). LPA met with Brieceida Lopez, Child Care Worker. At the time of the visit, two staff members and three clients were present. The IR was submitted regarding an incident that occurred on March 14, 2025. According to the report, C1 was not offered their medication that day. During the visit, LPA conducted an interview with Child Care Worker to obtain additional information regarding C1 not being offered their medication. Upon review of further documentation, it was found that staff had thought C1 was offered medication on the previous shift. LPA offered technical assistance and best practice advice to avoid similar incidents in the future. No citations were issued at this visit. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was left with Brieceida Lopez, Child Care Worker, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On Friday, November 6, 2020, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Helga Wong made an announced visit for a scheduled Prelicensing inspection. LPA and LPM met with Aspiranet Executive Director Vernon Brown and Division Director Mickie Allen. Aspiranet has submitted an application for a transitional shelter care facility license for a capacity of 6 ambulatory children ages 0-17. There are currently no children in care, and care staff need to be hired. LPA and LPM conducted a walk-through of the facility. The facility is a one-story, tan house in a suburban residential neighborhood. The house and grounds are in good repair, free of mess, and free of obstructions. There are no bodies of water and no firearms or ammunition on the premises. It will be staff policy to not bring any firearms or ammunition to the facility. Knives and sharps are stored in two locked drawers in the kitchen. The lock will be kept on staff's person. Chemicals, cleaning solutions, and laundry detergents will be stored in the locked cabinet under the sink. Medications will be stored in a locked drawer in the staff office. The facility will have a refrigerator lockbox for medications that require refrigeration. There are utensils to meet the needs of 6 youth. There is a front play space for young children in the front of the house and another lounge space for older youth in the back of the house. The facility will have a menu posted on the refrigerator. The facility has signs ready to be put up that cover house rules, activities, diaper changing, and crib safety. The license, facility sketch, and the emergency plan will be posted high on the wall in the front of the house. There are three bedrooms. Two rooms are double-occupancy with single beds, and one room will be for two children but can sleep three in two single beds and one crib. The facility intends to only sleep three in this room if the youth are siblings. All beds have mattress pads. There is one bathroom near the bedrooms, and one bathroom off of the staff office. Facility files and personnel files will be kept in the staff office. Staff keys will be kept on their person; personal keys and car keys can be stored in the locked staff drawer. Children's files will be kept in locked cabinets in the administrative intake room at the front of the house. First aid kit was observed to be complete and stored in the administrative intake room. Smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and are functioning properly. The fire extinguisher was present and up to code. The fire place is non-operational with a plastic plant on display. The garage will be used for staff vehicles and for storage of extra supplies for youth, including clothing for youth who arrive with too few or ill-fitting items. The facility does not have a facility vehicle. The transportation procedures for youth were discussed, including social workers transporting youth, staff license and vehicle inspection procedure, and car seats for young children. There are alarms on all exterior doors and windows. The backyard has a grassy area, a deck, and gravel paths on the sides of the house. There is a chain fence on the back of the yard, which opens to a downward sloped hill. There are a few gaps under the fence that staff will watch to ensure they don't become large enough to allow a youth to climb under. The air conditioning was observed to be functioning, and room temperature was within permitted range. Water temperature was measured at the kitchen sink and the hallway bathroom sink. Both measures were under the permitted range, as the gas had been turned off, and the pilot light is off, so there is no hot water. During visit, a maintenance worker was called, arrived, was screened at entry, and turned on the gas. At 12:30PM, the water temperatures were retested and measured within in range at 108. F at the kitchen sink and 110. F at the bathroom sink. There is a drop-ladder to the attic in the hallway. It can be pulled down by a tab. A safety plan will be developed for the use of this space or way to secure the latch to ensure it is inaccessible to youth in care. When the plan is developed, a statement about the plan will be sent to LPA Hawkins, and a meeting will be set with LPA Hawkins to view any alterations to the latch. The physical plant requirements have been met. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report left with Vernon Brown and Mickie Allen. Vernon Brown's signature on this form confirms receipt.
