narrative: On 12/04/2020 at 12:20PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins met with Core Program Director Monique Perry Nervis for a follow-up visit to review the secured attic access door. This visit was scheduled with Monique and Core Division Director Mickie Allen and was conducted as a televisit over FaceTime due to COVID-19 pandemic safety orders. On 11/06/2020, an initial prelicensing inspection was conducted, which determined that the physical plant requirements had been met. Today's visit is only to view the secured attic access door discussed during that visit. At the initial inspection, staff stated that, once locked, the attic access will remain locked and only accessible to staff. The attic can be used as storage. Children/clients will not be allowed in the attic space. Prior to today's visit, photos of the lock securing the door were provided to LPA. During the visit, staff demonstrated that the lock and door were secure by pulling on the latch. Staff also demonstrated how to unlock the lock. LPA observed the lock and door to be very secure. The site status as ready for licensure is unchanged. Physical plant requirements have been met. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was sent to Core Division Director Mickie Allen and Core Program Director Monique Perry Nervis, who agreed to sign the copy of this report emailed by LPA and return to LPA a signed copy signifying receipt.

On Monday 05/10/21 at 1:30PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a visit at the facility for a Post-Licensing Inspection. LPA met with Program Director Monique Nervis and informed her of the purpose of the visit. As a COVID-19 safety precaution, this visit was conducted as a televisit over FaceTime. There were three staff present, including Program Director, and one youth in placement. The youth was sleeping in Bedroom 3. LPA toured the interior and exterior of the facility and observed the site to be clean, in good repair, and free of obstructions and hazards. There are no bodies of water on the premises, and Program Director confirmed there are no firearms. The backyard was well-maintained and clear of debris or hazards. The staff office has staff desks, an attached bathroom (staff bathroom but is also used for youth who need additional support, such as those with lice), and a closet used as a file room. Client files are stored in locked cabinets in the file room. Medications are stored in a locked cabinet in the file room. Medication administration logs are kept with the medication, as well as administration instructions, and copies of the logs are stored in client files. Facility does not currently have youth with medications, but Program Director confirmed that medications are to be separated by client. The right from room is the admin area where intakes are done. The first aid kids were stored in this room, and the license was posted here. The living area consists of two lounge spaces, one suitable for all ages and one tailored to younger children. The kitchen and dining spaces are clean. The refrigerator is full of food, such as eggs, juice, milk, and yogurt, and the freezer contained waffles and sausages. Thermometers are kept inside to monitor the temperatures, which were in the required ranges. Pantry was also inspected. The menu is posted on the wall in the hallway next to the office. The facility sketch, emergency plan, personal rights, and foster youth rights were also posted here. Laundry chemicals and cleaning supplies are stored in the locked cabinet under the kitchen sink and in locked cabinets in the garage. Knives are inaccessible. There are three youth bedrooms and one youth bathroom. The bedrooms are double occupancy with single beds, except for Bedroom 1, which also has a crib and changing table, as approved by CCL. Beds have mattress pads and linens. Extra linens are stored in the upper shelving of the closet. Youth was sleeping in Bedroom 3, so this room was not closely inspected. The bathroom is clean and tidy. A few bathroom cleaners are stored in a locked cabinet under the bathroom sink. All locked cabinets can be opened by a magnet key only accessible to staff. The attic access latch is locked with a physical lock, the key to which is only accessible to staff. The facility has maintained compliance with all applicable licensing requirements during the provisional licensure period. There are no pending items for the licensee to complete in order for the facility to qualify for standard transitional shelter care facility licensure. Licensee will be notified and sent a copy once the license is ready. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with Program Director Monique Nervis, who agreed to receive the report by email and return to LPA a signed copy.

On 6/17/22 at 10:20AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins met with Administrator Monique Nervis for a case management visit. LPA informed of the purpose of the visit. During an investigation at the facility, LPA observed that an incident report for an incident on 12/05/21 did not match the shift notes describing the incident on that day. Per the submitted incident report, the youth left on an unauthorized absence because the youth wanted to go to the park and had asked staff to take the youth but no staff were available at that time. However, the shift notes indicate there was a longer, escalated event in which the youth was upset about television time and the need to take turns with other youth in care. This incident required multiple staff to engage with the youth to attempt to de-escalate the youth. Then, the youth left. However, staff statements of the incident were consistent and indicate, along with the shift notes, that staff followed program procedures to attempt de-escalation and prevent unauthorized absence. The tmie of the unauthorized absence matches, as well. Additionally, the facility has not shown a trend of missing information in incident reports or not following reporting requirements. LPA advises the facility, per Operating Standards (OS) Section Reporting Requirements, that incident reports should include a detailed narrative of the incident and events leading up to the incident. See LIC 9102, dated 6/17/22. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator Monique Nervis, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

investigation_findings: 13On 03/14/23 at 1: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng conducted a complaint inspection at listed facility and spoke with Monique Nervis, Administrator. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegation. During the investigation, LPA Ng reviewed documents and conducted interviews with staff and client. Based on documents reviewed, the facility separated the clients, offered mediation between the clients, and offered to put personal property in a secure area. In addition to the documents reviewed, all interviewed parties confirmed that client was allowed to go on walks. Although, the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that client is making verbal and physical threats to another client, Client is stealing and damaging another client's personal property, Staff is not making arrangements for transportation for a client's medical appointments, Client feels unsafe in the facility and Client is not allowed to go on walks for physical therapy. Therefore, the above allegations are unsubstantiated. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report was given to Monique Nervis, Administrator. UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

narrative: On 6/26/2023 at 1:00PM, a meeting was coordinated between Dept. of Social Services representatives, Contra Costa County, and Facility Representatives. The attendees were as follows: Nelson Martinez - Regional Manager, Community Care Licensing (RM) Helga Wong - Licensing Program Manager, Community Care Licensing (LPM) Selena Hood - Licensing Program Analyst, Community Care Licensing (LPA) Alicia Bernstein - Manager of Placement Support Services, Family Intake and Engagement Unit Julie Waters - Manager, Family Intake and Engagement Unit Adele Carson - Program Analyst, Family Intake and Engagement Unit Lori Castillo - Division Manager, Contra Costa County Hannah Slade - Children and Family Analyst, Contra Costa County Kathy Marsh - Contra Costa County Vernon Brown - CEO, Aspiranet Laurie Walsh - Aspiranet Monique Nervis - Program Director of Receiving Centers, Aspiranet During the meeting the attendees discussed the Harmony House Annual Review Response initially sent on 6.9.2023 as well as Contra Costa and Aspiranet's response to the review. County representatives discussed the actions that Contra Costa County has taken to lower overstays at the receiving centers, including working with Dept. of Behavioral Health, supporting existing STRTPs and resource family homes, increasing relative placements, focusing on Intensive Services Foster Care (ISFC) homes, and contracting with a company that does extra family searching for relative placements. Continued on LIC809C... County representatives relayed that they have conducted outreach in the community for more placements. According to the representatives, this has included reaching out to other counties, current providers, and currently certified homes. Aspiranet representatives discussed that a youth would not be accepted in the facility if there was a consistency of not being able to provide services to the specific youth; however, youth with no history will typically be accepted into placement. Aspiranet representatives relayed that a youth would not be accepted if there was an inability to safely maintain the youth, but there is an option to accommodate these youth depending on the current status of the two homes. The meeting adjourned at 2:28PM.

On 2/8/2024 at 11:35AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Selena Hood conducted an unannounced visit to the licensed facility. The purpose of this visit was to conduct the required annual inspection. LPA met with James Leonard, Supervisor. The facility had a census of three clients. At the time of the inspection, there were three clients and two staff members present. LPA conducted a physical plant inspection of the facility. At the time of the inspections, two of the three bedrooms were in use. LPA observed that there was sufficient food and the medications were kept locked. LPA did not observe physical plant deficiencies. LPA reviewed the three client files for the three current clients. LPA did not observe deficiencies in the client files. LPA reviewed five staff files. The staff files were provided by Damian Nomellini, Administrator Back-up, digitally. LPA conducted interviews with two staff members and two clients in care. LPA did not interview one client in care because they were an infant. LPA reviewed the emergency binder, employee manual, and the Board of Supervisors' minutes. During the annual inspection, LPA was informed that the administrator on file is on leave from their position. Damian Nomellini has been acting as the backup administrator. Further review is necessary in order to finish the required annual inspection, LPA will return. No deficiencies were cited at this time. LPA conducted an exit interview with Brianna Ligon, Associate Core Division Director, at 3:15PM whose signature confirms the receipt of this document.

On 03/26/2025 at 10:00am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kristin Pierotti LPA Suzanne Martinez conducted an unannounced Annual Inspection at listed facility. LPA met with Ebony Smith, Core Program Supervisor and toured the facility inside and out. The Temporary Shelter Care Facility is licensed to serve 6 clients. Present during the inspection were 3 staff and 3 clients. At 10:10am LPA Pierotti and LPA Martinez reviewed 5 client files. Client files were up to date and contained all necessary documentation. LPA Pierotti was emailed 5 staff files for review as files are kept at an off-site location. Due to lack of internet connection, LPA was unable to review the files during today's inspection. All staff did have fingerprint clearance through Guardian. At 12:00pm, LPA Pierotti and LPA Martinez toured the facility. LPAs observed 3 bedrooms and 1 bathroom. LPAs observed facility license, personal rights, facility sketch, meal menu, and other forms posted on the walls throughout the facility. LPA Pierotti tested the water temperature and found it to be 120.6 degrees, the facility has a sign posted indicating that water temperature is hot. The thermostat read 68 degrees which is within range. Sharps were locked and chemicals were safely stored. There were two days of perishable foods and seven days non-perishable foods present. LPAs observed activity supplies in the garage. The facility is in good repair and clean. At 12:20pm, LPAs toured the backyard. There were no open bodies of water. The backyard was in good repair and clean. At this time no interviews were conducted. The 3 clients present were all asleep. LPAs will return to conduct the necessary interviews with staff and clients. At this time there were no deficiencies. The annual inspection is not complete at this time. LPAs will return at a later date to complete the inspection. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was given to Ebony Smith, Core Program Supervisor, whose signature confirms receipt.

On 08/26/2024 at 11: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mona Lam and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Helga Wong visited the facility. The purpose of this visit was to conduct the Pre-Licensing inspection. LPA and LPM met with Gilbert Murillo, Damion Wright, Priscilla Mojica-Angulo, Erica Kemp, Dennis Phan, Elliot Franklin, and Jackie Mercado. LPA and LPM conducted a review of the physical plant. A fireplace is covered in the living room and currently not in used. LPA and LPM observed three bedrooms utilized for clients as well as 2.5 bathrooms. The facility had sufficient amount of perishable and non-perishable food items. LPA and LPM observed a broken microwave in the kitchen in addition to menu plan not being posted. The facility will install a microwave by 8/21/24 and send photographic proof by 8/28/24. In addition, the facility will post the menu by 8/21/24 and send photographic proof to LPA by 8/28/24. LPA and LPM observed that the files and medications were kept in locked cabinets inside the locked staff office. Cleaning supplies were observed to be kept in a locked closet. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and functional during inspection.LPA Lam measured the hot water in the bathroom to reach 107.2 degrees Fahrenheit. LPA and LPM observed foster youth bill of rights not posted in addition to not posting evacuation plan and facility sketch. The facility will post the bill of rights, evacuation plan, and facility sketch by 8/28/24 and send photographic proof to LPA. LPA and LPM reviewed two staff files. Based on the review, the staff members were missing their updated CPR Certification cards. The facility will update the staff files to include the CPR Certification card by end of day on 8/28/24. LPA and LPM conducted one confidential interview. The facility had three clients in care at the time of the inspection, two of the clients were on an outing. One client is in the facility. LPA and LPM reviewed two client files. The facility was missing signed admission agreements. The facility will provide updated client files via email by the end of day on 8/28/2024. An exit interview was conducted with Gilbert Murillo, Assistant Director, and Pricilla Mojica-Angulo at 2:30pm. Assistant Director's signature confirms the receipt of this document.

On 10/4/2024 at 11:00am, a virtual meeting was conducted to provide Technical Assistance to the Santa Clara County (SCC) representatives. The following attendees were present at the meeting: Nelson Martinez - CCL Regional Manager, Fresno (RM) Helga Wong - CCL Regional Manager, San Jose (RM) Mona Lam - CCL Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chadwyck Moore - Provider Analyst, System of Care Branch Alicia Bernstein - Program Manager, System of Care Branch (PM) Maya Staheli - Provider Analyst, System of Care Branch Javier Guerrero - System Director, County of Santa Clara Aaron Voit - County Counsel, County of Santa Clara Priscilla Mojica-Angulo - Program Manager, Santa Clara County Daniel Little - Director of Santa Clara County Social Services Agency Clarence Cisneros Jones - Designated Administrator for Riverview TrSCF and Hidden Valley TrSCF During the meeting, Santa Clara County (SCC), Community Care Licensing (CCL), and System of Care (SOC) representatives discussed the recent concerns pertaining to Hidden Valley TrSCF, emergency intervention plans, neighborhood policies and community resources, and application for a site on Almaden Expressway. SOC representatives discussed about McKinley contract (trauma-informed training) and AB 1811 (Statutes of 2018, Chapter 35) as suggestions to provide support to Hidden Valley TrSCF. In addition, SOC representatives suggested memorandum/memo of understanding (MOU) when working with law enforcement. SCC representatives informed on importance of staff members' safety regarding supervision over residents. In addition, SCC representatives stated in the implementation of therapeutic crisis intervention (TCI) training, Wraparound program, and harm-reduction plan to de-escalate. SCC representatives shared goals in increasing activity engagement of youths. The executives have quarterly meetings with local law enforcement and planned to do community outreach. RM Wong shared and had a discussion regarding the control of property at Hidden Valley TrSCF. In addition, there is a discussion of possibly a new application; SCC informed CCL there is no care or operation of that site. SCC states to CCL in remembering conversation in June 2024 regarding unlicensed operation. SCC stated the site operations at Morgan Hill have been paused at the moment. The only sites that are in use are Riverview TrSCF and Hidden Valley TrSCF. The meeting was adjourned at 12: PM. This report will be sent for digital signature.

A Type A citation includes 86670 (h)(13) Client Records and a Type B citation includes 86672(c)(14) Personal Rights under the Transitional Shelter Care Facility (TrSCF) Operating Standards. A technical violation is issued under 86620(a) under the TrSCF Operating Standards. An exit interview was conducted with Clarence Cisneros-Jones. A copy of the report and an appeals rights page were discussed and left with Clarence Cisneros-Jones.
investigation_findings: 13On 12/27/24, at 2: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mona Lam conducted an unannounced visit to Almaden Expressway TrSCF. The purpose of this visit was to deliver the findings on the listed allegations. LPA Lam met with Clarence Cisneros-Jones. Based on medication administration records between October 2024 and November 2024, there are multiple unmarked days observed on the documents. In addition, within confidential interviews, staff admit some incidents of client's prescription not available for client to take. Based on confidential interviews, staff have confirmed that packages and/or mail are inspected prior to handing to clients. Based on transitional shelter monthly reports of October 2024 and November 2024 and confidential interviews, some clients are found to be staying at the facility beyond the 10-day placement limit. There is a preponderance of evidence to SUBSTANTIATE the above-mentioned allegations. SubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

narrative: On 5/30/2025 at 3: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mona Lam conducted an announced inspection at Almaden Expressway TrSCF. The purpose of this visit was to follow on a video that was submitted to the department. LPA met with Priscilla Mojica-Angelo. No further action was taken. LPA conducted an exit interview with Priscilla Mojica-Angelo whose signature confirms the receipt of this document.

investigation_findings: 13On 5/30/2025 at 3: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mona Lam conducted an announced inspection at Almaden Expressway TrSCF. The purpose of this visit was to deliver the findings for the above allegations for a closed site. LPA met Priscilla Mojica-Angelo. During the investigation, LPA conducted 8 confidential interviews. LPA reviewed incident reports. Per confidential interviews, there were inconsistent statements regarding whether a client was physically assaulted by staff and if staff failed to get medical attention for client. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are UNSUBSTANTIATED. LPA conducted an exit interview with Priscilla Mojica-Angelo whose signature confirms the receipt of this document. UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

narrative: On 12/10/2024 at 1:30PM, a virtual meeting was conducted to discuss the Component II and Component III for the facility application. The following attendees were present at the meeting: Helga Wong - CCL Regional Manager (RM) Carolyn Flynn - CCL Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Mona Lam - CCL Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Simran Nayyar - CCL Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Chadwyck Moore - Provider Analyst, System of Care Branch Damion Wright - Director of Santa Clara County Department of Family and Children Services Priscilla Mojica-Angulo - Program Manager, Santa Clara County Clarence Cisneros Jones - Designated Administrator for Riverview TrSCF and Hidden Valley TrSCF Teana Box - Management Analyst, DFCS Nandini Iyer - County Counsel, Santa Clara County During the meeting, applicant and CCL representatives discussed the TrSCF Operating Standards, Program Statement, and program policies. Incident reporting, personal property, basic services, accountability, personnel requirements, personnel records, ratios, personal rights, manual restraints and emergency intervention plan, admission agreements, medical assessment, client records, register of clients,transportation, health-related services, food services, building and grounds, inspection authority, waivers and exceptions, planned activities, neighborhood policy and community resources, compliance and the LPA, deficiency types, and administrative actions were discussed during the meeting. LPA Lam shared the Community Care Licensing Division website, Provider Information Notices (PINs), quarterly provider meetings dates, different LIC 624 forms, and psychotropic training information. CCL representatives reiterated information on unlicensed care and penalties pertaining to it. LPA Lam discussed the pending items pertaining to the applicant: clarification on roles equivalent to facility manager, physical plant corrections for Almaden TrSCF, and cleared staff background checks. LPA Lam discussed that revisions for McKee TrSCF is due on December 26, 2024 and the Welcoming Center application is due on December 30, 2024. LPA Lam stated if extensions are needed, they need to be requested via email. DFCS stated that Morgan Hill TrSCF application is on pause. The meeting was adjourned at 3: PM. This report will be sent for digital signature.

On 01/22/25 at 2: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mona Lam and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Joel Segura conducted an announced visit to the applicant location. The applicant location is located in a residential neighborhood in a high-traffic area. The purpose of this visit was to conduct the Pre-Licensing inspection for the applicant. LPA and LPM met with Priscilla Mojica-Angulo, Clarence Cisneros-Jones, and Teana Box. Daniel Lopez, Wendy Kinnear, and Matthew Hornung were present at the visit. LPA and LPM conducted a tour of the facility. The facility has two units. One unit is in used for solely clients. Posted bill of rights and clients complaint procedures were observed at the entrance of the unit. The unit contains a five bedrooms and four bathrooms (three client bathroom and possibly one staff bathroom) residential home. The unit uses smoke and carbon monoxide dual detectors, which were tested and found to be working during inspection. The facility maintains the required perishable items within refrigerator. Refrigerator temperature reached 24 degrees Fahrenheit. Freezer temperature reached -12 degrees Fahrenheit. Room temperature reached 70 degrees Fahrenheit. Water temperature reached 105.6 degrees Fahrenheit. Grievance forms were observed in living room. Telephone service was observed on kitchen counter. Priscilla stated that knives and sharps will be locked within staff office. LPA and LPM observed locked hygiene products. LPA Lam advised in buying combs regarding hygiene products. LPA and LPM observed a complete first aid kit. LPA Lam observed school supplies in locked supply cabinet. LPA and LPM observed the second living unit. Priscilla stated that staff will only have access to this living unit. This unit has two floors. On the first floor, there is a living room, two staff meeting rooms, and staff bathroom. On the second floor, there is a staff kitchen with had sufficient amounts of non-perishable items, and two meeting rooms. (See LIC809-C) LPA and LPM inspected the outdoor area and did not observe any health and safety hazards. The outdoor area had a table with benches. Fencing is around five feet, covering the perimeter of the property. LPA and LPM inspected the garage. Laundry applicances were observed in the garage. In addition, Priscilla stated that locked detergents, cleaning compounds, and soaps will be locked in storage closet within garage. Currently, no detergents or cleaning compounds were observed. The electrical breaker for for the garage was not working at the time of the inspection therefore the lighting was non-operational. There is no pool on site and no weapons were stored at the facility. LPA and LPM observed disaster preparedness plan, which was in compliance. LPA additionally reviewed individual forms of client intake, registrar of clients, and youth info. LPA inspected five staff files. LPA and LPM discussed with Priscilla, Clarence, and Teana on ensuring compliance with staff files. LPM Segura advised on reviewing waiver request to include reporting requirements. In addition, LPA Lam advised applicant facility on OS 86661(s) Reporting Requirements. LPA conducted an exit interview with Priscilla Mojica-Angulo, Clarence Cisneros-Jones, and Teana Box. The report will be submitted to management for approval of licensure. Priscilla's signature confirms the receipt of this document. A copy of this report was printed and left at the site. The outstanding items pending for approval are Component I meeting and review of the Program Statement (amending reporting requirements).

On 07/15/25 at 10: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mona Lam conducted an unannounced inspection to the facility. The facility is located in a residential neighborhood in a high-traffic area. The purpose of this inspection was to conduct the post-licensing inspection. LPA met with Erica Kemp, John Carr, Priscilla Mojica-Angulo, Teana Box and Clarence Cisneros-Jones who assisted with the inspection. LPA conducted a physical plant check. The facility has two units. One unit is in used for solely clients. Posted bill of rights and clients complaint procedures were observed at the entrance of the unit. The unit contains a five bedrooms and four bathrooms (three client bathroom and one staff bathroom) residential home. License was posted in staff office and not in a prominent location. LPA issued a technical assistance under 86609(a) Posting of License. The facility maintains the required perishable items within refrigerator. Refrigerator temperature reached 38 degrees Fahrenheit. Freezer temperature reached 9 degrees Fahrenheit. LPA issued a technical violation under 86676(b)(2) Food Service. Room temperature reached 69 degrees Fahrenheit. Water temperature reached 118.9 degrees Fahrenheit. Grievance forms were observed in living room. Telephone service was observed on kitchen counter. Knives and sharps are locked within staff office. LPA observed locked hygiene products. LPA inspected and observed a complete first aid kit. LPA observed school supplies in locked supply cabinet. LPA inspected fresh linen in closet. (Continued on LIC809-C) LPA inspected the outdoor area and did not observe any health and safety hazards. The outdoor area had a table with benches. LPA observed missing window screening and observed it to be in neighbor's yard. Staff disclosed youth threw it in yard two days prior. LPA inspected locked detergents, cleaning compounds, and soaps in storage closet within garage. There is no pool on site and no weapons were stored at the facility. LPA inspected two client files. One medication did not have information regarding on specific symptoms for usage. Information was not mentioned in doctor's note. LPA issued a technical assistance under 86675(b)(6)(A) Health Related Services. LPA did not observe one client file on authorization of psychotropic medication, but has consent of medical treatment. LPA issued a technical assistance under 86670(h)(12) Client Records. LPA inspected client registrar. Client registrar did not include information on contact information of client's attending physician, but information was located in client files. LPA issued a technical assistance in 86671(a)(1)(B) Register of Clients. LPA observed disaster preparedness plan, which was in compliance. LPA additionally reviewed individual forms of client intake, registrar of clients, and youth info. LPA inspected five staff files. LPA did not observe two files to have complete job descriptions. LPA issued a technical violation under 86666(g)(1) Personnel Records. Performance evaluations were unavailable due to their evaluation is conducted end of July. LPA conducted two staff interviews and one client interview. One client was unavailable for interview due to going out on a visit. LPA did not finish emergency intervention and staff file review. LPA will return at a later date to finish the inspection. LPA issued two (2) technical violations and four (4) technical assistances. LPA conducted an exit interview with Clarence Cisneros-Jones Clarence's signature confirms the receipt of this document. A copy of this report was printed and left at the site.

On 07/17/25 at 9: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mona Lam conducted an unannounced inspection to the facility. The facility is located in a residential neighborhood in a high-traffic area. The purpose of this inspection was to conduct the continuation post-licensing inspection. LPA met with Erica Kemp, John Carr, Jacqueline Mercado, and Priscilla Mojica-Angulo who assisted with the inspection. One client was unavailable for interview due to sleeping. LPA inspected emergency intervention training, which was complete in all five staff files. A log for manual restraints was observed. LPA reviewed five staff files regarding training. Some staff files do not have annual training due to recent hires and licensee have not reached one year mark of opening the site. No citations were issued at this time. LPA conducted an exit interview with Priscilla Mojica-Angulo. Erica Kemp's signature confirms the receipt of this document. A copy of this report was printed and left at the site.

On February 2, 2024, at 10: AM Regional Manager (RM), Nelson Martinez, Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Helga Wong, and Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Selena Hood conducted an office meeting virtually via Microsoft Teams. The Department met with Santa Clara County representatives, Damion Wright, Director, Gilbert Murillo, Acting Assistant Director, and Roxana Martinez, Management Analyst. The following topics were discussed: lack of transportation for returning youths going to the Welcoming Center, food services, personal rights/blanket policies and searches, and communication with law enforcement. Santa Clara County (SCC) representatives provided the following responses: Transportation: SCC stated that if a child returns from AWOL within the same 24 hours, the child would be admitted back into the site. If a child is at the site after the 24 hour window, then the facility will coordinate transportation and/or assessment. SCC will forward the correspondence with staff to CCL before 2/16/2024. Food Service: LPA did not observe food service issues during visits. SCC informed that the facilities are in the process of hiring a food vendor to provide all three meals. Personal Rights/Blanket Policies and Searches: SCC clarified that they do personal inventory searches for new admits and search clients that have a concern to bring contraband or unsafe items into the facility after AWOLs. CCL asked that the facility clarify this information in their Program Statement. Communication with Law Enforcement: SCC explained that they had conducted an internal review and discussions with the managers. SCC relayed that they would be sending a memo to all employees and share this with CCL before 2/16/2024. SCC relayed that they have conducted law enforcement engagement at one of the facilities and they plan to do so for the other facilities as well. A copy of this report is provided virtually to Damion Wright, Director, for signature.

Director and Acting Assistant Director relayed that they would like additional technical assistance calls for two of the other pending applications, but they would know more the coming week.

On 5/28/2024 at 1:58pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Selena Hood, Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Helga Wong and Regional Manager (RM) Nelson Martinez conducted an announced visit to the unlicensed facility. The purpose of this visit was to conduct the Pre-Licensing inspection for the unlicensed facility. LPAs met with Gilbert Murillo, Acting Assistant Director, Damion Wright, Director, Priscilla Mojica-Angulo, Program Manager, and Temera Carson, Program Manager. LPA, LPM, and RM conducted a tour of the facility. The facility is a four bedroom and two bathroom residential home. LPA, LPM, and RM observed that the kitchen had sufficient amounts of perishable and non-perishable items. The sharps, pots, and pans were kept locked in secondary locations. LPA measured the bathroom tap water to reach 112 degrees. Smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and found to be working during inspection. One room is currently in use including a furnished bed and dresser. Two rooms are currently unfurnished, the facility informed that they were waiting to furnish the rooms until after the flooring is changed. The facility will provide a photograph of the furnished rooms within 30 days. LPA, LPM, and RM observed the outdoor area. The outdoor area had patio furniture and a self-latching gate. There was a locked storage shed on the facility premises which the facility did not have access to. The facility will coordinate with the landlord to inspect the storage shed and provide a photograph of the inside contents to Community Care Licensing (CCL) within 30 days. LPA, LPM, and RM observed the locked staff office. The facility keeps the client files in a locked cabinets. The facility also keeps the medication, Medication Administration Records (MARs), and Psychotropic Medication Administration Records (PMARs) in a locked cabinet inside the locked facility office. The facility keeps the staff files on an internal server which was observed. RM advised the facility to provide a mock file for client and staff files, facility will provide this via email to CCL within 30 days. LPA conducted an exit interview with Gilbert Murillo, Acting Assistant Director, Damion Wright, Director, Priscilla Mojica-Angulo, Program Manager, and Temera Carson, Program Manager at 4:19PM. Gilbert Murillo's signature confirms the receipt of this document. This report will be emailed for records.

On 6/4/2024 at 4:00pm, a virtual meeting was conducted with an applicant to discuss the pending applications. The purpose of this meeting was to provide technical assistance to bring the facility into compliance with the TrSCF Operating Standards prior to licensure. Throughout the discussion, observations made during the Pre-Licensing inspection on 5/28/2024 were discussed. The attendees were as followed: Angela Carmack - CCL Assistant Program Administrator (APA) Nelson Martinez - CCL Regional Manager (RM) Helga Wong - CCL Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Selena Hood - CCL Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alicia Bernstein - Program Manager, System of Care Branch (PM) Daniel Little - Director of Santa Clara County Social Services Agency (SSD) Damion Wright - Director of Santa Clara County Department of Family and Children Services (DIR) During the meeting it was discussed that the County will comply with the Operational Standard (OS) for pending applications of locations where unlicensed care of youth is provided, including reporting requirements. A copy of the OS has been provided to the facility representatives. Also, during the meeting it was discussed that the County should not operate any additional unlicensed care sites. RM asked that the facility provide the mock files and client files to CCL that meet Operational Standards (OS). RM asked that the facility provide a complete mock file and client file to CCL before 6/18/2024. During the Pre-Licensing inspection, it was observed that two rooms in the facility were unfurnished. During this meeting, facility representatives agreed to submit pictures of the two furnished room before 6/18/2024. Continued on LIC809C.... During the Pre-Licensing inspection, the facility had an inaccessible storage shed. During this meeting, facility representatives agreed to gain access and send pictures of the storage shed contents before 6/18/2024. RM informed the applicant that a plan should be made to ensure that the shed would need to be accessible to licensing during site inspections DIR relayed that Priscilla Mojica-Angulo will be the Administrator and had passed their Administrator Certification test on 6/5/2024. DIR also relayed that they had a second Administrator, Clarence Cisneros Jones who had also passed their Administrator Certification test. Both pending Administrators will submit their packages to the Administrator Certification Bureau. RM requested the status of the next revisions. DIR stated that Morgan Hill TrSCF, Riverview TrSCF, and Hidden Valley TrSCF's next revisions will be sent by their due date on 6/17/24. LPA requested a date for the Riverview Component II and Component III. DIR agreed that they could attend the meeting with the pending Administrator on 6/10/2024. This report will be sent for virtual signature to Damion Wright, Director.

LPA Lam observed there to be soap at the hand washing sinks, disinfectants and cleaning supplies were kept locked, and there were no obstructions in the walkways. In addition, LPA Lam observed a client bedroom that is furnished and the clients' bathroom. LPA Lam conducted two staffs interviews. The client present declined an interview at this time. LPA Lam conducted an exit interview with Erica Kemp, Social Worker I, at 2: PM whose signature confirms the receipt of this document.

On 11/4/24 at 9: AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Mona Lam and Celeste Aparicio conducted an unannounced visit to the above licensed facility. The purpose of this visit is to conduct a post-licensing inspection. LPAs met with John Young, Social Worker I, and Lori Niepoth, Social Worker I, who assisted LPAs with the inspection. At the time of the visit, LPAs were informed Administrator Clarence Cisneros-Jones will arrive at the site within 20 minutes. In addition, two clients were asleep in their respective bedrooms at the time of the visit and one client was at school. There are three client bedrooms, a client bathroom, and one staff office with a staff bathroom. LPAs identified carbon monoxide and smoke dual detectors within the staff office, bedrooms, and hallway. Kitchen is free of sharps and debris. A sticky ant trap is placed on the kitchen window sill. LPAs observed detergents and chemicals in a locked closet in the garage. LPAs identified a fireplace in the living room, which was covered and not in use. Outdoor space was free from debris. Administrator Clarence Cisneros-Jones assisted LPAs with staff files and emergency disaster plan. Areas were identified that can be improved by the facility. LPAs issued 13 technical violations and 2 technical advisories. No deficiencies are cited during the visit. The inspection was not complete at this time. LPA Lam will visit at a later time to complete the inspection. LPAs conducted an exit interview with Clarence Cisneros-Jones, Administrator at 3: PM whose signature confirms the receipt of this document.

On 11/15/24 at 11: AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Mona Lam and Jasmine Cardeno conducted an unannounced visit to the above licensed facility. Priscilla Mojica-Angula, Social Services Program Manager II, provided assistance for LPAs regarding client files, staff files, and additional documentation pertaining to the post-licensing visit. LPAs conducted an exit interview with Priscilla Mojica-Angula, Social Services Program Manager II at 5: PM whose signature confirms the receipt of this document. An appeals rights page was provided.

investigation_findings: 13On 08/01/25 at 12: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mona Lam conducted an unannounced inspection at another site with Clarence Cisneros Jones who helped with the inspection. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the complaint findings. The complaint alleged that staff do not provide adequate supervision to minors in care. LPA Mona Lam conducted confidential interviews. Based on the confidential interviews, staff followed appropriate protocol for youth that AWOL, including following some youth outside and filing missing person's report. Interviews were consistent on changing and re-evaluating protocol based on individualized clients' needs. Within April 2025, five shift reports were indicated AWOLs. Reports are detailed in time stamps of supervising clients' activities and applied de-escalation. Based on client supervision plans, plans indicated strategies in moderating youth's behaviors. On 09/03/25 at 10: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mona Lam conducted an unannounced inspection to the above licensed facility. The purpose of this inspection is to conduct an annual inspection. LPA met with Raymond Gonzalez, Supervisor, who assisted LPA with the inspection. No clients were on site at this time. Priscilla Mojica-Angulo and Teana Box assisted LPA with staff files and emergency disaster plan. One out of five staff files was missing their work performance evaluation. There are three client bedrooms, a client bathroom, and one staff office with a staff bathroom. Kitchen is free of sharps and debris. LPA identified a fireplace in the living room, which was covered and not in use. Room temperature was 71 degrees. Water temperature was 123.2 degrees. LPA issued a technical violation under TrSCF Operating Standards 86688(e)(1) Fixtures, Furniture, Equipment, and Supplies. Outdoor space was free from debris. One window screening has a small hole. First aid kit was in compliance. Staff was unable to access locked storage of detergents in the garage. A few perishables were observed in the refrigerator, but was not a concern due to having no clients on the premises. Thermometer for refrigerator and freezer were not observed. LPA was unable to read temperature for both. Facility staff bought and implemented thermometers towards the end of the inspection. LPA conducted an exit interview with Priscilla Mojica-Angulo at 2: PM whose signature confirms the receipt of this document.

Children's Residential Program Administrator Kim Taylor, Licensing Regional Manager, LaCresha Cook, Licensing Manager, Jennifer Smith, and Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Carmen Escobar met with Rosie Mayzum, Children and Family Services (CFS), Hannah Gutierrez, CFS Supervisor, Dianne Wolkenhauer, San Bernardino Department of Behavioral Health Manager, Adele Gray, California Department of Social Services (CDSS) Analyst, Julie Waters, CDSS Manager, and Nancy Satterwhite San Bernardino County CFS Deputy Director, to conduct a meeting to discuss and review the San Bernardino County Transitional Shelter Program Statement submitted to Community Care Licensing on February 24, 2022. During the meeting the following was discussed: Application and Supporting Documents, Plan of Operation, Program Statement, Core Services and Supports. County representatives were also reminded that all pages in the entire Program Statement should be numbered and all corrections and/or revisions highlighted for ease of reference during the review. After review of the Plan of Operation/ Program Statement LPA Carmen Escobar and CDSS Analyst Adele Gray observed the following: Section B: Supportive Documents Page 4: · Where will staff and volunteer files be kept? How will they be made available for review by CCL (and other departments)? Supportive documents for each position should include: college transcripts, copy of degrees, certifications, work experience, referrals, etc. (staff files). Section B3: Verification of Social Worker Qualifications Page 5: · What specific training will staff receive as the needs of children in can vary. ·Please also include information regarding "on call staff" who might be needed in case of emergency and/or ratio requirements. · Verify number of annual training hours. Page 6: · Expected? Should be minimum of 2 staff and plan for on call staff in case of emergency (re: one staff has to take youth to emergency room, etc.) · Please also include information regarding "on call staff" who might be needed in case of emergency and/or ratio requirements. Also, address whether or not volunteers will be considered in staff/child ratios. Section B4: Job Description-each position Page 7: · Are these attached (staff classification statements)? Section B6: In-Service Training for Staff Page 8: · What specific trainings are required for each job classification for the facility? Does training plan specify any job shadowing? How will it be determined staff are competent/adequately trained? Per regulations: · A maximum of 4 hours of the training requirement may be satisfied by successful completion of job shadowing. · Successful completion of job shadowing shall be verified by a statement completed by the experienced facility personnel being shadowed affirming: a) specific activity observed; b) dates and times of shadowing; and, c) training topic listed in Section 87065.1(c)(3)(A) through (X) that is satisfied by the job shadowing activity. Page 13: · Please address how employees will be shadowed, or for how long (per regulations) and how they are assessed as being competent for facility positions. Page 14: · Training plan is very detailed, including different departments and such. Is this considered "community resources"/using "outside trainers" in terms of your training plan? · Provide information as to where training hours are kept, how departments like CCL would be able to request training logs, etc. for review/verification. Section B7: Facility Program Description Page 14: · What about child's strengths (assessments)? · Is this also considered part of the "primary purpose of program"? Section 3 offers different primary purpose, perhaps combine the two? Page 15: · Within what timeframe (in reference to appropriate placement resources being identified)? · What is the actual protocol for crisis intervention at the facility? · Trained in trauma informed practices, is this separate from the training plan provided on pages 8-11? Page 16: · Will staff be doing the visitation? If so, this would change staff ratios at certain times and would need to have more people staffed. · What would a typical daily schedule look like? How would transitions be done though a trauma informed lens to decrease escalation of clients? Also, planning activities should be through a trauma informed lens as some activities can be triggers for youth. Section B8: Rules of Discipline/Personal Rights Page 18: · What is plan if youth becomes assaultive and staff cannot de-escalate? Section B9: Admission Policies Page 19: · Where will client files be kept? Centrally stored/locked? Available for review? Section B10: Sample Menu Page 20: · What is offered if they do not like that meal or have dietary restrictions? · Describe provisions available for children with special dietary needs. · Portion size (1/2 cup, 1 cup, etc) should be included in menus. Section B11: Control of Property Page 21: · Mention documentation of such incidents (LE incidents/SIR incidents). · Law enforcement should not need to be contacted for disposal of E-cigarette (for example). Please specify protocol further. Page 22: · Are neighbors being made aware of this new facility? Will staff be going door to door? Complaint procedure, grievance procedure for neighbors should also be made available (contact, email, phone number, etc.) PART I PROGRAM IDENTIFICATION SECTION Page 25: · No mention of whether or not the facility operates other activities other than the TSCFs. PART II PROGRAM POPULATION, SERVICES, & CAPABILITIES SECTION Page 26: · Statement regarding the types of children to be served does not mention dependent, neglected, delinquent, pre-delinquent, physically handicapped, developmentally disabled, mentally disordered, or emotionally disturbed children. · What will the volunteers be doing at the facility? · Mention the policy regarding volunteers being alone with clients or providing care or supervision to clients. Page Facility Sketch: · This section requires: -Number of children per room -Bedrooms to be used by non-ambulatory children -All indoor and outdoor space, including driveways, fences, storage areas, gardens, recreation areas, other space used by children (backyard area/front yard area?) Page See Facility Sketch info above. Page 93 (LIC500 example): · Most homes have shifts that overlap each other at beginning/end of shift so staff can update on youth and transition. Other Requirements: · Neighborhood Complaints: How will complainant be notified of findings (phone, email, in-person)? · Complaints/concerns need to be documented and kept on file; please address. Section A required documents that are missing or incomplete: A1. Application-LIC 200: Name listed is Jonathan Byers, should be County of San Bernardino. A2. Application Information-LIC 215: Under "Personal Information" (next to signature), Box A was left blank. A3. Designation of Administrative Responsibility-LIC 308: Needs to be completed for all employees on the LIC 500 who have authorization to act on Administrator (?) Jonathan Byers' behalf. A4. Administrative Organization-LIC A5. Affidavit Regarding Client Cash Resources-LIC A11. Personnel Record-LIC A12. Health Screening Report-Facility Personnel-LIC 503: Need proof of TB test which is included in this screening report. A13. Criminal Record Statement-LIC A14. Emergency Disaster Plan-LIC 610C A16. Fire Inspection-LIC A17. Board of Director Statement-LIC 9165 contained in PUB Section B required supportive documents that are missing or incomplete: B1. Letter from the Board of Sups authorizing approval to apply for a license and a resolution naming a person(s) authorized to apply for the license. *Under this section it states to "See San Bernardino County Board of Supervisors Agenda Item approved February 8, 2022", but agenda is not included. B2. Verification of Administrator Qualifications and Certification: missing. B3. Verification of Social Worker Qualifications: missing (need names of staff/copies of docs). B14. First Aid card: missing, need for all staff. B15. Orientation Certification: missing orientation certificate for Administrator (?) Jonathan Byers. Additional documents missing: LIC 400: Affidavit regarding handling Client Cash Resources. San Bernardino County representatives will contact LPA Carmen Escobar when all corrections and/or revisions have been made. Community Care Licensing LPA requested stated corrections and/or revisions will be completed and submitted by May 17, 2022. If additional time is needed, request will be submitted to LPA Escobar before May 17, 2022. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to Rosie Mayzum, CFS Manager, and Nancy Sutterwhite, San Bernardino County CFS Deputy Director, via email for signature.

On February 16, 2023, Community Care Licensing met with several San Bernardino County agencies, via Microsoft Teams, to discuss the review of the San Bernardino County Transitional Shelter Plan of Operations and Program Statement edits and revisions submitted to Community Care Licensing on November 14, 2022. Children's Residential Program Licensing Regional Manager, LaCresha Cook, Licensing Program Managers, Jennifer Smith and Natasha Dunlap, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Carmen Escobar and Darlene Oseguera and Larry Fluharty, California Foster Care Ombudsperson met with Rosie Mayzum, Children and Family Services (CFS), CFS Supervisor, Eric Raley, Probation Division Director II and Amber McChristian, Social Service Practitioner. During the meeting the following was discussed: revisions to Application and Supporting Documents, Plan of Operation, Program Statement, Core Services and Supports. The opportunity for questions about the revisions was provided to facility representatives with a summarized review of revisions. The following is a summary of the review of the revisions to the Plan of Operation/ Program Statement completed by LPA Carmen Escobar, Systems of Care (SOC) Policy Analyst Gina Jones, and California Foster Care Ombudsperson, Larry Fluharty. Ombudsperson Review and Feedback: - Training on Foster Youth: mandatory training on Foster Youth Rights would go long way toward reducing Rights violations -The social worker must use the materials developed by the OFCO to provide the child their written copy of their rights, WIC §16164(e) -The rights below do not reflect the current 41 rights as updated by AB175(2019) and AB1735 (2022) -It is suggested to abandon use of archaic military term, AWOL. It is recommended to use Absent from Placement without Permission, or something similar. -Is there a separate designation for children who are believed or known to have been abducted? -How is exploitation determined? -It is recommended to add the child's parents, tribe, tribal social worker for children with tribal affiliation, attorney, juvenile court judge if court involved. -Specify how an NMD can be AWOL/ Absent from Placement without Permission. -Is there separate direction on what to do for a youth returning from a period of absence without permission? Does it matter the length of absence 10 mins, 2hrs., 2 days? -This is an overly broad statement and inconsistent with law: CFS is authorized to attain any medically necessary medical services..... -This does not account for religious and culturally necessary diets. -Overall this section does well at protect the youths rights but needs revision to comply with the U.S. and California Constitutions and the Foster Youth Bill of Rights. -Youth are entitled to possession of their own property as well as safe storage for their belonging. This can create some friction. In addition, youth are entitled to as safe home. This would include an environment free of drugs, alcohol and weapons. Obviously, it is a challenge to address all of those competing interests. -The youth should not have any burden to sign that they did not consent. It makes more sense to require a signature if the youth did consent. -There needs to be some better description of the accounting for these items and the consequences for the youth in admitting possession, which could constitute a crime or have other consequence for the youth if documented in case materials. -Is this saying that only LE would conduct searches of youth? I see some value to that but also some problems. -This needs to be better developed to address the youth's right to groom consistent different needs for hair care and skin care based on their culture, ethnicity, gender identity and expression and tribal social and cultural standards. -This should spell out more specifically what is implied that youth 12 and over have a right to choose their own provider and seek health and mental health care including reproductive health without the knowledge of their caregivers or parents. -As stated above, this form needs to reflect that the youth receives OFCO created materials. -Signature should be for consent not refusal. -Notes on exit log: This could be better developed to include the voice of the youth in this significant transition. The current language is not youth focused or trauma informed. -When child is moved, should you notify the tribe, the court, the parents, the attorney, education rights holder, and CFT? -Visitation orders: This is as drafted is inconsistent with law including but not limited to the ICWA and §16001.9. The child is entitled to unsupervised contact by phone mail, video chat unless prohibited by court order. There should be no approved contact list, only unapproved contact which is based upon court order. If there is no court case it should be based upon safety criteria which should be explicitly spelled out. -Activities not allowed: Dating other youth in placement not being allowed. This is a violation of Foster Youth Rights. -The social worker must use the materials developed by the OFCO to provide the child their written copy of their rights, WIC §16164(e) -Personal rights listed: The rights below are not current. WIC 16001.9 was updated in 2019 and 2022 (AB175 (2019) and AB1735 (2022)). -It is suggested to use, Absent from Placement without Permission, instead of AWOL. -Is there a separate designation for children who are believed or known to have been abducted? -Who AWOLs are reported to: it is suggested adding the child's parents, tribe, tribal social worker for children with tribal affiliation, attorney, juvenile court judge if court involved. -Daily log keeping track of children who have run away from their last placement-- it is recommended to expand on how this is a valid data point. -This section is confusing. It needs to distinguish between Title 22 regulation grievances, OFCO complaints and complaints to the SBC Ombudsman. -Publications PUB 339 and 396 cannot be located. Suggested reference to DSS ACLs. ACL21-69 and ACL 22-34 as these are most pertinent. -Youth are entitled to possession of their own property as well as safe storage for their belonging. This can create some friction. In addition, youth are entitled to as safe home. This would include an environment free of drugs, alcohol and weapons. Obviously, it is a challenge to address all of those competing interests -CFS 222: The youth should not have any burden to sign that they did not consent. It makes more sense to require a signature if the youth did consent. -Youth are entitled to an allowance regardless of placement status. Some youth will be in the shelter longer than 72 hours. They will be there weeks and possibly months. There needs to be a method for the youth to receive an allowance in the event of an overstay for longer than a week. -This section should address culturally appropriate clothing, accessories and jewelry. -This section should address religious and culturally appropriate food choices. -The youth are entitled to an allowance. There needs to be a better solutions that what is described here (as addressed above). -Having property "locked up"/"secured" is a violation of FYBOR to have. -CFS222: The youth should not have any burden to sign that they did not consent. It makes more sense to require a signature if the youth did consent. -Youth purchasing items with own funds: This sentence will result in violations of foster youth rights. Youth should be provided hygiene products of all types which meet the youths needs, for examples the program cannot provide one brand of tampons or soap as that brand may not fit well or cause irritation. This is a matter need and not simply personal choice. SOC Review and Feedback: -What information shall the facility request and use to determine the compatibility for the shelter placement for that individual youth? -In version 2, although this information on screening and assessments was clarified in section B7 facility program description (bottom of pg 18) it also needs clarification in Part II program narrative A. Program description (pg 41). The difference between screening and assessments and who gets them, why, when, by whom is unclear. Do site supervisors and social service practitioners (SSPs) do both screenings and assessments? Or does the social worker II and social service aide do the screenings (the word interviews is used in their job description)? Are mental health assessments done by clinicians from DBH only (pg 18)? Are these clinicians separate from staff listed in section B4- job description? Also in client medical assessments - section 6 (pg 45), do all youth get medical assessments? Or is there a two step process involved with first a screening and then assessments? Please clarify. What is the time frame? Who does them? Please also clarify who does the screenings in section B Job Description (it currently discusses the site supervisor and Social service practitioners do assessments and the SWII and social service aides- do interviews if interviews include screenings please clarify) -(Do not see this documentation information in the second version- it could be added to B9, creating a client file- screening and assessments are documented in the case plan and kept in the client file) -Don't see information below in version 2 of admission/intake section: This information should be in addition to the separation room discussed on page 70 - as that is discussed as a room for youth who are escalating. What is the plan to separate children when assessments or other circumstances warrant that separation? Will there be increased staffing? Will the separation room discussed on page 70 include sleeping and housing the youth if needed? Please clarify. How many separation rooms are there? How many youth does this hold? What if you have more than 1? Also what considerations or briefings for staff shall occur to support a less restrictive response to an elevated issue/behavior, should one occur in the future? -Missing this information. Pg 19 you discuss assessments to determine if an STRTP is needed but stop there. What is the communication plan/protocol for when a Qualified Individual (QI) assessment referral from the county may seems necessary due to the elevated nature of youths needs? Do you establish relationships with STRTPs in or out of your area- so they know you may be contacting them? If a youth needs an STRTP level of care how do you ensure other youth are safe in the facility while you are searching for placement? -Missing information: Would like to see a timeline and a list of activities for each day from referral to placement. Is this a timeline on Page 90 (under the organizational chart)? If so, please label as Timeline from Referral to Placement. Is it possible to categorize by day? CCL Review and Feedback: -LIC500 needs to be updated and added. -Copy of facility Admission Agreement is not included. San Bernardino County representatives will contact LPA Darlene Oseguera when all corrections and/or revisions have been completed. Community Care Licensing requested stated corrections and/or revisions will be completed and submitted by March 10, 2023. If additional time is needed, request will be submitted to LPA Oseguera before March 10, 2023. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Rosie Mayzum, CFS Manager, via email for signature. Original signature for facility representative is on file.

On June 29, 2023, Community Care Licensing met with several San Bernardino County agencies, via Microsoft Teams, to discuss the review of the San Bernardino County Transitional Shelter Plan of Operations and Program Statement edits and revisions submitted to Community Care Licensing on November 14, 2022. Children's Residential Program Licensing Program Manager, Natasha Dunlap, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Darlene Oseguera, Larry Fluharty, California Foster Care Ombudsperson, Systems of Care Analyst, Gina Jones, Provider Policy Implementation Unit Manager, Alcia Bernstein, met with Rosie Mayzum, Children and Family Services (CFS), Kristin Hinds and Social Service Practitioner, Amber McChristian. During the meeting the following was discussed: revisions to Application and Supporting Documents, Plan of Operation, Program Statement, Core Services and Supports. The opportunity for questions about the revisions was provided to facility representatives with a summarized review of revisions. The following is a summary of the review of the revisions to the Plan of Operation/ Program Statement completed by LPA Darlene Almaraz-Oseguera, Systems of Care (SOC) Policy Analyst Gina Jones, and California Foster Care Ombudsperson, Larry Fluharty. Section B: Supportive Documents · LIC500 needs to be updated and added. 1. Is this facility a Transitional Shelter Care Facility? If so, why is it named a Temporary Shelter Care Facility in the title? To prevent confusion with the other licensure type, please change the title to Transitional Shelter Care Facility if you are following the Operating Standards for transitional care facilities and adhering to the limitation on the license, that no individual child stays for longer than 72 hours. 2. Nothing was seen in the application about serving under six or parenting minors. If you plan to be licensed for these populations, please incorporate in your section these sections of the operating standards: . 86672.1 - discipline policies and procedures 86877- Personal Services 86878- Care and supervison 86888-fixtures, furniture, equipment and supplies 86874- transportation 86876- Food service 86878. Sanitation 86887.3-indoor activity space and 86668.4- removal and or discharge Parenting minors see subchapter 2- section 86872.1 and 86678 3. If the application version sent May 8 includes the operating standards version 1 dated February 2023. Please incorporate more of section 86678. Trauma informed program practices, service and supports. Although you say that you will use and integrate trauma informed interventions and strategies, Please explain how do you individualize strategies for trauma specific interventions to address trauma consequences and facilitate healing? What are examples of your healing practices? How will observable trauma behaviors be identified, documented, and evaluated to assess the need for services? How will you support children, and staff in identifying and accessing services and supports to heal from trauma, reduce the risk of re traumatization and foster well-being and resiliency. How will you seek to build circles of support for children to strengthen organic, lifelong relationships? Review of revisions submitted March Please put the information under these headings even if the content is repeated elsewhere in the application. B8. Rules of Discipline/Personal Rights page These are out of date rights. The Foster youth Bill of Rights was amended in 2019 (AB175) Current rights are in statute at WIC16001.9 page At each placement change the social worker is to provide the youth with their rights using the material created by the OFCO. . Discharge Removal, Section Page How will a child be notified of the removal or discharge in a manner that is consistent with trauma-informed practices? Will the child have a prior meeting with the new placement or visit before being transferred? How will the staff be transporting the youth to the new placement, while still using trauma informed practices? How will you ensure a timely written child exit log Per OS 86668.4(f)? Pg 57- you say that the goal at the shelter is no more than 30 days. Please revise to say the goal is no more than 3 days. VISITATION RULES AND POLICY Section Page 58 last paragraph- Youth are entitled to visit and communicate with anyone of their choice unless prohibited by court order. DISCIPLINE POLICIES/PERSONAL RIGHTS Section Page First paragraph These are out of date rights. The Foster youth Bill of Rights was amended in 2019 (AB175) Current rights are in statute at WIC16001.9. At each placement change the social worker is to provide the youth with their rights using the material created by the OFCO. RUNAWAY PLAN Section Page 29 & 70 missing AWOL procedures when client returns from AWOL . Reporting Requirements and Continuous Quality Control How will the licensee work together to ensure the data is collected and provided to CDSS to understand the need and usage for shelters, reduce the length of stay youth experience in the TrSCF, clarify and eliminate the gaps in the continuum of care, and ultimately reduce the state's reliance on shelter-based care? What methods are in place to ensure continuous quality improvement to understand gaps in services and work with CDSS to reduce reliance on shelters? Your reporting requirements section should contain the new requirements around reporting. Please add information on overstay and monthly reports to CDSS in section 86661 (s) (t) and (u). 86661 (p) - Please add to your reporting requirement section Pg 87: #11. The licensee must report to CDSS and child's authorized representative of any incident that affects the health and safety "and personal rights" of any child in the facility no later than the next business day. How will you work with the county to ensure accurate and timely data entry and documentation in CWS/CMS? Limitations and Timelines: Due to the TrSCF placement limitations and the need for the county to secure appropriate placement for a youth, the TrSCF staff, partner agencies and providers must coordinate services to meet the time limits. On page You have created a timeline from the first to last day to ensure that each day there are coordinated efforts to meet the needs of each youth within the required time. Please indicate how you will work to coordinate with your local team to coordinate services in the timeline including schools, regional centers, BCBA and mental health providers and families. How will you build relationship among county entities that will support partnerships and strengthen communication to ensure services and timely placements including interagency placement committees, interagency leadership teams and other individual and system level activities to support you in meeting this timeline.

On October 05, 2023, Community Care Licensing met with several San Bernardino County agencies, via Microsoft Teams, to discuss the review of the San Bernardino County Transitional Shelter Plan of Operations and Program Statement edits and revisions submitted to Community Care Licensing on July 13, 2023. Children's Residential Program Regional Manager, Lacresha Cook, Licensing Program Manager, Natasha Dunlap, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Darlene Oseguera, Systems of Care Analyst, Gina Jones, Provider Policy Implementation Unit Manager, Alcia Bernstein,Program Analyst, Family Intake and Engagement Unit, Adele Carlson, met with Deputy Director, with Rosie Mayzum, Placement Resource Division Manager, Ana Del Nogal, Department of Behavioral Health, Dianne Wokenhauer, Administrator Diana Herrera, Social Service Practitioner's, Amber McChristian and Niccole Sackett. During the meeting the following was discussed: revisions to Application and Supporting Documents, Plan of Operation, Program Statement, Core Services and Supports. The opportunity for questions about the revisions was provided to facility representatives with a summarized review of revisions. The revised plan of operation and program statement, and any application and supportive documentation will be due on October 19, 2023 (per facility request). The following is a summary of the review of the revisions to the Plan of Operation/ Program Statement completed by LPA Darlene Almaraz-Oseguera, Systems of Care (SOC) Policy Analyst Gina Jones, Family Intake Unit Adele Carlson and Julie Waters, and California Foster Care Ombudsperson, Larry Fluharty. CCL Review: Pink Family Intake Unit: Green SOC Review: Orange Foster Care Ombudsman: Blue General Comments: Please highlight the changes you make in the next version of the application so we can easily see the changes we request. Section A: Supportive Documents · LIC500 (any updates) · LIC Administrative Organization · LIC Affidavit Regarding Client Cash Resources · LIC Personnel Record · LIC Criminal Record Statement · LIC C Emergency Disaster Plan · LIC Fire Inspection (pending) · LIC Board of Directors Statement - approved 02/08/2022- copy pending · Copy of admission agreement Introduction (page 3 1st paragraph How many youth will be placed here? Please be more descriptive of type of youth facility will/will not take i.e. medically fragile, feeding tubes, youth that require shots for medication, pregnant teens, etc. B3. Verification of Social Worker Qualifications · page Staffing plan, qualifications and duties Will there always be a supervisor or manager present? · Are there specific duties that some classifications cannot do? For example, can and SSA administer/pass out medication? B6. In-Service Training for Staff · Page CFS - Behavioral Health Crisis Intervention Training -this is listed as an optional training but would be beneficial for TrSCF staff · Page CFS - De-escalating Clients in Crisis- This is listed as an optional training but would be beneficial for TrSCF staff · Page CFS DSS CSEC 101- This is listed as an optional training but would be beneficial for TrSCF staff · Page 15 (last paragraph - Is it 8, 16, or a total of 24? · Page 16 1st sentence - Will the facility do restraints? If so, need more in detail policy. · Page 18 2nd paragraph- Good Information but the flow is confusing. · Page 20 (2nd bullet)- Structured Decision Making SDM) tools (e.g., Family Strengths and needs assessments), This will be phased out after 2024 and the CANS should be utilized · Page 20 (first bullet ) This list should also include: In the case of an Indian child, maintaining connections with the child's tribe and tribal community. · Page 20 (last bullet) This list should also include: In the case of an Indian child, maintaining connections with the child's tribe and tribal community. · Page 23 - under Typical daily schedule & Weekend/non-school days- Please assign times for this B8. Rules of Discipline/Personal Rights · Page Under discipline, Please use trauma informed language such as "taking space" a "feeling break" etc. · Page 29 under Definitions, Missing from Care is a trauma informed phrase used for AWOL · Page 33 under Youth Returning From AWOL- It is more trauma-informed to use the phrase "missing from care". · Page 33 under Contacting Law Enforcement statement, when out of site- This is subjective. Please site examples · Page 34-Visitation will take place in accordance with Juvenile Court approved case plans, and CFS policy on monitoring visits- How does this align with youth becoming assaultive? PROGAM POPULATION, SERVICES & CAPABILITIES · Page 42 - last sentence Above pages say 0-18. which ages will be served at facility? PURPOSE, METHODS, GOALS · Page 43 -1st sentence the word temporary- Should this be switched to transitional? CLIENT MEDICAL ASSESSMENTS · Page 49 -4th bullet Not sure how this ties into client medical assessments · Page 50 - 2nd paragraph- Hands on medical care- What if is first aid or CPR? Are there exceptions to not allowing to do any hands on medical care? DISHARGE REMOVAL ·Page 60- 5th bullet- Pre-placement visit- Just making note that often youth need more then 1 pre-placement visit to feel comfortable HOUSE RULES · Page 63 7th bullet - term appropriate clothing- This is subjective. Please give concrete examples · Page 63 10th bullet- smoking - Should also include drinking alcohol and drug use Youth Returning from AWOL · Page 74 & AWOL terms- It is more trauma-informed to use the phrase "missing from care". Admission/Intake: How will you ensure all screening and assessments, including QI assessments and services needed and provided at the shelter, will be documented in the child's file? How will you ensure that this information is entered timely, accurately and is complete? (did not see this information) Reporting Requirements and Continuous Quality Control How will the licensee work together to ensure the data is collected and provided to CDSS to understand the need and usage for shelters, reduce the length of stay youth experience in the TrSCF, clarify and eliminate the gaps in the continuum of care, and ultimately reduce the state's reliance on shelter-based care? What methods are in place to ensure continuous quality improvement to understand gaps in services and work with CDSS to reduce reliance on shelters? (Don't see this information) Your reporting requirements section should contain the new requirements around reporting. (don't see and don't see III-B-10 either) How will you work with the county to ensure accurate and timely data entry and documentation in CWS/CMS? (don't see this explained- how will you ensure a timely exit log?) Limitations and Timelines: Due to the TrSCF placement limitations and the need for the county to secure appropriate placement for a youth, the TrSCF staff, partner agencies and providers must coordinate services to meet the time limits. On page You have created a timeline from the first to last day to ensure that each day there are coordinated efforts to meet the needs of each youth within the required time. Please indicate how you will work to coordinate with your local team to coordinate services in the timeline including schools, regional centers, BCBA and mental health providers and families. How will you build relationship among county entities that will support partnerships and strengthen communication to ensure services and timely placements including interagency placement committees, interagency leadership teams and other individual and system level activities to support you in meeting this timeline. (don't see this discussed) can also mention resources like the state level technical assistance and coaching for complex care youth. See guide: https://www.cdss.ca.gov/Portals/9/CCR/Complex-Care-Guide.pdf Regional Manager, Lacresha Cook, advised that if there was any clarification or questions needed to contact Lacresha Cook, immediately.
