This is an amended LIC809 to the original issued 01/03/2024. On January 03, 2024, at 8:45am, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs), Darlene Almaraz-Oseguera and Emina Preciado, arrived at the facility for the purpose of conducting pre-licensing inspection at the facility. LPAs were greeted by Deputy Director Rosie Mayzum, Facility Administrator Niccole Sackett, Facility Manager Hugo Castellanos and Facility Manager Christopher Lukachie. This is a single-story home with four bedrooms and three bathrooms. During the inspection, LPAs completed a health and safety inspection and observed the following: Kitchen area with cabinets for snacks. Dining room with tables and chairs for six clients. The smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and are in operable working order during the time of the inspection. The water temperature is no more than 120 degrees and there are no bodies of water on facility grounds. There is a family room with a fireplace, fireplace screen, and recreation space. Sharp objects including knives and cleaning supplies will be stored in a locked kitchen cabinet. Bedroom #1 is set up with two twin beds, closet and dresser space, ample lighting, mattress covers, fitted and flat sheets, comforters, and pillows. Bedroom #2 is set up with two twin beds, closet and dresser space, ample lighting, mattress covers, fitted and flat sheets, comforters, and pillows. Bedroom #3 is set up with two twin beds, dresser space, ample lighting, mattress covers, fitted and flat sheets, comforters, and pillows. This bedroom is missing a door and closet space. Bedroom #4 is set up as a staff office and has a locked closet, staff bathroom and table with four chairs. The medications will be stored in a double locked in the staff office. Client files and staff files will be locked in a file cabinet. The facility outside grounds were also inspected and it was observed to be clean and well maintained. Based on LPA's observations, the following items that are required to be posted were not posted in the facility: Grievance Procedures (OS 86672.2 (a)), Personal Rights (OS 86672(a)), Ombudsman Poster (OS 86672 (a)(1)). In addition, there was no telephone line (OS 86673 (a)) and no first aid kit (OS 80075 (f)). LPA's also observed that bedroom #3 does not have a bedroom door (OS 86687) and there is no closet space (OS 86688 (i)(4)). The required fire clearance approval is also pending. Per Rosie Mayzum, proof of the corrections and copy of the approved fire clearance will be submitted to LPA upon completion. After a final file review, the facility will be submitted for licensure. Exit interview conducted a copy of this report was provided to Rosie Mayzum.

On 7/12/2024 at 10:41am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Selena Hood, LPA Mona Lam, and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Helga Wong conducted an announced visit to the unlicensed site. The purpose of this visit was to conduct the Pre-Licensing inspection. The following attendees were present from Santa Clara County Social Services (SCC): Damion Wright, Gilbert Murillo, John Carr, Erica Kemp, Karen Roberts, Clarence Cisneros Jones, Edwin Garcia, Jackie Mercado, and Daniel Estrada. LPAs and LPM conducted a review of the physical plant. The facility has two client bedrooms, one client bathroom, one staff office, one staff bathroom, and a backyard. The facility had sufficient amount of perishable and non-perishable food items, the facility also receives food service around 8am and 5pm. LPAs and LPM observed that the files and medications were kept in locked cabinets inside the locked staff office. Cleaning supplies were observed to be kept in a locked cabinet inside the garage. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and functional during inspection. LPA Lam measured the hot water in the bathroom to reach 124 degrees and the hot water in the kitchen to reach 123 degrees. The facility will send photographic proof of the water temperature as below 120 degrees via email by end of day on 7/15/2024. LPAs and LPM reviewed one staff file. Based on the review, the staff member was missing their updated CPR Certification card. The facility will update the staff file to include the CPR Certification card by end of day on 7/15/2024. LPAs and LPM conducted two confidential interviews. The facility had one client in care at the time of the inspection, the client was on an outing. LPAs and LPM reviewed the client's file. The facility was missing face sheet, discharge plan, and a signature from the client and authorized representative on the personal rights documentation. The facility will provide updated client file via email by the end of day on 7/15/2024. An exit interview was conducted with Gilbert Murillo, Assistant Director and Clarence Cisneros Jones, Manager, at 1:19pm. Assistant Director's signature confirms the receipt of this document.

facility_name: SENECA FAMILY OF AGENCIES-THE WELCOMING CENTER
narrative: On March 15, 2021, at 10:00am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Monica Pavia conducted a pre-licensing inspection. Seneca - The Welcoming Center has submitted an application for a Transitional Shelter Care Facility (TSCF) license for a capacity of 15 ambulatory children ages 0-17. This inspection was conducted with Matt Cammann, Jessica Eschman, Eileen Mariano, and Paul Felder and included observation of the following: The facility is a two story home, which includes two dayrooms with one alternative dayroom on the first floor; the second floor includes two dayrooms and/or nursery; both floors include offices and open spaces for play/activities; there are three client restrooms; the facility and grounds are in good repair, and free of obstructions; chemicals are stored and locked in the garage; locked and centrally stored medication cabinet observed; observed medication logs and discussed procedures for psychotropic medications; first aid kit complete; individual beds are in good repair; individual beds and crib were observed with clean linens; additional bedding and linens observed; dayrooms are accommodating of all required furnishings; food storage space observed; nonperishable foods observed; perishable foods and additional nonperishable foods will be bought as soon as licensed; dining room equipped with tables and chairs accommodating all clients; hot water measured at 110 degrees by Paul Felder, from all sinks; all smoke detectors were tested by a fire inspector and appear to be in proper working order; carbon monoxide detector observed; fire extinguishers are properly charged; facility maintains a current fire certificate; facility will be using single use paper and plastic at this time, due to COVID; appropriate forms are posted in view of facility clients; facility does not have any open bodies of water; and, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. The following items were discussed and reviewed by LPA during inspection: Facility procedures for 30-day updates to CCLD regarding participant Overstay logs discussed Currently, the Operating Standards for this site are being developed and approved. Upon approval and the Essential Terms being signed by all parties, this site will be ready for licensure.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Monica Pavia, conducted an unannounced inspection on today's date at 11:15am, and met with Administrator, Jessie Eschman. Locked and centrally stored medications observed. Adequate storage space observed. Individual beds are in good repair, clean mattresses and pillows observed. Individual beds and crib were observed with appropriate clean linens in good repair. Adequate supply of additional bedding and linens observed. Bedrooms are accommodating of all required furnishings. Adequate food storage space observed. Supply of two days of perishable foods and one week of nonperishable foods observed upon inspection. Weekly menu is posted in the kitchen. All smoke detectors were tested by a fire inspector and appear to be in proper working order. Several fire extinguishers were observed throughout the facility. LPA Pavia reviewed 5 client records and 6 staff records. All files are current and complete. Fingerprint clearances were reviewed using Licensing Information System (LIS) on 9/30/21. All facility staff or other individuals who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index clearances and/or exemptions. There were no Title 22 deficiencies observed during this visit.

facility_name: SENECA FAMILY OF AGENCIES-THE WELCOMING CENTER
narrative: ** Amended - name correction on 10/30/2023 ** On October 27, 2023, at 10: AM, California Department of Social Services CDSS representatives met with Seneca and Santa Clara County over Microsoft Teams for the purpose of conducting an Annual Review. In attendance in this meeting were: - Nelson Martinez - (Community Care Licensing - CCL Regional Manager - RM) - Helga Wong (Licensing Program Manager - LPM) - Carolyn Flynn (Licensing Program Manager- LPM) - Alicia Bernstein (Provider Policy Implementation Unit, Manager - Policy and Technical Assistance Bureau - Systems of Care Branch) - Gina Jones (Provider Policy Implementation Unit, Associate Governmental Program Analyst - Policy and Technical Assistance Bureau - Systems of Care Branch) - Adele Carlson (Associate Government Program Analyst - Child Protection Policy Unit) - Damion Wright (Department of Family and Children's Services - DFCS Director - Administration, Continuum of Care and Intake Operations) - Gilbert Murillo (Department of Family and Children's Services - DFCS Acting Assistant Director) - Matt Cammann (Seneca Regional Executive Director) - Leticia Galyean (Seneca Chief Executive Officer) - Melissa Lawton (Seneca Chief Program Officer) - Aiko Yano (Seneca Program Director) The purpose of the meeting was to discuss Seneca's - The Welcoming Center (TWC) and Santa Clara County Annual Review that was submitted on 9/21/2023. County representatives discussed the actions that Santa Clara County has taken to reduce the number of (Cont. Lic809-c) clients entering the shelter, including engaging with the families early on, working with Behavioral Health, Public Health Nurses, Probation, reaching out to learn more about STRTPs of one/two, and resource family homes, increasing relative placement's. They discussed the building out of their continuum of care, building out hospital divergent programs, and utilizing a "Strike Team." It was discussed how the county is working with San Andrea Regional Center for their clients with disabilities. The county explained that they are working to partner with specific partners such as Seneca who have STRTPs for one/two. The priority is for a community based program but will consider a county run facility. Explanation of the Mockingbird Constellation was provided. Clarification of how overstays are recorded/tracked was given and discussed. Review of Essential Terms and Operating Standards will be done to ensure that all agree of methods used for tracking the time a youth stays at the shelter. Seneca shared that the County's transition to placement for first time removals is very often done within the first 24 hours or often go directly to care. Many of the clients that utilize the shelter need stabilization and individual support. Collaboration with the DHCS and the county is working well and meet daily and hold CFT's weekly. Seneca provides a very "homelike" environment for the client who feel safe and welcomed back when they return to TWC. Seneca will continue to support Santa Clara when the new application is approved and will surrender their license. The Department questioned Santa Clara County, when would a shelter be no longer needed? The county responded that there will always be a need for a shelter. RM reviewed that the license for Seneca Family of Agencies - The Welcoming Center will expire in May 2024 and if an extension is needed that it would need to be requested 30 days prior to expiration in writing. The meeting concluded at 11: AM. No deficiencies were cited during this meeting and a copy of this report is being sent via email to Matt Cammann, Seneca Regional Executive Director, for his signature with a request that a copy of this report be signed and returned to Licensing Program Manger, Carolyn Flynn to file.

facility_name: SENECA FAMILY OF AGENCIES-THE WELCOMING CENTER
narrative: Licensing Program Analysts, Sethany Yem and Dung Mac, conducted a case management inspection on 3/06/2024 at 11:00am based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 3 out of Direct Care Staff and 3 out of 3 youth files were reviewed. 3 out of Direct Care Staff and 1 out of 3 youths were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, 3/06/2024). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the Leadership meetings related to the facility's incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the Risk Screening and Youth Safety Plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPAs Sethany Yem and Dund Mac observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Program Director Aiko Yano.

facility_name: SENECA FAMILY OF AGENCIES-THE WELCOMING CENTER
narrative: On April 26, 2024, at 9:30am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Monica Pavia conducted an unannounced visit to the above facility. The purpose of this visit was to conduct the required annual inspection. LPA met with Cheyenne Appleby to conduct the required annual inspection. The facility is a 23 hour and 59 minute transitional shelter care facility (TSCF). This TSCF was licensed in May 2021, for a period of a 3-year term. The licensing agency is currently processing a 3-month license extension. The facility is a two story home, which includes two dayrooms with one alternative dayroom on the first floor; the second floor includes two dayrooms and/or nursery; both floors include offices and open spaces for play/activities; there are three client restrooms; the facility and grounds are in good repair, and free of obstructions; cleaning supplies are stored and locked in the garage; locked and centrally stored medication cabinet observed; observed medication logs; first aid kit complete; individual beds are in good repair; individual beds and crib were observed with clean linens; additional bedding and linens observed; dayrooms are accommodating of all required furnishings; food storage space observed; perishable and nonperishable foods observed; facility does not have a full kitchen so prepared meals are brought in as needed; dining room equipped with tables and chairs accommodating all clients; hot water measured at 112.2 degrees from kitchen sink; smoke detectors are hardwired to the local fire department, which are serviced yearly; fire extinguishers are properly charged; facility maintains a current fire certificate; most forms are posted in view of facility clients (see page 2); facility does not have any open bodies of water; and, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Three client files were reviewed. Four staff files were randomly reviewed. All necessary fingerprint clearances were verified on 4/16/24. Operating Standards section 84072(a), Personal Rights, states the licensee shall post a listing of a foster child's rights. The current rights posted is outdated. Facility will post current foster child's rights as of 2021. See Technical Assistance attached. Operating Standards section 80088(2e)(1), Furniture, Fixtures..., states all containers used for waste, shall have a tight fitting lid. Two (2) recycle bins (with used face masks) and 1 garbage can did not have lids. See Technical Assistance attached. Operating Standards section 80075(b)(6), Health-Related Services, states for all prescriptions or nonprescription PRNs, there shall be a signed physician prescription or prescription blank. Facility will request waivers for prescription blanks of Epi-pens and inhalers. See Technical Violation attached. There were no Title 22 deficiencies cited during this inspection. Reports were reviewed with Cheyenne Appleby. Reports were emailed to Cheyenne Appleby, Aiko Yano and Matt Cammann.

facility_name: SENECA FAMILY OF AGENCIES-THE WELCOMING CENTER
narrative: On May 15, 2025, at 9: AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Mona Lam and Vaishali Singh-Sood conducted an unannounced inspection to the above list facility. The purpose of this inspection was to conduct the required annual inspection. LPAs met with Aiko Yano, Program Director, to conduct the required annual inspection. The facility is a 23 hour and 59 minute transitional shelter care facility (TrSCF). This TrSCF was licensed in May 2021, for a period of a 3-year term. The licensing agency is currently processing a 3-month license extension. At the time of the inspection, three clients and four staff are on site. LPAs inspected three client files. One client file is incomplete due to being admitted on the day of the inspection. LPAs were not able to identify signed copies of written complaint procedures for youth. LPAs advise that copies are to be signed upon admission at the transitional shelter. LPAs issue a technical violation under TrSCF Operating Standards 86672.2(a)(2) Complaint Procedures. LPAs inspected disaster preparedness plan and five staff files. No deficiencies are cited during the inspection. The inspection was not complete at this time. LPAs will visit at a later time to complete the inspection. LPAs conducted an exit interview with Aiko Yano, Program Director at 3: PM whose signature confirms the receipt of this document.

On July 18, 2022, the Department conducted a Technical Assistant meeting via Microsoft Teams with Fresno County. Present in the meeting from Community Care Licensing were, Regional Manager Nelson Martinez, Licensing Program Manager Juanita Arroyo and Licensing Program Analyst Cynthia Galindo. Present from the Family Centered Safety and Support Bureau were Program Analyst Adele Gray and Supervisor Program Analyst Julie Water. Present from Fresno County were Raymundo Zermeno, Rita Bohannon, Christie Lee, and Sharelee Flores. During the meeting, the following was discussed: LPA Galindo and PA Gray discussed the sections that still do not meet the standards, which are sections 10, 13 and 14. Fresno County stated the revisions will be submitted by the end of this week. Fresno County inquired about the Pre-Licensing Inspection expectations. LPM Arroyo discussed insight of what will be inspected. Fresno County is to provide possible dates for the Pre-Licensing Inspection. RM Neslon discussed the next step after the Pre-Licensing Inspection. A copy of this report was emailed to Program Manager, Raymundo Zermeno.

On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cynthia Galindo, accompanied by Regional Manager Nelson Martinez, Licensing Program Managers Juanita Arroyo and Lourey Bartolome and Program Analyst Adele Gray travelled to the facility listed above to conduct a pre-licensing inspection. Present from Fresno County were Raymundo Zermeno, Rita Bohannon, Christie Lee, Sharelee Flores and Yessica Medina. The facility listed above submitted an application for a Transitional Shelter Care Faility on 02/8/2022. The application and program statement have been reviewed and by both Community Care Licensing and the Systems of Care/ Family Centered Safety and Support Bureau. Facility Inspection conducted. 1. Facility Grounds are clean and free of debris or observable hazard. 2. Adequate indoor and outdoor activity space and materials observed. 3. Chemicals appropriately locked under the kitchen sink. 4. Procedures for locked and centrally stored medications observed. Discussed medication logs and procedures for psychotropic medications. 5. First aid kit observed. Lacks scissors. 6. Storage space is provided- 2 drawers. 7. Individual beds in good repair observed. 8. The facility has 6 bedrooms, single occupancy, all located on one single level. Bedrooms are accommodating of all required furnishings. 9. Adequate food storage space observed. Adequate supply of food to be in place prior to accepting youth for placement. next page... 10. Weekly menu is posted. 11. Dining room equipped with large table and chairs accommodating of all clients. 12. Facility has three full restrooms and one bath in the facility for client use, all are operable. 13. Forms posted- personal rights form with licensing phone number to be posted. 14. No firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. The following items were discussed and reviewed by LPA during Inspection 1. Reviewed staff schedule to ensure appropriate staffing ratios. More direct care staff to be hired. The facility does not utilize Peer Partners and volunteer at this time. 2. Administrator will be present on-site a minimum of 20 hours per week. 3. Personnel Files are retained at the office and will be available to the department for review upon request. Facility is in the process of setting up guardian account. 4. Facility is to ensure all clients considered for placement have been assessed as meeting placement eligibility requirements. 5. Discussed implementation of Core Services and Supports. 6. Discussed feedback from CFSD and Program Statement revision. 7. Essential Terms and Operating Standards. On this date, this facility is recommended for licensure after the Essential Terms and Operating Standards are completed. Facility will be licensed for a capacity of 6 clients ages 12-17, licensee will maintain age and behavioral compatibility. Facility accepts only ambulatory clients.

On the above date, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Cynthia Galindo and Jessica Rodriguez arrived at the facility and were met by Raymundo Zermeno. LPAs toured the facility. There were no issues or concerns. A copy of the report was left at the facility.

On October 24, 2023, a technical assistance (TA) meeting was held via Microsoft Teams. Present from Fresno County: Kimberli Smith, Rita Bohannon, Raymond Cerda, Bruna Chavez, Jeanette Deleon, Ellieana Ducan, Samrjian Gohar, Marshunda Harding, Novina Holland, Catherine Hueta, Jill Mason, Devendra Patel, Rita Valenzuela, Pamee Thao, Ana Torres-Arana, Peter Vue Present from CCL: Nelson Martinez, Juanita Arroyo, Cynthia Galindo Present from FCSSB: Adele Carlson The purpose of the TA meeting was to discuss the Department's revision letter. Discussed EIP, Job Descriptions, Inservice training for staff and Administration. CCL clarified the Board of Directors and Board of Supervisors. Discussed the Essential Terms, Pub 326, and the steps to finalize the process. The due date for Fresno County's updates is November 27, 2023, but it is subject to change. At the conclusion of the virtual meeting, a copy of this report was emailed to Rita Bohannon for review and signature.

On November 15, 2023, a technical assistance (TA) meeting was held via Microsoft Teams. Present from Fresno County: Kimberli Smith, Bruna Chavez, Novina Holland, and Christie Lee Present from CCL: Nelson Martinez, Juanita Arroyo, Cynthia Galindo Present from SOC: Chadwyck Moore The purpose of the meeting was to share the Essential Terms (ET). CCL briefly reviewed ET with Fresno County and answered questions. Fresno County said the board will review the ET. CCL said any questions raised by the board on the ET will be forward to Legal. Fresno County said an extension may be needed to submit the program statement updates. At the conclusion of the virtual meeting, a copy of this report was emailed to Fresno County for review and signature. Attachments sent with this report: ACL 17-32, TrSCF Operating Standards v1 and PIN 21-12.

On May 10, 2024, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Briana Placencia and Angelica Borja, traveled to UMC MOD C for the purpose of a second pre-licensing inspection. Present was Licensing Program Managers Juanita Arroyo and Lourey Bartolome. Present from Fresno County were Deputy Director Dalvin Baker, Division Chief, Rita Bohannan, Social Work Supervisor/Administrator: Marshanda Harding,Division Chief Camille Wilson, Senior Staff Analyst: Pao Yang, Staff Analyst: Jesse Ocegueda-Abarea , Commander Fong Vang, Commander Richard Aguilar, Sergeant Michael Meux. UMC MOD C, submitted an application for a Transitional Shelter Care Facility on February 8, 2022. The application and program statement have been reviewed and by both Community Care Licensing and the Systems of Care/Family Centered Safety and Support Bureau. Facility Inspection conducted. 1. Facility Grounds are clean and free of debris or observable hazard. 2. Adequate indoor and outdoor activity space and materials observed. 3. Procedures for locked and centrally stored medications observed. 4. First aid kit observed. 5. Storage space is provided- 2 drawers. 6. Individual beds in good repair observed. 7. The facility has 6 bedrooms, single occupancy, all located on one single level. Bedrooms are accommodating of all required furnishings. 8. Adequate food storage space observed. Adequate supply of food to be in place prior to accepting youth for placement. 9. Weekly menu is posted. 10. Dining room equipped with large table and chairs accommodating of all clients. 11. Facility has three full restrooms and one shower in the facility for client use, all are operable. 12. Forms posted- personal rights form with licensing phone number. 13. No firearms or weapons were observed in the facility. 14. Water temp read 113.1 degrees. 15. Fire extinguishers were serviced on November 20, 2023. 16. Carbon Monoxide and Smoke detectors were observed and in working order. 17. Facility has an approved fire clearance with the date of April 20, 2022. Facility approved for licensee contingent on receipt of LIC 9165 and LIC 309 for all board members. The facility will receive a copy of this report.

Meeting was held at the request of Fresno County to discuss the pending UMC MOD C application licensing requirements regarding the identification of the Board of Directors or governing body for the Fresno County Transitional Shelter Care Facility. In attendance for Fresno County: Deputy Director: Kimberli Smith County Counsel: Daniel Cederborg Deputy County Counsel: Libby Hellwig Teague Deputy County Administrative: Amina Flores Becker Senior Staff Analyst: Pao Yang Staff Analyst: Jesse Ocegueda-Abarea In attendance for the California Department of Social Services (CDSS): Assistant Chief Counsel: Rachel M. Raymond Senior Staff Counsel: Lila Hollman-Dowty Assistant Program Administrator: Angela Carmack San Jose Regional Manager: Nelson Martinez Licensing Program Manager: Juanita Arroyo Licensing Program Analyst: Briana Placencia The LIC 9165, PUB 326 and board members accountability were discussed. The CDSS will provide on-going technical assistance to support the County. UMC MOD C Licensure is contingent on LIC 9165 being completed and signed by Board of Directors. A copy of this form will be forwarded for County signature and a copy will be provided to the County.

On October 30, 2024, Licensing Program Manager, Tamara Melikian and Regional Manager, Nelson Martinez met with UMC Mod C Administrator, Rita Bohannon and Deputy Director, Kim Smith, as well as other County personnel virtually. The purpose of the meeting was to provide technical assistance to UMC Mod C regarding the use of public health nurses and fingerprint clearances. Options were provided by the facility and discussed. The facility will notify and discuss further with Community Care Licensing once a decision has been made. A copy of this report was provided via email to Administrator, Rita Bohannon on this date.

On December 3 2024, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Briana Placencia, Angelica Borja and Licensing Program Manger (LPM) Tamara Melikian conducted a post-licensing inspection at UMC MOD C and met with Rita Bohannon, Administrator. A inspection of the facility was conducted. The Transitional Shelter Care Facility (TrSCF) currently has one client in care. The TrSCF currently employs Administrator, Back up Administrators, Facility Managers, and Direct Care staff. LPA inspected 3 staff files and 3 client/former client files. LPAs were unable to interview as client left the facility without permission and location was unknown prior to the inspection. LPAs conducted two staff interviews. Per the Administrator, there are no firearms at the facility. There are no bodies of water at the facility. There are no pets at the facility. A review of the Licensing Information System on November 26, 2024, indicates that all facility staff are associated to the TrSCF and have DOJ, FBI, and child abuse index check clearances. LPAs/LPM discussed PMARs, staff files, staff training's, posted forms that were in addition to required forms. There were no deficiencies cited on this date. A copy of this report is left with Administrator, Rita Bohannon at the conclusion of this inspection.

On December 3, 2024, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Briana Placencia, Angelica Borja, and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Tamara Melikian conducted a Case Management inspection at UMC Mod C and met with Administrator Janya Taylor. The purpose of this inspection was to discuss an incident that occurred on 11/18/2024 regarding youth in care #1 (see LIC811 dated 12/03/2024). LPAs and LPM conducted an interview with Administrator who stated the youth has a history of over eating to the point of making themselves ill. It was determined to be an isolated incident and no deficiencies were cited on this date. A copy of this report was left with Administrator, Janya Taylor.

On January 16, 2025, Licensing Program Manager, Tamara Melikian and Regional Manager, Nelson Martinez met with UMC Mod C Administrator, Rita Bohannon and Deputy Director, Kim Smith, as well as other County personnel virtually. The purpose of the meeting was to provide technical assistance to UMC Mod C regarding the possible relocation of the facility as well as storage requirements for personnel files. Procedures for relocation as well as options for personnel file storage were discussed. A copy of this report was provided via email to Administrator, Rita Bohannon.
